But I can't continue to work, because employers fire me, as soon as they discover I have epilepsy.

label: negative
message: The reality of it is, it does limit you, and this inhibits you as a person growing up with epilepsy. It is a major handicap that many people don't understand because it is not visible. Even if it is controlled with medication it does not matter. Having epilepsy when I was younger, and they didn't know what was wrong with me, it was hell for me as a child growing up. It made my already teased, and bullied, struggle to learn situation so much worse. I made it, but there is some irreversible damage, and problems that I have to overcome everyday. I am happy that they know more about epilepsy nowadays, thanks to groups like this, and medical research. It is better that everyone can get a better chance at the development, of social skills, mental, and emotional skills, and education, that we all deserve.

author: Amy Mullikin

label: positive
message: I've had epilepsy sense the Age of 3 I'm now 35. I've moved mountain's, and have done things Drs said I could never do after living through 3 Commas and 1 Stroke I graduated High School, had a live birth my son Dakotah Wheatley will be 10 this Yr , and I thank God for him every day. I'm now in Pre Grand College Studying Family in Human Services with a Major in Psychology I'm yet Pregnant one's again. Never let a Dr play God Through the Yrs as a child I also had to relearn to walk, talk and fiction as what they call a "normal" person btw there really no such thing as normal. I can talk, walk, drive, be a mom. You are the only person that says I can't not anyone else, and no matter how much you're friends,family, other halfs ect want it for you. You have to want it yourself to thrive btw the Commas and Stroke keeped me in it for years anything is possible if I can do it so can you!

label: negative
message: Here are my 4 words, Injury, death, rebirth,growth! on 8-28-11 I had an anyuerism and stroke. Many of the things in my life died, career etc. After hospital time I walk out of rehab in only 19 days.  I had my fist seizure months later and was told "post traumatic epilepsy" from the physical damage to my brain. I have had horrible seizure clusters 10-20 in a day. went through the stages of grief, anger by far the worst, still haunts me sometimes but I learned to be a better me. As with any great  thing it is / was a struggle. The harder you try the stronger you become!  I think I am a better man today!  I hope you have a beautiful day for the run!  Lastly VNS Therapy for Epilepsy has been amazing in my case. I am down to a  little seizure that are more nuisance every couple weeks now and again. and a full tonic clonic every couple months. over hard seizing every week, I'll take it!

Due to lack of proper protocol and education IN TEXAS ...

I AM FIGHTING FOR JUSTICE AND CHANGE DAILY .....THE BEST I KNOW HOW IN A MESSED UP STATE AS TEXAS .
..
author: Josette Tharp

label: negative
message: My heart goes out to all who suffer from this condition/disorder as my son and husband both had seizures.  I lost my son when he suffered a seizure on Easter Sunday, April 12, 2009 and died of asphyxiation.  My husbands seizures however did not take him from me, he died of brain cancer in the motor cortex as well as other places.  The most important thing i found out regarding epilepsy is that the patients need to be diligent about taking meds and that they need the right doctor with continuity of care.  Over the 40 years of our marriage my husband would decide he didn't need his meds and we would have episodes of status epilepsy.  He did this early in our marriage but go better because I was relentless about making sure he had his meds.  When our loved ones are having seizures we have to be advocates for them both in hospitals and with doctors because they can't speak for themselves.  They need to see doctors who are especially trained in epilepsy.  My husbands seizures were so bad that we finally got him in to see an epileptologist at Duke University and he prescribed medicine for him that I would administer to him if he started having one seizure after another so that we did not have to make a trip to an ER.  Going to ER always made things worse because the doctors would change his meds and it could take months to gain back the ground we had lost.  My son was a different story as he was very noncompliant in taking his meds and he was also bipolar and had hemophilia.  He was his own worst enemy when it came to his conditions but he was a grown man and as a mother there was only so much I could do to help him especially after the government put rules in place that prevented parents from having access to medical information on their children once the reached puberty.  When patients are having seizures they cannot communicate with medical personnel therefore for those of you who have children or a significant other you ned to make sure that someone has healthcare power of attorney in these type situations or your hands are tied. If things are not available in hospitals that are essential for diagnosis and treatment of your loved ones take them to a facility that has the proper equipment.  You loved ones can't fight for themselves so you have to do it for them.  If i can be of assistance for any of you please feel free to contact me.  It took me 40 years to learn what I know about epilepsy and treatment and i am happy to share what I know if it will help even one person or one parent from losing a child as I lost mine.  Praying for all.  May God bless you all.
author: Brenda Johnson

label: negative
message: We lost our son who developed seizures at the age of 40.  Just 3 months short of living with seizures for nine years.   You cannot imagine our grief.  He was being primed for surgery, but died of asphyxiation before that took place.   We will never, ever get over our grief.  Please approve and research medications quickly to save lives.  Rick Muñoz was our son .  48 years old.
author: Irma Mendez Munoz

label: positive
message: I went through every anti-seizure-free medicine; then as every new medicine came out, I also took that too.  Til, I was out of options!  Medicare & Medicaid spent more money on step- protocol, due to trying the medicine's before that did not work before and I changed insurance companies.   Now, I have learned it is too late for brain surgery due to trying now; seizures effect both sides of the brain.   I also had a Sister pass away from her seizures!  How many more are going to DIE BEFORE THE RIGHT STEPS ARE TAKEN!
author: Mary Priebe

I of course said no and he said "well its not fun for me either so please take your medicine". It was this open and frank conversation that led me to take better care of myself and helped open the door for ys to discuss my condition more openly.

Our neurologist was very helpful in taking care of it for us.

author: Carol Smith

label: negative
message: I believe they tried everything under the sun on me in very high doses at that. I ended up on 3meds and the stimulator in my chest wall. But after 7 heart attacks and double bypass, I guess everything was reset...because it's been 6 1/2 years with no seizures or meds for the past 4months I feel blessed.. So I guess what I'm getting at is , let the meds through.. So people don't have to go through what I did trying to get things right.
author: Carolyn Totton

label: negative
message: I was Diagnosed with Epilepsy and Tuberous Sclerosis Complex when I was nine year's old it was a very Difficult time for me and my mom was told I would end up in an Institution or Dead that was thirty year's ago by the Grace of God I'm still here and in good health childhood was very Difficult I thought I was suffering from a Nervous breakdown this girl spread a rumor that I had AIDS and it went through the whole school what ever doesn't kill you makes you stronger still beating the odds through faith GOD and family. :-)
author: Marc Guzman

label: negative
message: I was misdiagnosed since childhood.  The alienation from my peers due to ignorance and discrimination on the job was horrific.  This was before the government enacted laws preventing this.  I was fired.  My insurance rates were always higher and still are.  Finally in my thirties, we learned it was a benign brain tumor that had been there since birth.  I had the surgery, 3x.  I am off seizure meds.  Seizure free for 30 years, but I have permanent damage from the last second surgery.  I have a tendency to drag my right leg and I can fall a lot.  Also, I have muscle tightness on my entire right side.  I can no longer work a full time job.
author: Monell Servis

label: negative
message: A question I have for all of you, what can you do aside from getting another doctor and writing to the medical board with a complaint when the doctor doesn't listen and is causing your son even more seizures? The board backed the doctor even though it was the doctor who took son off a medication that was working to one that was causing multiple seizures.
author: Julie Su Brown

label: negative
message: Aldo anyone that is interested in surgery ,you will go threw 6 months of testing.Its not something that is just jumped into! My life just began after my surgery almost 19 years seizure free! Better than ever , I started a rental business went back to college was back to work 6 weeks later.And of course wrote my book and console   People for Brain surgery!
author: Debi K Harmon Ference

label: negative
message: Sadly enough , we have one neurologist in Brownsville, Texas oddly enough has a horrible bedside manner and is no more interested in your input than the man in the moon? But what's epilepsy , non complicated, life changing and devastating on families . An eliptoligist in a border town? What's that? Like everything else we are not the most desirable place to be , so we search for answers and research and diagnostic tests for stability . My daughter has that condition , my aunt had that condition, one Jacksonian, my daughter partial complex, right temporal since age fifteen or earlier? Thanks for sharing , it inspires me to know that there is a voice out there for epilepsy.

I changed schools three months later those three months were hell. many fools did similiar things all throughout my education
author: Mia G Vayner

label: negative
message:
It enhanced my depression, finding the right meds became demanding, I had just been promoted when I first started getting them. The meds screwed up my head pretty badly. I had to re-learn how to work in the corporate world. I went from a nearly photographic memory to being unable to remember what was said to my face after I walked away. The stress of changing my life, because it was so much harder, just made everything get worse. I have serious depression as well and the combination has made me a different person. I am angry, I am sad, I am hurt and always feel broken. My seizures are controlled by a nice expensive cocktail of meds, but I eventually have a breakthrough seizure then have to work from there. 
I started making bad choices and feeling like I wasn't myself. It caused me to leave one stressful, but familiar, job for a different stressful job, which I ended up walking out on. I got three more good jobs after that, but was treated differently in every one of them once I had a seizure in the office. I was treated with kid gloves, but in a completely biased way. I was looked over for promotions, I became the black sheep or the problem child. I did work equal to or better than my teammates but it wasn't relevant.
I had friends, and I literally have none. I hurt emotionally and physically every day. I spent five months job searching,  interviewing, writing cover letters and changing my resume and thank you notes only to come up completely dry. My depression is dark and vicious and I have another cocktail of meds for that. Then I take concentration meds because I'm so tired, and I take pain meds because my body hurts every day.
I was fun, funny, athletic, likeable, nice, and good-hearted. Now I'm just not. I used to play volleyball with friends and then at some point I just wasn't on the team anymore. Same with basketball. And happy hours. And sitting with a group of friends with season tickets for football games. And stopped being asked to go to things. Etc.

So other than losing jobs, changing my speech patterns, adding very dark, negative thoughts into my everyday life, gaining 135 lbs, changing how I feel, keeping me in constant vigilance, disrupting the plans of my retired parents, alienating me from friends and colleagues, adding fear to my son and wife if I make a strange noise or breathe funny, feeling judged and discriminated against often, feeling insecure personally, causing me pain, making me a worse person with less ideals and hopes to being judgmental, angry, and mouthy, it hasn't impacted me or my relationships in any way. Aside from those things.
author: Todd Morse

label: negative
message: I always get treated differently because I suffer from epilepsy.  :'(
author: Amanda Roper

label: negative
message: 1978 I was diagnosed with epilepsy, I was 14 going on 15 and in 8th grade.  The stigma was so strong people thought back then it was a commencal disease?  I found who were really my friends, and those who were so misinformed from their parents.   Now some 30 years later, there are still people who when I tell them I had epilepsy their attitude changes.
author: Michael Francis Mangano

label: neutral
message: Yes since i have epilepsy people do treat me different. <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+009E>

message: Yes everyday.... Since the early 1970's, still to the present time.....I wish people would go and get some education on epilepsy.....

label: negative
message: Had first seizure in school when I was 11.  Had no friends afterwards.  Never invited to boy/girl parties,  never went to dances, never dated til I was 17 (was a blind date).  Denied jobs so finally only told those people who HAD to know. Since that decision I've lived a normal life.  Have 2 grown daughters,  5 grandchildren and 2 great grandchildren.  I'm happily retired.

label: negative

message: No, actually.. I was 14 when I started having seizures. I thought people would, but no they didnt, and still dont.. ivr only had one seizure in 14years.. wad diagnosed 20 years ago. Was uncontrolled for about a uear or so

label: neutral
message: Yes. And. It was. Very. Embarrassing. And. People. Still. Laugh. When. I have. Seizures. I guess. They. Think. It's. Funny
author: Roger Berry

label: negative
message: Only if they knew about it.  If I wasn't having a seizure, no one knew.  I remember I got a new boss, he didn't understand epilepsy when I told him I had it and treated me with kid gloves.  He wouldn't let me do anything.  I assured him I would let him know when I was having a seizure.  Fortunately, I had only one in front of him (that was enough)  After that, they finally found the right medications for me to take and my seizures stopped completely. He was still leery though.

label: negative
message: My husband's family have completely distanced themselves from him, many of his friends have abandoned him as well.. He says it doesn't bother him.   He says if they can't handle me at my worse then they don't deserve me at my best...I think that says it all!  Definitely puts reality into perspective and you find out who really will be there in the end!
author: Kristina Kunkel

label: negative
message: Sure did for me. I lost a lot of so called friends after they found out. This made me sad and lonely. But a few remained my true friends. Having Eplilepsy has taught me a lot about being judged and not being seen for who I am as a person.  More as as a sick person. I hate to have people feeling sorry for me.

label: negative
message: They did and still do I'm still trying to decide if having a seizure is worse or being depressed from how I get treated is more depressing

Yes they do… they have to…??? Depends on what you're doing and where you are.

So they either don't want to deal with it or act "funny" around or about it… and there's nothing we can do about this… try and educate but don't loose sleep over it either...

label: neutral

label: neutral
message: Oh yea ! Of course !   Even the family too !

label: neutral

But my husband still ask to marry me i want to have that surgery but i am afraid i have a vns in my body it stops them some times

label: neutral
message: Big time. Very often people assume I have been partying or gotten in trouble with the law since I cannot drive due to my seizures. label: neutral

author: Garry Conway

label: negative
message:
Oh, also, after I was let go from my last position, I was told I was using my epilepsy and depression as an "excuse" for why I "underperformed." I underperformed because I had too much work, and asked numerous times for a transfer to a similar job, or for assistance with the amount of work I had, which was easily quantifiable to be significantly more than my teammates.

So I went from making $41/hour, to $365/week on unemployment, to zero dollars while I wait for my disability claim to be rejected.
author: Todd Morse

label: negative
message: It has impacted me in too many ways to write something short.
author: Todd Morse

label: positive
message: Go onto medical sites. Dont believe everything you hear or see on tv. Just like with snowflakes or giraffe, no 2 people w seizures are going to be a like. What works for 1 doesnt for another, or what works for 5 doesnt for 1 or 2.

label: negative
message: My 9 year old daughter has just described to me that she curls up in a ball and turns ridged and stiff and she shakes and she can't control her body. label: negative
message:
Calm down and let it sink in, realize that nothing has changed and you have to truly evolve to a state of wellness and health and this has to be a serious focus in life… beware of the poisons… and… DON'T STOP LIVING YOUR LIFE
Research your medication(s) and other options and yes educate yourself. 
LIVE AND WALK TALL… and if you fall… you will always… GET BACK UP…

label: negative
message: Actually, kids with grand mal seizures are ridiculed as well. When I was younger, I had a grand mal seizure on the bus and the kid across from me was making fun of me. He didn't know what was going on because of the lack of education about epilepsy.
author: Robin Blakeman

label: negative
message: It is really hard to be a kid with the type of epilepsy that is not GrandMals. It seems like kids only know that type and anything else you are made fun of and treated like a fool.
author: Juneen Fink

label: positive
message: For the that same reason as Timothy Sprofera is why for most of my life i also didny tell people i had epilepsy. And to this day i still have to explain wat a seizure is most time thats hard enough when you yourself have intractable epilepsy. But my son too has seizures they dont always show themselves so we still atent sure where they are coming from, or what kind for that matter.
author: Athena Ramirez

label: negative
message: I have epilepsy from a serious brain surgery I had in my late 30's...
author: Deborah Mitchell

label: negative
message: I don't tell people I have epilepsy because most people don't understand what it is all about and all ready have a pre conceived notion that I am going to just have a tonic clonic seizure and swallow my tongue and loose my bodily functions . America needs to be educated !
author: Timothy Sprofera

label: positive
message: Kids with pedi mauls get into trouble a lot of times due to them being mistaken for daydreaming, not paying attention etc.
author: Sherry Bagnall-Theroux

label: positive

author: Athena Ramirez

label: positive
message: I switched to an Epileptologist and she found the right combination of meds and was able to reduce the amount I take. I've been seizure free for 5 years.
author: Thomas Gene Parady Jr

label: negative
message: My son's neurologist has mentioned sending him to an epileptologist if she can't get his seizures under control.
author: Casey M Johns

label: negative
message:
I drive 4 hours 1 way twice a year to see my epileptologist. I will NEVER go back to an egocentric neurologist again. I have been receiving treatment for 51 years and have seen over 10 different neurolgists. ALL of them had egos bigger than the planet Saturn. And NONE of them honestly helped! I have seen 4 different epileptologists and 3/4 were caring and wonderful. The 1st one I saw told me I had schizophrenia, not epilepsy, even though I had been having seizures for 31 years at that point. Dumped that idiot and sent a letter of complaint to the hospital she worked for. 
The next 3 were absolutely wonderful. 2 moved away and I have been tight with my current one for about 6 years. I love her to pieces! She is wonderful! She makes sure my bones are solid, checks my kidneys and my liver, discovered my brain tumor, she looks at my total health! She is at henry ford in Detroit!
author: Nancy Clark

label: positive
message: Do research on your epileptologist first. The one I saw was awful. Nothing but bad things to say about him. I found a neurologist who did two extra years studying epilepsy. She is not considered an epileptologist but seems more knowledgeable and helpful than that guy ever was!
author: Nicole Witton

label: negative
message: After years on the wrong medication and 3 minute visits with a neurologist, my wife and I found her an amazing epileptologist, he got her meds under control, and they've only changed once since seeing him. It's been 3 years and she's doing so much better.
author: Rebecca Price-Larison

label: negative
message: By this definition the doctor who cares for me and my epilepsy is truley an Epileptologist. I wish he wasn't retiring this month. I'm going to miss the care this doctor has given me.
author: Mark Allison

label: negative
message: I loved seeing my neurologist. My seizures were out of control, but due to circumstances she has moved on and I found an epileptoligist. My seizures are doing much better. I still have some break through, but I am having tests for the rns.....now if I can get insurance to cooperate
author: Terah Stout

label: positive
message: I am seeing 1 on Monday! Hoping for improvement. My neurologist referred me to her.

label: positive
message: God blesses us in different ways. It sounds like this couple has chosen their relationship and health. I pray God continues to bless us all in what we were called to become!
author: Stephanie Rabon

label: positive
message: Thankyou for sharing...my son is a stay at home Dad...my grandaughter has a cell phone and knows what to do if Dad has a seizure...but ppl.judge him not knowing about his condition...he is a great Dad n his wife is a patient hard working lady...hes been having granmal seizures since childhood...its taken a toll on his body...his back has fractures his skull has scars...but the pain thats the worst is the judgement people professionals and even doctors have had its taken a toll on his selfesteem but he is tough and has coped with and learned to accept that society can be cruel and its all because they are ignorant and but for the grace of God they have never had to learn what its like to have epilepsy! I am soo proud of all that live with epilepsy ... strong ppl.with patience to forgive the ignorance...thats just sad society is still so ignorant!
author: Shirley Regan

label: positive
message: May God bless you. My grandaughter has epilepsy
author: Mary Roser

label: positive
message: I too have a husband with epilepsy. Reading your blog I literally thought I was reading my own story. Many similarities. He has had epilepsy since age 8, worked all his life,  controlled with medication until October of 2013, when he began to have breakthrough seizures and since no medication has worked. Dealt with looks when he seized in public but never a helping hand. Remarks from his coworkers calling him names like retard. Or people refusing to be next to him. He underwent many studies, test etc. To determine where the seizures are coming from. He had surgery in December 2014, new year's Eve..we, I thought finally, a new year a new start for our lives. Didn't work. Still seizing, all grand mal, we don't have any warning of when they will come and like you I deal with his state afterwards. He can't work either. And because of his condition, there are many simple things we take for granted I can't have him do. He is going through occupational, speech and physical therapy once a week. He also has a seizure about once a week. We have a family, three beautiful girls. We are doing and making the best of it all.
author: Patty Molina

label: negative
message: My daughter has epilepsy and will never work. She is so drugged she cant stay awake in am. Without it she has more seizures. She has 1-2 a month now. Desparate. God lives her and so do we!
author: Angie Berger Barnett

label: neutral
message: Love this article.  My husband has epilepsy and we have it under good control but it doesn't stop the worry and related problems that accompany.
author: Kimberly Van Gilder

label: negative
message: I have Epilepsy as well as Crohn's disease.  I am unable to work.  I get too tired in even a 30 hour work week.  Luckily my husband is able to to support both of us.  I have had epilepsy for 14 years it is a struggle but this is my life.  I have been seizure free for 2 years.  Hopefully I will stay that way.
author: Kimberly Ross

label: negative
message: I know the feeling i was a cna for 13 years and seizure free for 20 years then i fell and had 3 concushions and my seizures have now returned and cant work and trying to explain that to people and the goverment is hard and when you get looks like well you sstill take care of your child so you can work or get told you can be a waitress when your seizures can happen just talking to someones and drop something and you can look at them and no one can tell you are in one cause it just seems like you are in a daze doesnt help. never knowing when one can happen is the worst feeling in the owrld i am 40 and have lost all but my right take care of my child so far and if i loose that i loose my whole world . i have tried to go to work and i tell them i have a seizure condition and by law they can tell you that they wont hire you because of that but you can tell by their look its why . they just say we shall see what hapens.
author: Brandy Morris

label: negative
message: I have Epilepsy (clonic/tonic) which I was born with.  They went dormant for 22 years, had three, then went dormant again, in 2012 they came back and now medication does not control them.  I had a VNS put in last year and I still have them but instead of 2-3 every month I have 1-2.  I worked since I was 18 but in 2012 was told by my Epileptologist at Mayo Clinic that I am unable to work due to not knowing when my seizure will hit. The hardest thing is losing my independence.  Not being able to drive or work is hard.  But I stay positive! <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+008A> Prayers for everyone.
author: Rebecca Kingsley Gonzales

label: negative
message: Has anyone got their disability on their epilepsy alone?
author: Valerie Martin

label: negative
message:
I had seizures
 from a fall @ 2 years old. Then had brain surgery in 1999. Free from them now. Prayers to all.

label: negative

label: positive
message: I'm a parent of the most beautiful girl who has seuzires and is been a lesson of love because we learn to live every day with the best love you can have and share for each other. when a seuzire happens, we pray and follow the procedure we administrate the medicine and we wait until is over. is not easy I may say, but love give us the strength to be together as family and be there for her and for each member of the family. Love is hope.

label: negative
message: Totally! We get this ALL the time!  My husband has had grand mal seizures since his teens..  OMG, thank u for sharing this!!! <3
author: Georgia DrinkWater Dawkins

label: positive
message: I stayed out of work for quite a while. After things were under control I've been out there working. The stress level has went up this last yr with work and I can tell. After 12 yrs without I'm starting to have the warnings of them again every so often. So my dr and I are monitoring things rt now and trying to figure out the rt med combo. I hate this process. If things don't work I may end up having to leave work again.
author: Kari Wasney

label: neutral
message: I am your husband,and I have a wonderful wife,celebrated 20th wedding anniversary this past 6-21st. I wish you both the very best!
author: Richard Kerns

label: negative
message: The stigma and even judgment from people continues to astound me.  Having gone through breast cancer and the many failed reconstruction surgeries, chemo, septic infections (which is thought is what caused my epilepsy), all of it was easy compared to what has come from having epilepsy.  People treat you like you are crazy, made it up - you name it.  I mentioned in another post, I even had an ER room kick me out, after arriving by ambulance, from a drop seizure that left me unable to walk or control my left side.  But, with it, has come many awakenings.    My politics, my views on law enforcement, pretty much everything changed after one too many abuses - inflicted on me and seeing others (like kids and dogs) go through it.  Mine are not under control either.  Working has gone from professional to little cleaning jobs and stuff (also awakened me to how many of these people are treated).  I have gone through long periods without working, which devastated me and my daughter financially, but kept going.  I'm glad to hear of a supportive spouse and glad I found this site.  After having even my primary care physician treat it like I had lost my mind, I found one of the best neurologist in the country who gets it.  Thanks for sharing your story about stigmas.
author: Gina Goodman

label: positive
message: I hope my daughter has a spouse that will help her and have this much empathy one day. She is 10 and has had seizures since she was born. Last couple years they have been sparse, but there were years there were many per day. Never know when they will be on the upswing again. It's hard living in so much fear, she is the strong one though. I don't think people realize how hard epilepsy is to live with.
author: Shannon Williamson

label: negative
message: I've had seizures for 25yrs from being hit in the head, I have big ones and small ones.I am unable to work. I just want to thankyou for your story
author: Beverly Lenkowski

label: positive
message: My brother had Grand Mall Epilepsy. It wasn't pretty. My heart broke for him. Some of the experimental treatments he was put through by his doctor, I considered inhumane. As he grew older, it became less severe and was controlled by medicine. I was extremely defensive of my brother though he was older than I was. He endured monthly visits to Mercy Hospital for "treatments". It broke our poor mother's heart. She raised us by herself and had no support system except for me, and I was just a child.

label: negative
message: I was born with it every now and then I'll have a seizure hit me like a hurricane i can be sitting at home or at my program I'll notice a queezey feeling in my stomach and goose bumps but the medicine i take now keeps it under control

label: negative
message: I struggle with my Epilepsy. ..I am divorced....have had comps with relationships..have been a single Mom....2 yrs ago....I was contacted by a guy I went to school with since 6 th grade...He drove from OK to WA state.   Loaded me and my youngest up and brought us back to OKla.  I have continued to have Grand mal seizures 2 to 7 times a month with petites throughout. ..Have been denied any SSID. ..He has never left my side...takes care of me...private or public...  He is so strong...I don't know what I'd do without him.  He definitely loves me and my son.  Wish I would have talked to him when we were in school.  :)

label: negative
message: I didn't have problems falling asleep. My last job was working at a convenience store and people would call in saying they couldn't work their shift, so being a manager, I'd have to. Working an 8 hour shift on 2-3 hours of sleep would always trigger my seizures. My boss would come in and refused to let me go home as soon as he got to work. Fortunately I found a good doctor who wouldn't stand for it and put me on disability. I haven't worked in over 3 years and was deemed permanently disabled last year because my seizures were so bad.

label: negative
message: My doctor told me no caffeine and no lights at night except maybe a very little night light.  It doesn't help.  Still exhausted

label: positive
message: It doesn't matter how much I sleep I'm always exhausted.

label: negative
message: I'm always tired no matter how much sleep I get

label: neutral
message: I have these problems.  Im 25 and I have had epilesy since I was 2 years old.  I am now waiting to make an appt at a sleep study.
author: Casey Schweizer

label: negative
message: As a FORMER truck driver I could not always pick my sleep time. This method worked for me then and now.  Take a long deep breath, Let this first lung full of air out at a speed that is twice as long as it took to fill them. breath in deep again and repeat. Change the balance so the inhale is as long as the exhale and truly focus on the rhythm. what ever "crap" you have on your mind will give way to maintaining the equal rhythm, personally I can be asleep in about 5 min tired or not. Your body will seem to sleep what it needs if you are not interrupted by external intrusions. As I have 50yrs old in my sights the "midnight pee" thing gets me but falling back is just that simple
author: Michael Koster

label: neutral
message: I usually sleep after work and then stay up for a bit and then go back to sleep and I'm 21 and had it since I was 3

label: neutral
message: When I was on my meds I never had any problem sleeping since part of the medication was to calm me down. HOWEVER, when I came off of them THEN I started not being able to sleep properly.
author: Colin Ross

label: negative
message: Start at 3000 and count backwards by 3s... So boring you have to fall asleep! Stay well my friends!
author: Carla Harmon-Kimberlin

label: positive
message:
This is me...
I am also always low in sodium.  
Which causes seizure's. 
So many things that cause them...
author: Laurie Longmate

label: positive
message: drugs and alcohol are right up there with primary triggers, kinda obvious though.
author: Wister Haines

label: neutral
message: I'm sorry, but DUH. That is why I have now converted to Buddhism & meditating.
author: Jason Kara

label: neutral
message: Manuel Vargas so you understand a bit more
author: Shining On

label: neutral
message: Jon Jon Bell.  Greg Bell.
author: Cyndi Riddle

label: negative
message: I actually wrote a letter to the Fox network after an episode of House.  In one scene the actors were restraining a patient having a seizure.  People who have epilepsy and those around them know not to restrain a person having a seizure.  I thought it was unwise and ill informed and a tiny bit irresponsible for a medical show to show people doing the exact opposite of how a seizure should be handled.
author: Marlene Carey

label: neutral
message: No, since I have only seen grand mal seizures portrayed. All types should be portrayed accurately
author: Robin Blakeman

label: negative
message: It seems like everyone on tv who has seizures has grand mal seizures. It is just for the shock value. I don't really feel it's the best way to do it, though. The average person doesn't know what seizures are like except for what they see on tv. People never know I'm having seizures unless I tell them, or unless they are very familiar with my situation. Except for the obvious grand mal seizure which everyone recognizes. I've been mistaken as drunk, high, and retarded. Once in a HOSPITAL while visiting a friend I had a seizure (grand mal) in a bathroom, and woke up in the PSYCH WARD!!!! They probably found me when I was partly awake and confused. I don't recall it. It just irks me that in a hospital I was misdiagnosed so badly, and I could have needed medical help from a fall in the bathroom with the hard walls and floors.... Obviously, once evaluated they realized I was fine, mentally. Looking back I kind of feel like I should have done something. It was SO wrong!!!
author: Deloris Constance

label: neutral
message: WE NEED SOME1 WITH EPILEPSY TO RUN FOR PRESIDENT!!! SOME1 WHO WONT DISCRIMINATE - U LIVE IN THIS COUNTRY - THEN WE R ALL 4 1 AND 1     4 ALL!!!
author: R.C. Epilepsy Foundation - Team Shake & Bake

label: positive
message: No I do not think the Epilepsy is properly portrayed in pop culture I think a lot of people think its funny and have no idea how horrifying it is to watch somebody you love suddenly start convulsing on the floor
author: Orah Stanish

label: neutral
message: People have to prepare and learn about the epilepsy , how to help the person convulsing .
author: Olga Garcia

label: neutral
message: I will say thank-you cause I do have epilepsy.... Now I know there are support groups..thankyou
author: Nancila Yacino

label: positive
message: I remember seeing something about a blog relay.  I have a blog and would love to participate.  Where are the details about the blog relay?
author: Melinda Curle

label: negative
message: I agree, growing up my parents told me never to let anyone know because they would treat me different. We moved from CA to KY when I was 15 years old. My mother told the school that I had Epilepsy and on the first day of High school I was put in special education. I was actually a very good student and was removed from special ED, but that is the stigma that goes with epilepsy. I am very careful of who I tell about my condition.
author: Stacy Caludis

label: negative
message: I'm a nurse and got moved out of the department I wanted and loved after I had a seizure. They've even gone as far as asking if it's safe for me to work as a nurse. My neurologist has kept close tabs on me and doesn't see an issue as of yet. I'm really considering changing jobs and just not saying anything but then what if i have a seizure? Am I seeing myself up to be fired?
author: Michelle Taylor Lopez

label: neutral
message: It was extremely hard for me. Unfortunately I do not have a positive story about my epilepsy and workplace experience.
author: Sean Stotts

label: negative
message: Ppl seem to be okay with it at work. Then I had a seizure while working nights. They let me switch to strictly day shift so I can have a normal sleep schedule. But I know some of my co-workers talk about me for not having to work nights, even though everyone knows I have epilepsy. I'm just used to people talking about me behind my back saying it's a flimsy excuse.
author: Amber Brothag Flanigan

label: negative
message: I really must agree.  At my current employer, I let them know in a rather violent way.  I had a seizure.  If I had been a regular status employee, I would have told them long before so that they would not be caught unawares.   Luckily, I had good people around me including a fellow employee who is an EMT.  Other people aren't so lucky and some may have even died.
author: LauraAnn Johnston

label: negative
message: I have epilepsy since I was 8 yrs.old, and I always told my employers about my condition, they need to know for your safety and for the safety of others. And I always got hired....yes it's a stigma, but I keep my head held up high and never let my condition get me down....
author: Jean Greene

label: positive
message: I have had seizures from the time I was little and now im 38. I told employees and employers regarding my condition on case something went horribly wrong.
author: Sarah Mack

label: neutral
message: My daughter doctor diagnosed her with refractory seizures cause medicine don't help her....
author: Terrie Harp Amburn

label: negative
message: At this point I don't know whether to tell people or not anymore I was hired on my old job letting them full well know I had the condition got sicker and it was uncontrolled never seized at work but just got worse. Now nobody will hire me because I have been declared legally handicapped so either way I just don't bother
author: Dominique Nicole Jones Reidhead

label: negative
message:
My daughter who had epilepsy from birth and 2 unsuccessful brain surgeries took her life July 20, 2013. 
Epilepsy was a factor in her decision. She was 22.
author: Angie Berger Barnett

label: neutral
message: Prayers Peggy Beauchamp Nault
author: Sherryann Smith

label: negative
message: I wish they could mend a broken heart<ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B2><U+0094>. My son passed from a seizure less than 2 weeks ago.
author: Peggy Beauchamp Nault

label: positive
message: Thanks UCB and Epilepsy Advocate for amplifying this message!
author: Jessica Keenan Smith

label: neutral
message: It is my meds and the seizures that cause the short term memory loss.
author: Rachel Abernathy

label: neutral
message: Totally understand my son has a lot of memory loss
author: Casandra Ross

label: positive
message: I have the memory loss all the time especially a lot more lately but I'm not sure my kids understand
author: Norlene Smith

label: negative
message:
Yep!
Because of my seizures and medicine that was supposed to 'help'.
author: Katherine Evans Reed

label: negative
message: I have it all the time.... N sometimes I end up at the hospital for days
author: Mariana Andaló Rocha

label: negative
message: I recently forgot my phone number and had to think hard how to say the food i wanted to order when I'd gone too long without taking my medication. Then 2 hours later had a seizure. My memory had never been that bad before, normally i just can't remember things from years ago. That was scary.
author: Veronica Crowe

label: neutral
message: I never remember anything during a seizure
author: Jessica Miller

label: positive
message: This part of my condition sometimes can be a bit depressing. Needless to say it's educating others about it just in case you forget things in general.
author: Pamela Wilkes

label: negative
message: I forget my sisters phone number, people's names, what I was doing. Stuff like that.
author: Brittany Olafson

label: positive
message:
I forget darn near everything but have made a game out of it. I have notes and reminders evert where including inside the refrigerator: like: "Salmon, not chicken tonight" !
Or in my shop/studio " don't start this (with an arrow, until you've finished that."
And I just have to laugh. How else you gonna deal with it?? 
We've been dealt this hand.....
author: Kevin McNulty

label: neutral
message: But doesn't bother me any besides my kids always tells me what i did while laughing and i laugh to
author: Jessica Miller

label: negative
message: If my auras are acting up then I notice I have a hard time remembering some events from that day. I have temporal lobe epilepsy so when I get that déjà vu feeling I won't remember much in those moments. However overall I think my memory is decent. Hang in there everyone you are not alone <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B2><U+009C>
author: Selina Erwin

label: positive
message: For as long as I've had it and where it is the right temporal lobe my memory has been affected,along with seizures! Seems when I don't do something for awhile I can't remember it! So frustrating and embarasseing at times
author: Kathleen Quain

label: negative
message: The brain is a miraculous tool and there are many ways to get around some of our memory difficulties.  As for my biggest difficulty it is my spatial recognition and memory.  Simply put this is remembering where objects are in relation to other objects like remembering land marks, remembering what I see visually.  Fortunately my auditory memory is fairly good so if I talk myself through situations and describe things and situations to myself I am able to compensate for my lack of visual/spatial memory.  The most powerful tool you have as being a person with epilepsy is too learn as much as you can to give you the tools to fight back!
author: Darcy Healey

label: positive
message: I have memory loss I've been having seizure's for 14yrs now & my memory seems to be getting worse than better. I use to love to read & write poems, & be good at writing & spelling I can't even remember at times how to spell a word or what I'm reading! I'm constantly tired the only support I have is my husband & sometime my son & my daughter, its hard on me so I take it day by day! I know what you all go through its hard not remember things just trying stressing & having seizures!!  My thoughts and prayers go out to you all god bless you all!!
author: Tracy Austin Arredondo

label: negative
message: I got diagnosed with epilepsy back in 2008 ever since then I hardly remember anything before that, the last seizures I had were around 17 in a hour, I always have to get reminded by family and friends but they all understand, my memory well get better has time goes, I jus think god for the life, friends an family I have <U+263A>
author: Junior Creekmore

label: negative
message: Michelle Jeanne, I would never say that either! My parents always taught me not to use my epilepsy as an excuse. I have to get to know a person before I even tell them I have epilepsy because of some of the comments I've gotten in the past. I've lived with epilepsy for over 40 years and have worked overseas in the Pacific and Europe. I just don't allow epilepsy to run my life.
author: Claudette Harris

label: negative
message: My Son deal with epilepsy a lot I wish their was a cure but i know right now he lkeep having .Maybe one day.I  hope
author: Cathy Hooper

label: positive
message: I had two bad seizures the day before yesterday and one last night and I lost my memory really bad from them I even put my bra on backwards
author: Sarah Nelson

label: negative
message: My daughter has seizure disorder, and it has been difficult realizing that she does not remember what a cup is or what the word counter means.  We practiced for so many years with her being autistic, to just repeat those words, and now I ask for a cup and she walks to the kitchen but is lost on what she is there for. I just wish she could speak to tell me what's going on, but I forget that she has memory lapse and I end up getting it myself when I could be using it as a teaching tool. So frustrating, can't imagine being her.
author: Charma L'Heureux

label: positive
message: Yes. I had a great memory too. Others won't understand, even if they know you have epilepsy. I also don't want to announce it to the world that I have it when I'm forgetting something. So really I just look like an idiot! I'm looking for brain exercises and ways to improve my memory.
author: Emily Barrett

label: positive
message: I have had  memory loss since I have had tonic-clonic seizures to Absence seizures . Now I am having auras not knowing  where I am or what l am doing scared me at times. I feel  the spirit  is helping  me out day by day, i pray that God will bless us all.
author: Adrianne Bostick

label: negative
message: I definitely have short term memory loss after the surgery on the left front lobe.  I did have a Dr. that performed a test and said I would be on disability for life because the memory loss would be so bad for life.  I use to mention memory loss to people about the surgery, what they always mentioned back is they had the same problem because they were getting older.  Nobody quite understands how bad it is for people with epilepsy.  I still can not believe myself after the surgery.  I can remember easily things from before and not things after.
author: Bill Porter

label: neutral
message: I've had epilepsy for 57 yrs so for as long as I can remember I've had trouble with my memory...lol!!!  My family and friends understand and for the rest of them I can now tell them old age.
author: Joyce Hede Krebbs

label: positive
message: I worked in real estate for four years before my seizures. Now I can't remember hardly anything! A few weeks ago my husband came home to me crying, I was try to fill out paperwork. I couldn't remember how to spell my last name. It's so frustrating some times!!
author: Susie Rodriguez

label: negative
message: I had grand mal and petit mal seizures when I was younger my medication stopped working when I was 20 and I had brain surgery when I was 21 I had a scar on my left temporal lobe they don't know if it was there when I was born or if it was from my first seizure when I was 15 months old that was over a half hour long. They removed the scar I have not had a seizure since I'm still on medication I'm 41 now I do have a bad short term memory
author: Katie Porath

label: negative
message: I had epilepsy seen i was born it is sad but i make it if people  do not understanding  that i feel sad for them . I make it day by day .
author: Suzzanne Peacock

label: negative
message: I've had epilepsy since the late 90's and find my short term and long term has gotten worse. I've never used it as an excuse and have not openly discussed the concern. It is an incredible comfort to know I'm not alone. I'm also looking for ways to help maintain or stop continued memory loss. <ed><U+00A0><U+00BC><ed><U+00BC><U+009E>
author: Terri Applegate

label: negative
message: hi all i have grand maul and it takes me a couple of days to get back were i was but i don't rember nothing.but hang in there your loved ones will help you through this.
author: Kevin Rook

label: positive
message: Yes I do forget things once in awhile because of it but I refuse to blame that on EVERYTHING!!!  OMG...I would NEVER SAY what it does for the social gathering!!!  I MEAN WHAT THE HELL?!?
author: Michelle Jeanne Lonergan

label: neutral
message: I MAY HAVE SEIZURE BUT IM NOT STUPID!
author: Christina Kaneaster

label: negative
message: I forget words, names, memories, etc. have a hard time talking sometimes. Part of this thing we have but I deal with it and move on. I use to get all worked up about it but things could be worse right?
author: Layla Marie Coady

label: negative
message: i am learning not to apologies and state clearly when i meet new people i inform them that it is likely that i will forget their name as i have brain damage and memory problems, like most people on this page i only tell them that i am epileptic when i have known them for a while
author: Chenice Nice

label: negative
message: Being at the lab exams to a driver is going on 56 now I had a hard life but a good one so I do when I can and I'm still happy
author: Bill Kane

label: negative
message: I wish any of those worked ... after having seizures all throughout high school and if I wrote that on a test  or told a teacher that they woulda told me to go piss off

label: positive
message: Yeah... like the last time I had a seizure. I don't remember being in the er at all. I remember seeing a paramedic and then I was admitted

label: negative
message: I've tried these its thrown in in my face like I'm a liar
author: Lottie E Carden

label: positive
message: I can remember what happened 50 years ago but yesterday forget it. I have right temporal lobe seizures. Had them since I was 8.
author: Pat Trombley Lewis

label: neutral
message: Those are two-liners. A bigger thing, anyway, is NOT APOLOGIZING for your epilepsy. It isn't something to be ashamed of.  I'm epileptic and will never apologize for anything involving my seizures. If anything, non-epileptics should apologize to us. I've met so many epileptics who are actually ashamed to the point where they hide it from everyone. That's messed up. If I can't remember a fact, or someone's name, I may certainly will not apologize. Just, "I have epilepsy and that's what seizures do. They damage your brain." usually that prompts a conversation about epilepsy wherein I correct all the stupid things non-epileptics think about epilepsy and seizures. Just stop apologizing and be matter-of -fact.
author: Onyx Song Jat Sharif

label: negative
message: And it seriously sucks my memory is bad enough then the stroke then the seizures maybe one day ill get my life back.. the memory lose is killing me! Cant remember what happened last week let alone what happened two days ago, and I've been seizure free for five months..

label: neutral
message: Boy does it suck!  I used to have the best memory ever too!

label: neutral
message: Is there some kind of national database where we can search for these doctors?

label: negative
message: Hell no ! My HMO only refers within and the only epileptologist in this city is pediatric  !!! 42 + yrs of epilepsy and have only been seen by neurologists .
author: Debi Pictum-Lotta

label: negative
message: I was referred to my epileptologist after my neuro said I was a confusing case and he didn't know what to do with me. My seizures were controlled but the side effects or allergic reactions were horrible. One med change and one year to get all other meds out of my system and I'm finally back to some semblance of a normal life.
author: Kami Wegner

label: positive
message: I was referred to an epileptologist a couple years ago and it made a huge difference! I was able to find out where my seizures were coming from and have a better knowledge of medications. Unfortunately, I have intractable epilepsy, so I am going to have VNS which my Epileptologist will be in charge of.
author: Audrey Salas

label: negative
message: I had an epileptologist and he was great. It made all the difference in my care. I had a brain tumor,have had seizures since the age of 7 and terrible migraines. Now I have a Neurologist it just not the same. Still on very high doses of meds. Now it starting to affect my kidneys.
author: Tammy Niffen

label: positive
message: I've been blessed with two WONDERFUL epileptologists over the past 20 plus years.  Neurologists are good, but their knowledge is much more general, whereas the expertise/focus on epilepsy that an epileptologist has, can make a H U G E difference in the quality of care one receives as far a treatment for epilepsy.  If AT ALL possible, get a referral to an epileptologist, even if getting there is a little inconvenient.
author: Tim Tilt

label: negative
message: When you find someone that specializes in the issue you cannot control, what a difference. My husband was told by his neurologist that he is medication resistant and there was nothing else he could do. Horrible to hear for someone who has cluster seizures several times month, his epileptoligist has given us options and hope
author: Jillian Isbell

label: positive
message: My neurologist could not effectively treat my epilepsy, and he had the great honesty & humility to advise me to go to an epileptologist. I am eternally grateful to my neuro for that. My epileptologist tried different med combos before moving onto neurosurgery, for LTL re-section. I love my epileptologist!
author: Heather Moe

label: negative
message: Our epileptologist was able to achieve seizure control on our 9 year old when our neurologist could not.
author: Stacey Hargrove

label: neutral
message: My epileptologist understands the disorder so much better than any neurologist I have ever met! There is a HUGE difference, and recommend that all Epileptics go to one for better care.
author: Andrea Talamantez

label: negative
message: My son was treated unsuccessfully by a neurologist for many years.  We were told his episodes were psychosomatic.  Once getting to an amazing epileptologist, we were told the EEG which is normal for him is so abnormal for most others that it takes a special talent to decipher his seizures from the other brain waves.  It's been a bit over 20 years that she's worked with him - epilepsy surgery at Mayo and VNS implanted, he's still not totally controlled, but he's light years ahead of where he was.   I *highly* recommend this sub speciality to anyone not finding success through the regular channels.
author: Audrey Stokes

label: positive
message: My original neurologist didn't recommend one to me but when I got fed up with the care I was receiving and decided to change even though I was only looking for a neurologist I ended up finding an amazing epiletologist
author: Tiffany Ann Roberts

label: negative
message: I think that after over 35 yrs of neurologists with no real seizure control, it's time to refer myself to a epileptologist.
author: Roxanne Ishmael

label: positive
message: Such better care from the epileptologist! No ego problem either! Will NEVER go back to a neurologist ever again!
author: Nancy Clark

label: neutral
message: They are wonderful in their field and very hard to find! Mine retired a few years ago and I'm struggling to trust a Neurologist for answers.
author: Amy Vanderhorst Dziedzic

label: negative
message: If you or a loved one has epilepsy that is not controlled by a pill or two, or if the side effects of your medication is outweighing the good, you must see an epileptologist.
author: Linda Phare Harding

label: negative
message: My daughter has always gone to the Cleveland Clinic. I didn't know it was so unknown. She's always had one and I know there are some at UH too in Cleveland. I guess we're lucky to live so close to world class care. Explains why there's always patients from all over the world there when we stay in the pediatric monitoring unit for a video EEG.
author: Jenny Wilson Keesee

label: neutral
message: Is an epilepsy. Specialist. In epileptic seizures.
author: Myrna Dejesus

label: neutral
message: Made ALL the difference with my daughter.  They were more focused on what types of seizures,  possible triggers, better knowledge of meds and side effects and even concerned with how meds effect future life events, marriage and family.  Better testing, better results and better communication.  Highly recommend it!  Good luck and prayers for all who deal with epilepsy.  My heart goes out to you.  Smiles
author: Sean A'lee Bevell

label: negative
message: It took an Epileptologist to be able to read my daughters difficult EEG, to say it's Lennox Gastaut Syndrome and not behavior or multiple other diagnosis we'd been given. He is our Angel, he gave my daughter back her life
author: CynDee Cornell

label: negative
message: My first visit with elipetologist he knew everything about me had studied my file and already had a plan I still have a few a week but a lot less than before and I have had seizures for 21 years
author: Mandy Boyer

label: negative
message: I see one at the Cleveland Clinic they have a few
author: Thomas Gene Parady Jr

label: positive
message: My son, who is now 13, was referred to a pediatric epileptologist when he was 8 years old.  He spent 7 days in the PICU with uncontrollable seizures.  We continue to meet with her at least 4 times a year.  Although we live in Orange County and her office is in LA County, we couldn't imagine changing doctors.  She's amazing and I credit she and her specialized expertise and knowledge in saving my son's life.
author: Tracey McMillan Mulvaine

label: negative
message: They are far more knowledgeable and have far less time for you. At least that's how it is in my area. I can never get an appt with him and when I do it is short, but I am doing better since starting to see him.

label: neutral

label: negative
message: I woul like to see Occupational Therapists added to this list   With their help,  some may be able to achieve a highee level of independence  and quality of life.

label: negative
message: I would like to speak to a social worker about my condition because how can i do it
author: Myrna Dejesus

label: negative
message: The only thing I desire is to get out of the hands of the GREEDY, who try to profit off of a medical condition, thet after 50 some yrs of it have gotten me nowhere. Stop using us as your guinea pigs for your ideas of making money, I gave in to the surgery, without success, which should be logical that half my brain is damaged from falls and injuries and emotional traumas I have experienced. Before the surgery they did some of their new tests to see my brain, without operating and the picture they showed me, showed the center left of my brain like a warped plant, whiich was from 107 fever at age 8 and the left right took over that left area's jobs, but the Epilepsy truthfully started from a mental trauma of child molestation at age 10, because I could not relax and fall asleep due to the fear of it happening again. and the one I was protecting thinks I lured him, because it was her dad.
author: Maj-Britt Aust

label: neutral
message: MY list would have consisted of just Family, Friends, Family Doctor and Neurologist and that was it.

author: Mark Allison

label: negative
message: These comments are AWESOME!!! SO, I HAVE to share a mini version of my Eplipsey Saga... I had my first grandma in the shower, while my mom was at work in... A HOSPITAL... the medics wrapped my burned body in a bath towel!!! So, I had to be put in a tub of ice.. Then, grafting surgery.. I was 27!!! Spent the next ten years being called a Retard, freak... Losing job after job.. And.. My Dr's. Spending less than 15mns with me, every six months.. Blaming my onset on my Female hormones... And, doping me up on meds... A client for years, helped get me in for tests at the MAYO... One hour there and meeting my doctor.. He told me I had a brain tumor, non-cancerous and BRAIN SURGERY was the answer... WOW!!! 9 Nerologists, 7 MRI's, and 32 medications... And.. I was probably born with this!!! The MAYO was blown away... I had surgery ten years ago this past week.. And, have only had two seizures in the past ten years... BUT, that label has stuck with me.. Because Now, I have side effects of the chuck of my brain they removed... I was very fortunate... I do my best to go on.. Pay the gift my customer gave me forward... And... Would like to tell the world my story, because of the label, Sigma, etc.. That continues... I was lucky to have met Coach Jerry Kill a year ago (MN golfers coach with Epilepsy) told him he was my Hero... I pray that social media can help prove that those with Seizures & Eplipsey are VERY capable of living life.. Coach Kill is a shinning example (college educated, great coach) and he is working with my local Epilepsy foundation to help pass along this label is unfounded... <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+0082> I was blessed at my Worst... And, I just want to tell the world that to help others that face the challenges of daily life... With this.. Not to be so quick to judge!! Bless you ALL!!! <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B2><U+009F><ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B2><U+009F><ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B2><U+009F>

label: negative
message: I have a family member & a friend - one with Parkinson's - one with Epilepsy! Both have  MCI (mild cognitive impairment) - memory loss is a major issue - dementia (one with PD) mild forms) ... my concern is the person with epilepsy should get the same 'dementia' !  Epliepsy Advocate - please explain who these two illnesses / diseases 'corellate' to the same types of symptoms. As well as depression too.  can I send an email to someone to go more into detail? I do all that I can to be 'caregiver' & friend to both! I believe in always trying hard & not giving up! thanks!

label: negative
message: ...and PLEASE don't try to guess what we're trying to say, or attempt to finish our sentence for us, or get annoyed and walk away.  That only makes it worse, and makes those of us experiencing the problem, less likely to communicate with you.  If it happens to involve something you've told us before, or we told you, but we've forgotten, please be patient with us, and don't get angry.  I can assure you, our "forgetting",  bothers us a WHOLE LOT MORE than it does you.  Thank you for being patient.

label: negative
message:
As far as I'm concerned, the only person who has to know why you have memory loss is yourself. If you want to tell the person to whom you're speaking, then fine - but I don't think that it should be part of a standard answer.

My one-liner is "Epilepsy doesn't have me, I have epilepsy". Saying "my epilepsy causes me to ..." throws that right out the window.

I don't have a issue with remembering how to do my work (HVAC) but the things that matter most I can't recall such as life events family important information and it hurts people I know. message:
I get all. So they aren't sure if I have secondary generalized with multiple focal points throughout my brain or primary generalized. Either way it always ends up with a grand mal. VNS has stopped any absence or grand mals. I still get, on days I miss meds or whatever, the stuff above.
One day I came to my epileptology nurse to check my VNS and I was a nervous wreck and felt like I was going to have a nervous breakdown and was intermittently crying. She almost sent me for an EEG. She said she could tell something wasn't right when she came out to get me.

author: Charlotte Bradford

label: negative
message: It definitely affects daily life. I think mainly because of the side affects of the medications.  I was blessed I've been married for 23 years. Ive had epilepsy since the age of three months. I'm 45 now. My husband helps me through the seizures and is understanding of the state I'm in after a seizure. Hes been with me through both brain surgeries that I've had for my epilepsy.  11/25/1996 I had a partial right temporal lobectomy. In 2/18/2005 they removed the remainder of my temporal lobe and my hippocampus.  At the age of 35, after my second surgery my hair grew back in totally gray. It had been very dark brown. I didn't know if I should scream or cry!! We got this bright idea to try and have Jeff color my hair. He's been doing it every 6 weeks or so since. It would be to expensive to have it done at a salon. He treats me like a queen.
author: Lisa Ann Herzberg

label: negative
message: I've had a hard time finding the right guy because they r afraid of my epilepsy and because I have a child I've been a single mom all my daughter's life
author: Michelle Thompson

label: negative
message: People are so are just unaware of Epilepsy that they don't want to deal with it or the responsibilities. I have gran mal seizures & mild cebrel palsy & I am a smart intelligent woman and it's very hard for me to met someone. It just sucks all these intelligent people out there and the truth is no one wants to deal with it. Only a few. I had relationship where I ended up being the strong one and every time I did not feel well he couldn't deal and told me to go home.
author: Anita DiGiallonardo

label: negative
message:
Several years ago, when my husband and I were young and best friends, he was dating a young single mom whom he thought he had strong feelings for, and thought those feelings were returned. After several months of dating, they agreed he should move into her place. Everything seemed fine. She knew he had occasional seizures, but had never seen one. Two days after he moved in, he had a grand mal on her floor. She shut her infant child in their room, and scared, continued to let him lay there bleeding, unsure of what to do. She eventually got ready, dropped her child at daycare, headed to work. She told me about the seizure, how she had never seen anything like it and said, "I dont think I can handle this." 
"Do you love him?" 
"Yeah . . . " 
"Then anything is possible."
She went home and he was sleeping, packed up the few things he brought with him, and put them in her trunk. When he woke up, she drove him back to his parents house and broke up with him. He was so sad and heartbroken. She didn't even want to try to help or learn, just gave up on him when the first real relationship obstacle appeared.
author: Dabre Newcomb

label: neutral
message: My husband knew i had them,but still ask me to marry him, yes 33 years and still kicking with them, yes that is a man that can deal with us with these seizures, over 25 or more years.

label: negative
message: I have taken medications close to 60 years now.  I have a wonderful husband, family and friends and live as normal life as I can.   PTL!!!
author: Sherelyn McLaury

author: Benjamin Gage

label: negative
message: Remind yourself.  There are over a million medical problems. Epilepsy is just one. The majority of people you meet and know may develop a medical problem.  It may be far worse then epilepsy or quite minor.  This is life.  We All have our ups and downs.  Do not let others let you feel down.  Remind yourself- they may just be a bit naive.  Common of many people, until they experience a medical problem or a close relative does.  Try your hardest to remind yourself of all the good things you can do and enjoy. Everyone is special in one way or another.  You are too!!!

label: negative
message: Until I was so lucky after 2 major things; going from extremely severe ( over 20-30 grand mals and 300 partials a week) to severe where I finally met a woman who could handle that and accepts me as I dearly love and help her as much as I can. Married now for almost 6 years. I was so lucky when first going out my family drove and she understood.
author: Ian Anttila

label: negative
message: My sweetheart came with Epilepsy!  I love him. His seizures while scary are manageable (grand mal). I clear the area of danger, count the minutes, call paramedics after 5 minutes, and follow to hospital,  if necessary. I take him home, tuck him in bed, and wait for him to come back. They are a once in a blue moon and sometimes have humorous effects. One time he spoke in numbers for an hour. Another time he forgot my name and called me Darlin' for 3 months.

label: negative

author: Evangelina Garcia

label: negative
message: Your doctor has to be your friend or get another one.
author: Robert A. Fiore

label: negative
message: Be sure your Dr. has YOUR best interest at heart, and not just his/her's (basically, all they want to do is CYA). Had same neurologist for 20 years (not by choice, parents picked him out when I was still child). Kept him until my 30's, when his 'expertise' almost killed me with Steven Johnson's syndrome, told me I should never have children b/c if I ever get divorced no one would give me custody of my child (WTF?!), and told me he couldn't cure me, just help 'control' seizures (which his answer was to overmedicate me). Do NOT be afraid to question their actions or suggestions, based on your needs and lifestyle. And when they decide it's ok for you to wait 2 hours AFTER your scheduled appt (that you had to leave work for b/c unlike a neurologist, you aren't a millionaire) that you had to catch a ride too as well b/c you can't drive, then its time to say you and your time are worth more to someone who cares..... 4 years, seizure free all b/c of a NEW dr. that found out more about me in 2 week hospital stay than previous dr. did in 20 years.
author: Stefanie Herdman

label: negative
message: Your Doctor should be your friend is right.  I had one.  She went to another state.  She was good.  I felt that I could tell her anything, like Family.  I was so very comfortable with her.  It really is important to have that good doctor friend patient relationship.
author: Chris Bridges

label: positive
message: I LOVE my gastro doctor! (My Nuerologist, not so much) He goes above and beyond his job. Always taking time to listen.no matter how busy he is!
author: Vickie Black

label: negative
message: I'm straight forward with my PCP & Nuerologist. They have been professional & bluntly honest with me, since my 1st seizure in 1999. Though i moved upstate NY, i always go to NYC, to see them & I'll keep them, as long as I can.
author: Nicholas Humphrey

label: negative
message: Tried explaining my experience, and not getting the help that I need. For some reason, it greyed me out...
author: Jacob Clayton

label: negative
message: I avoided telling anyone about what they call auras and partial seizures until I was 20 something. For fear they'd think I was crazy. I'm not crazy, just a seizure disorder.
author: Sean Stotts

label: negative
message:
I'm so excited and proud of all of my fellow epilepsy survivors for telling your stories. I was diagnosed at age eleven. I'll turn 57 this year and still have seizures. 
We need to speak up more. Myself included.
author: Laurie Boyd

label: negative
message: Sounds similar to how my son described it. My son was diagnosed with complex partial seizures at 3 and he's 12 now. When he was younger, he said right before he had a seizure it felt like his brain was dizzy. Afterwards, he'd be very tired and would sleep for hours.
author: Lakisha McDonald

label: negative
message: I have complex partial and it feels like a sudden uncontrollable electrical rush from my feet to my head.  Then you feel like crap afterwards, headache, sleepiness or both.
author: Linda Fuentes

label: negative
message: Partial onset are strange kinda like the Déjà vu seizures Grand Mal seizures are the ones I have the most but now since I have had 2 mini strokes I have been diagnosed with cluster seizures I can have different ones I didn't start having seizures til 34 I was misdiagnosed for several years before they found out what was going on
author: Regina Yount Stewart

label: negative
message: Thanks for sharing. My granddaughter has had seizures since the age of 5 and is sixteen now. She has gone through three brain surgeries and never been able to describe. You put in perspective.
author: Cheryl Lambert

label: negative
message: I have simple partial cranial seizures triggered by stress or perceived threats that effect my frontal lobe, the emotion center. I get an immeasurable rush of a particular emotion (whether rational/appropriate or not) and I get lost in wat I describe as a whirlwind of incomplete and irrational thoughts. I'm very dysphoric afterwards
author: Whitney Hatton

label: positive
message: I hear all of you. I started in my 20s i was working and now iam in the house i was having 50 or more a day for years but now once or twice a month my is called TLE.  I have the VNS. IT works good at times
author: Marie Henry

label: neutral
message: Had these for 34 years. Had an operation in1993. NO seizures or medication  since.
author: Mary Jenkins

label: negative
message: I have an aura and know it's coming. Mine I can feel the pain until I black out. For those who don't have them I explain mine as if it is a Charlie horse all over your body....it sucks.
author: Jessica Unger Tilse

label: positive
message: Yes I agree with all of you and it's great knowing that we Are not going crazy..
author: Paulina M Benson

label: positive
message: I am so glad you put this up, I always had a lot of questions and no answers
author: Sandy Maoz

label: positive
message: Omg!! That is what my son says happens he's 8.  He also has Generalized seizures.
author: Kristen Clayton

label: negative
message: They get worse as we get older. I seem to get them more often than before even with the medications.
author: Evangelina Garcia

label: negative
message: People with epilepsy will understand this. There's no way for me explain exactly how my seizure feels, but we must talk to our epileptologist to get the treatment that we need. Our doctors understand some of the things that we can't explain and they will ask questions when they don't.
author: Mark Allison

label: negative
message: And you feel like crap afterward.
author: Jamie Kimsey

label: positive
message: Thank you to all who share in this group.  I gain much strength and knowledge from you.
author: Amy Avedian D'Amico

label: negative
message: Where and how do you apply for this? I have a daughter that is graduating high school and could benefit from this.
author: Rita Harvey

label: neutral
message: I never knew about this scholarship programs for epilepsy.
author: Deaconess SanJuanita Cardenas

label: neutral
message: I always wanted to go to college.
author: Deaconess SanJuanita Cardenas

label: positive
message: Make sure you get a doc that works with you.
author: Krishna Diemert

label: negative
message: I'm still working on that. My present dr is such a control freak he got up in the middle of me trying to talk to him & said this appt is over. I had been waiting on him for almost 2 hrs. A true communication problem
author: Amy Chenault

label: neutral
message: I was misdiagnosed for 14 years, three docs and 1 epileptologist
author: Ariel Banister

label: negative
message: I loved my neurologist then he moved to Virginia! The new doctor at the practice is OK. There are not too many options in Philadelphia without driving to HUP!
author: Nicole Formica-Kieffer

label: negative
message:
I have found with almost all doctors they are so used to being in a rhythm one has to actually say "Slow down. I don't feel as if you are hearing me."
Every time I have said that, there has not been one doctor, epileptologist or not, who hasn't had their "reset" button pushed.
author: John Riley

label: negative
message: It took them six years for me then I moved and started all over again.
author: Patricia Kirchner

label: positive
message: I live Alone.  Is there a support group in lake Charles Louisiana area.
author: Thelma Caine

label: positive
message: Make sure that you put your education to good use, okay. I have a lot of education, but when I was young I couldn't keep a job because of my epilepsy.
author: Derrick Daniel

label: neutral
message: Been married 40 years and my husband is excellent with my epilepsy. He knew I had it when he married me and it didn't bother him then
author: Pat Trombley Lewis

label: neutral
message: Been married for 15years, my husband knew I had epilepsy. It can be hard on him and my daughter but we've managed. He's GREAT!! Always there for me, I'm very lucky!!
author: Miriam Franco

label: negative
message: It's very hard on my husband, but he does really good.
author: Brendi Archuleta

label: neutral
message: Look ahead, look forward!

label: positive
message: Thank you maybe some day what your doing will help my daughter,meanwhile thanks for helping all you can. God bless all who are helping& the one's  living with epilepsy!!!!!
