label: positive
message: Hope, faith, education = strength
author: Jerri Carr

label: positive
message: I hope to find out what type of seizures my son and I suffer from  we have the same thing and the doctor said they never seen anything like it so we need this the schools in colorado are the worst and they make you feel like a bad mom and it sucks the hell they are putting us throw
author: Ellen Fern

label: positive
message: My parents, keep encouraging me to keep trying for anything I want to do..
author: Anne Baker

label: negative
message: Accepting problems in life, and finding answers or ways to deal a problem is just a normal part of everyone's life. Accepting epilepsy as a problem is the beginning of the answer. LaKeisha's answer makes her the friend of many people and I'm sure they would like to tell her, "Thank you."
author: Mark Allison

label: negative
message: Thanks Chris I was diagnosed. A few years later I got meningitis which let brain scarring. My first return to the hospital was very scary but therapeutic. I do miss working and ability to drive.  But with challenges come celebrations.
author: Juanita Brewer

label: negative
message: I now have Essential Tremors plus the Complex Partial Seizures.  I had to give up working and driving due to both of my situations. I pray that it would go away for everyone.
author: Linda Fuentes

label: negative
message: I personally would like something like this in the state of Missouri. We seem to be forgotten!

label: negative
message: Being able to ask for assistance is key, to be able to survive with a disability

label: negative
message: We missed the walk but got there the next day for the Public Policy Institute and Teens Speak Up.  The cherry blossoms were beautiful!  =)
author: Jennifer Abramson

label: negative
message: My husband, daughter and I were there for the walk last weekend.  My daughter was diagnosed with Epilepsy in 2003.  The three of us took the trip to DC.  WE HAD AN AWESOME TIME!!!  Will definitely come again!!!
author: AmyJean Kazmierski

label: negative
message: I have epilepsy and it warms my heart to see this!
author: Vickie Black

label: positive
message: So there are people that still has hope THANK YOU::)
author: Marie Henry

label: neutral
message: My daughter has been seizure free for two yrs , but it took 25 yrs. to find the right medicine cocktail for her to be free. She has a lot of memory loss not being able to understand simple things.
author: Leanne Swanson Lutes

label: neutral
message: I have the same problem but three more semesters and I have my Masters degree in justice studies!
author: Victoria Czaia

label: negative
message: Good for her! When I was diagnosed I was having lots of memory trouble, and after I had a grand mal the entire previous year or two was erased it seemed.  I'm still working to recall dates with my boyfriend, times I nannied and watched the kids grow up, and schooling I learned.  People don't think about that aspect of epilepsy; you don't just move on.  I'm finally doing better after being on medicine for a year, and each time a memory is triggered I almost want to cry because I'm so happy and relieved that something is still there!
author: Megan Jolley

label: negative
message: I still lack childhood memories and struggle with long test. I am happy to say I graduated with my Masters in 2011 :) every graduation really felt like an even more accomplishment to overcome those issues
author: Ashley Taylor Lenzi

label: negative
message: Oh my Oh my.  Wow!  You all support this man still cursed with bad thoughts that I am broken.  When my marriage imploded(yet it was a very tight structured enmeshed in-laws), they starting calling me crazy and the unsafe and well unable.. Then to have my teens be told things.  Well let me simply say this man that worked Wall Street, had a business, and been working an ER/ICU and finishing my MPA.  Um zero police record period.  Girl your testimony right when I checked here after being amongst people who accept me as God allowed it.  Awesome.
author: Jon Kelley

label: positive
message: Accepting having Epilepsy & not being able to live same way.
author: Nicholas Humphrey

label: positive
message: Live My Life One minute at a time!! And I Thank God for each Day that I'm Given and I live it to the Fullest!!

label: negative
message: I live my life like i do every day

label: positive
message: Keep your faith, take the medication, and be strong

label: positive
message: We must make sure we find things to succeed at i am a great servant to God my wife my children and a sport to master.

message:
I've had Epilepsy since I was 12 & I'm 37 now,I don't qualify for surgery however I've learned over the years to accept my seizures as a part of me & someday soon I hope those around me will do the same.
To others who have Epilepsy,"each day gets easier & you do get stronger;don't let it define who you are.Were all exceptional people,believe in yourself & the rest will fall into place" :)

 WILL ALWAYS BE HERE

message: I've had since I was 4 (1951) and under control since 1984. Long delay since I wasn't officially diagnosed until 1979. I was always alone when I seized until I went to the doctor and I seized during the examination.

My son has epilepsy 
So I understand your plight.

Making Epilepsy Look Good!

label: negative
message: I was diagnosed in 2011 at the age of 26. I became very depressed and gained a lot of weight. I decided to take by my life back and to prove I wasn't going to let this disease hold me down. A year ago I competed in my first fitness competition and killed it. I started off my training at 195 lbs and 15% body fat in 10 weeks I completed at 158 lbs and 6% body fat. The whole time i kept telling myself that , "Epilepsy  won't stop me." Those are the four words I live by.

label: negative
message: I have had it since I was 8 and I am still struggling to get it under control at 28

label: negative

label: negative
message: No many people undertand about epilepsy and seizures disorders.  My son Robert has 17 years old, mentally 2 or 3 years old. Due to his medical condition,  he needs constant  monitoring for safety precautions so that his life will  not be at  risk.   We have been at Miami Childrens Hospital Room 353 for many days,  because he continues to have uncontrolled seizures. Please continue with a lot of "prayers" for my son's medical condition . Thanks to  all of the people that have taken the time to stop over an visit  him at the hospital, phone calls,  and prayers.

label: negative
message: This is great!  I had brain surgery.. Got Fired for it, from a job that hired me with Eplipsey... AND.. No one could do a darn thing to keep this big Corp. From doing this to me!!!

Also people tell me "I hope your Epilepsy kills you" I get a lot of shit.

author: Robin Rogers

label: positive
message: My son received this scholarship last year. It wad a huge help. Thank you UCB!
author: Laurel Cook

label: negative
message: It was bad when I was younger. I would have daily grand mal seizures. Sometime as many as 8 in one day. Now I only have partial-complex seizures and only about 10-15 a month. I've had 4 jobs and have been laid off 3 times because of just 1 seizure. Now I'm just trying to start my own epilepsy awareness company with my best friend who also has seizures. When I have a seizure, I'm confused and can't remember words or how to talk. I've had right temporal lobectomy surgery when I was 13 and I'm now on my 3rd V.N.S. When I had brain surgery, when I woke up from it, I didn't know anything, anyone, who I was, I didn't know a word of english, I didn't even know how to move my arms and legs. Luckily over the years much has come back to my memory but not all of it. I have forgot many things like I did in my past. Especially the good things. I went through high school only knowing the words yes and no. While having on average 3-5 grand mals a week. I would wake up with pee and sometimes poop all over me in the middle of the hallways. Everyone would be laughing and pointing fingers at me. Now its funny too me but back then it was 24 hour stress. Panic attacks and much more.
author: Mike Anderson

label: negative
message: Mine is horrible!!  Sometimes my words run into each other , I can't recall certain past events with family and that makes me feel like I wasn't even there!!
author: Awilda Coll

label: negative
message: Pay right temporal lobectomy I couldn't remember what happened,  was said, what I saw 2 minutes ago.   Tomorrow will be 7 years since the surgery and I have learned that though my memory doesn't always work I can work with my memory.  Routine is important,  the more practice in routine you are the less things you have to consciously remember daily.  Then,  find the tools that work for you, whether written or electronic, and use them regularly.  Lastly, ask for help from others as you learn to compensate for what was lost.
author: Kelly Porter

label: neutral
message: I understand because my memory has been so affected I felt I had the start of alzheimers,,my Dr gave me a test to prove to me I wasn't
author: Jeanette Horton

label: negative
message: My daughter, age 13 has epilepsy. We have to try our best to keep her routine the same everyday because the littlest change could cause emotional breakdowns. Her school has been wonderful about notifying me of upcoming tests and projects because she will forget the dates and will think it's the next day instead of a few days away. We try and be supportive of her at all times because we love her and want her to be happy. I wish all of you happiness, love, and the support you deserve.
author: Sitler-Currey Karen

label: negative
message: I struggle daily with short term memory loss.  The only way I get thru it at work is to constantly keep a notebook of what I do thru out the day. It helps so much. Now if I can get in that same routine at home. :-)  but I do have the post it's hanging, and notes written here and there. And always putting things in their special so I know where there are when I need them. If I don't keep a routine, or if it's not routine, I will not remember. It stinks having memory issues.
author: Vanessa Holmberg

label: positive
message: I thought mine had to do with my epilepsy seeing this makes feel better!! I hate talking to people and not even being able to remember a simple word like lotion. I'll say what's that stuff you rub on your hands it makes me feel so stupid. I can't remember a lot of childhood memories I thought it was me. I'm so glad I saw this!! I was telling everyone to wear purple the other day!!
author: Michelle Marshall Frioli

label: negative
message: It's just terrible! I try to keep things in the same spot, in the house, my purse and the car! I try to talk and I forget the words I want to say! Everyone gets impatient, so I talk when I need to! <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+00A9><ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+00A9>
author: Chrissy Willard

label: positive
message: I think this says it all. This message makes it clear that to be weak is to be strong. I have scarring on my brain from the meningitis and have seizures I am very luck to have a great husband, two great companion dogs, a loving mother and a family that alwAys helps me see the laughter a of it all and make it s learning experience. I ask that you look at health issues affecting our students as it has an impact on the learning process. Thank you all. I know I like be self dependent but I also learned to ask for help. God bless all of you and Happy Easter and Passover
author: Juanita Brewer

label: negative
message: Sometimes it's hard to tell someone how it , to not remember all of the small things that they take for granted. To wake up and be afraid of another seizure.

label: negative
message: I never realized how drastically my mind could be altered. From near total recall to where I am now. Thank you, Chris

label: positive
message: I can't remember names and my conservation skills are terrible, I hate it.
author: Mark Morris

label: negative
message: Cant remember shit really, I write things down when I really need to
author: Melissa Smith

label: negative
message: I was born having a seizure.  Was diagnosed with epilepsy as a baby.  My memory has always been bad. Does anyone else sometimes "remember" something that loved ones say never happened? Or maybe have a memory of how something that happened recalled completely different to me, than everyone else? Sometimes I feel alone with this
author: Sarah Davis

label: positive
message: My daughter is facing this as well. She has been referred to a Speach therapy to improve skills and other thecniques. .she is doing better the basic is organization, calendars, writing, etc
author: Marta M Gonzalez

label: negative
message: I have to have a calendar in several places in my house and I have a little purse size one I keep in my purse.  I have to constantly look and look and even though I know I have something there I still have to look the night before.  I won't remember if I don't.  Even if you had just called and told me I won't remember.  I had surgery, my short term memory was affected from the surgery.
author: Holli Henrie

label: negative
message: The temporal lobe lobectomey 9 hr brain surgery she has on here the girl playing the guitar is what I had it was a research surgery I agreed to let Vanderbilt in Nashville TN do it did not stop my seizures but it has helped others I am blessed I had it done they found my lung cancer I am 5 yrs. remission I have the worst memory I have totally lost all memory of my daughters life I feel and have all the symptoms of early dementia I have had 2mini strokes in the last year and highly over medicated on seizures med I have cluster seizures now all types where I used to have grand mal and déjà vi
author: Regina Yount Stewart

label: negative
message: I have the same issues.  My memory seems to diminish more and more everyday.  I keep notebooks of lists,  and sometimes have to make a list of lists to make.  Keeping track of the date from day to day is nearly impossible, And special events (birthdays, anniversaries,  et cetera...) is a task in itself.  My vocabulary is getting worse because I can't recall basic words I use to use daily.
author: Morgan O'Hare

label: negative
message: Physically 24hrs, 365 days a year weak tried sometimes suffer memory loss enough
author: RoRo Covington

label: negative
message: My memory is sharp as a tack!! But my body hurts more an more as years go by!! I get grand mal seizures and have broken ribs,arms,my nose twice,stitches, shattered my ankle to having to get surgery and steal plate,some screws,and over fifty stitches in and out!! So every day I fight some pain!! But I'm alive now and I'm a survivor!!!
author: Maria Rivera

label: negative
message: I struggle as well. It feels like dementia. I assumed it was my particular drugs, but perhaps it's just the condition, now that I read these other comments. It is comforting to know I'm not alone with it. Thx all for sharing.
author: Kristin Fisher Kufeldt

label: positive
message: I some times suffer from memory loss
author: Trishtan Dawson

label: positive
message: Never did like grandma seizures were one of the worst I hate them controlling it and people make fun of you and they do
author: Bill Kane

label: positive
message: I can completely relate to this! I can't even remember what the day is, what I did yesterday, etc.
author: Lindsey Freeman

label: neutral
message: I do the same thing Chrissy. If it's not in my pattern I can't cope!
author: Jayson Degroot

label: positive
message: I can remember songs and actions I did from the eighties. Nineties and yesterday 70% of that.
author: Jayson Degroot

label: negative
message: I struggle with my memory after having a seizure. Sometimes it takes 20 minutes before I remember the simple things.
author: Robin Rogers

label: negative
message: Kelly Porter I had the same surgery. Let's see how we can help others.
author: Mary Jenkins

label: negative
message: I also go thru the same thing.Some days are different from others . Just don't  know what kind of day it's going to be. It can be scary !! I feel for all of you . Been dealing with this for 39 years ...
author: Krista Blackburn

label: negative
message: I Found Out that they're Certain Medications Out there; whether they're Old/New That could help w/the Memory Recovery. It just depends upon What Type of Seizures y'all have: & Which Rx's will work for y'all. We've all got 1 thing in common; that's the Seizures. We all need to learn to listen to Our Bodies. If you're Lucky enough to have warnings; then notice, when and/or where: they happen. Read your Rx Labels, and find out which One's Affect you. Then Explain to your Doctor, how Those Medications are Affecting y'all. Tell your Doctor's y'all want Medications w/ 1 Side Affect but without another. That's how you'll find out which Medications will work for y'all. Whenever y'all are put on a New Medication; If those New Medications have a Negative Effect Then Tell them that 1 Medication is Counteracting 1 or the Other Medications; then They'll be able to Find Out Which One's they are. Some Of Our can be Controlled w/Work, & Other's Controlled by Certain Temperature Ranges. Your Prescription Vials/Labels will say which Medications can handle what kind of temperatures they can Handle. So if y'all live in an Environment where it's Warmer than Cold: Then you'll want a Rx that will  keep you from Sweating to Death; or If you Live in a Colder Climate; Than you'll want an Rx that will keep you from Freezing to Death.
author: Cristobal Patino

label: neutral
message: KobeDaishay Shonnecia Michaela Iyónnaa Meshay
author: Kim Love

label: negative
message: I have  had epilepsy for 36 yes now and I have never learned how to drive because I knew that I wouldn't only be putting my life in jeopardy I would be jeopardizing others as well.
author: Diana Peters

label: neutral
message: No I don't drive, but it was a decision of my own not to, I thought to myself that the price was to high for me to pay, if say by chance I have a seizure while driving and someone died , because of the fact I was behind the wheel.  No I couldn't live with myself,  so although inconvenient it's best not to drive for me.  I haven't had a seizure since December of last year !
author: Rodney Rhodes

label: neutral
message: I had seizures from age 7 to 29, at the age of 29 I had brain surgery and I been seizure free 18 years praise God.
author: Barbara Ann Hawk

label: neutral
message: What resources? Transportation is difficult when coupled with other health conditions.
author: Molly Kathleen Steindler

label: positive
message: Try to think about it this way; although no fault of your own(Epilepsy ). Great danger for yourself & others when there has been a known   Reason why you should not.Having said that, I have  enormous  empathy for all who  deal with this. I have a daughter that was diagnosed with Lennox syndrome,meaning  various types of seizures & more detailed info.She is currently on 7 meds & still not controlled. Good news is though medical data reads 80per cent can be. Good luck to you, .
author: Estelle Harrison

label: negative
message:
Lost my license after my first seizure but was able to get it again. Some time later I got it again but had to give it up again nearly 10 years ago. Thinking about applying once more. 2 years since my last.

Should say, though, that family and friends have been absolutely fantastic and understanding with giving me a lift when needed.
author: Adam Rodriguez

label: negative
message:
The longest amount of seizure-free time that I've had is 6 months.
I hate to think what could have happened to me or anyone else If I started to drive during that time assuming that I was seizure-free.
author: Lupe Farran

label: neutral
message: Yes I do drive.. I lost my license for about 1 yr. I'm now in control for 2 yrs.
author: Colleen Strong

label: negative
message: I stopped driving a couple of months ago. Very hard to do. I have a carpooler to get to work but have to get to our meeting point and then back home. I finally sucked it up and told my friends and some people from church and I now have a full schedule of people wanting to drive/help me. It's been amazing. It's a blessing to them too as they felt helpless with my illnesses. Now they can do something.
author: Kristi Schwartz Lovett

label: negative
message: I don't drive for fear of hurting others and myself!! Seizures are seizures,at that point you lose control momentarily you are putting yourself and others at risk!! Commen Sense!!
author: Maria Rivera

label: neutral
message: Getting to drive at 26 was a huge accomplishment!
author: Jamie Gerow

label: positive
message: I'm starting to learn now at age 22. I'm not cleared to drive yet by my doctor, long story short.. this doctor has no clue what he's doing so I have to find a new one. Anyway, I have to learn since my husband will be deploying soon and I have to be on my own. I've had control over my seizures and can tell when I'm about to have one. If anything happens I'll just pull over and wait for it to pass.  I'm proud I'm learning so I won't have to rely on others.
author: Jessica Schaffino

label: neutral
message: My husband didn't drive for 12 years before I met him. After switching doctors and switching medicine, he has been driving for the last three years (since my baby was born)!
author: Stephanie Rabon

label: neutral
message: I am able to drive , I had to get a prescription from my neurologist and give it to my attorney to give to DMV . So I can drive .
author: Timothy Sprofera

label: negative
message: I haven't driven a car since 2009. My family has started limiting the help in taking me where and when I have to go out. It's costing me a lot. I had a seizure at the store and now it's really hard for me to get someone.
author: Thelma Caine

label: neutral
message: I have Epilepsy and seizure free close to 5 years able to drive
author: Brian Colgan

label: negative
message: I lost my driving privileges about 4 years ago in an accident, to a seizure. I've still been struggling to get my seizures under control ever since. I have one about 1 every month. Been trying regulate my meds. I now have a VNS Implant now, so maybe things will get better from here.
author: Aimee Trachta-Heck

label: positive
message: My husband could feel his seizures coming on as well. He was a young father trying to support his family. Then one day he had his first tonic clonic, behind the wheel. He made it about 3 miles down the road seizing, hit two cars and a semi  truck, then dead centered a tree 2 inches from a gas line. Thank God nobody was seriously injured, but that was his last day of driving and working. I know its hard at 27 to lose that kind of independence, but we have tho think of how many people he could have killed, including himself. The paramedics said they would not have expected anyone to live after seeing his truck. So I believe if you have a history of seizures, even though they are "controlled" absolutely no driving.
author: Chrissie Mcwilliams

label: neutral
message: As long as I keep my stress level down and take my meds yes I can drive
author: Tami Cross

label: positive
message: Just heal people with epilepsy in Jesus name.
author: Sherry Tarpley

label: neutral
message: I tried to learn, but I never mastered it, so I rely on the mass transit system and a few friends for necessary rides.
author: Susan Williams

label: positive
message: If I can't get there by mass transit I try to have some kind of money for a car service!! Other than that I don't go!!
author: Maria Rivera

label: positive
message: I agree also protein  is a big help carbs keep within low to mid amounts. Sleep is important.  Staying up late watching TV I have noticed  brings  on seizures.   At least  8 hrs sraight sleep at night.  All of this has made a world of difference
author: Maureen O Krupa

label: negative
message:
Lack of sleep is my biggest trigger for seizures. I've had epilepsy since I was 3 months old and have had 2 brain surgeries for it.
I wish employers, even if you're PT would understand the daily struggles. Such as needing to drink more water. Walmart says you're  just being difficult!!  That you can't let Epilepsy affect your daily life! But it does!!!
author: Lisa Ann Herzberg

label: positive
message: To learn more about reporting side effects, please visit our Adverse Events Reporting tab. Remember you can always report any side effects that you experience directly to your doctor and the FDA by visiting www.FDA.gov/medwatch or by calling 1-800-FDA-1088. - UCB does not endorse and is not responsible for the content on a website not sponsored by UCB.
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: neutral
message: I wasn't born with epilepsy, but I do have a combined seizure disorder, as a result of a head injury. After 15 years, specialists came up with the right combo of medications that  I didn't result in any side effects.
author: Susan Williams

label: negative
message: Unfortunately I suffer from Epilepsy and it's a very painful and disturbing head disorder to deal with, I have been dealing with this problem for a few years.... now I wasn't born like this I became epileptic after having a head surgery that safe my life. In some occasions the most painful part of dealing with this problem its not even having  epilepsy itself  it's watching those whom are around you suffer when you get one.
author: Willy Palomares

label: positive
message: I am 73 and had one seizure last year.  Never had one before.  It was confirmed  thru numerous tests that was a seizure and a grand mal.  Lasted about 15 min my hubby said.  I take one medication only.  Just so frightening
author: Peggy Gilley

label: negative
message: I have a 14 yr old son who suffers from seizures. His first seizure he had he almost died when he was 7. I want to learn more about it. He's on medication for it but he has a seizure at least twice a yr and I get scared
author: Lisa Anna Hamm Wilson

label: negative
message: I have had epilepsy for 54 years, been on dozens of meds, my veins are scarred from blood level tests, been a burden to myself and those close to me and I still go on. Could use the money forced to spend on meds for so many other things. Just broke my hip in an atonic seizure. Wouldn't even wish it on my ex......on second thought........
author: Sue Ballard

label: negative
message: When one becomes disorientated, head sore from a fall and the biting down on the tongue, it's both frightening is a sore feeling occurrence. I used to have them every day.
author: Susan Williams

label: negative
message: My son got this lasy yr. Big help
author: Laurel Cook

label: negative
message: WAY TO GO LAKEISHA!!!  WO HOOOOOOOO!!!!!!!!!!
author: Tim Tilt

label: positive
message: Congratulations to them both for not letting it stop you from your dreams. I didn't let it stay me either. 20+ years later after surgery I'm happily married and have a good job.
author: Brian Cox

label: neutral
message: I lovev her spirit..best wishes...
author: Marta M Gonzalez

label: negative
message: I had my first seizure at the age of 12. The after math was an intense headache the lasted 3 days with me me being sick to stomach to point of dry heaving.It being the mid fifties they put in hospital. They kept me medicated,for 3days we're going to do spinal tap when I woke up. They had know idea what had happened.this went on for another 12 yrs. A neurologist had me take a true and false test of 500 questions. This test kick out the answers that were similar and they were able to diagnose Petite mall Psycho Motor Epilepsy. You can't see me have a seizure, the headache after is my only clue. I have been on meds since I was 24. Now at 66, I have had a stroke, so seizures are mini strokes. Some days you just can't win for losing. That's my story, hope it helps someone.
author: Patti Slattery

label: negative
message: My son has had partial epilepsy since a very young age wasn't confirmed until he was about 4 in a half. Now he is 7 and his last seizure he jerked and slurred  his words. Possibly the beginning of Granmal very scary
author: Therealcherrie Chandler

label: neutral
message: I had them for 12 years before having a grand mal and finally being diagnosed at age 29. Very confusing infeed!
author: Lindsey Randolph

label: negative
message: So he was a late bloomer? have y'all been able to find the Right Kind of Help for Him?
author: Cristobal Patino

label: negative
message: The more we know , The better our health is . The more we know the less we discriminate . Each and every person should have an equal chance to succeed . When a door closes , another door opens. We have many bridges to cross !
author: Richard Stewart

label: negative
message:
I told a friend that we had gone to dinner with. 
And she said really....you don't look like you have epilepsy!!!! 
"I said what dose it look like???? 
I didn't know I looked different!?!?!?! 
People are rude and stupid.
author: Laurie Longmate

label: neutral
message: I don't advertise my epilepsy but since my seizures are stress induced, I have to avoid  friends with too much drama
author: Tami Cross

label: neutral
message: My own sister won't come near me.  And whenever I had a seizure when we were kids she said I did it just to get attention.  She still does.  We don't have a relationship sisters should have
author: Lora Carcione

label: negative
message: I had a boss find out and not only did he try his best to get me to quit, he actually thought that I was "retarded"..really..HIS WORD..cuz apparently, epileptics are disabled in that way. I was all too happy to inform him that not only was I not "retarded", I actually graduated high school WITH HONORS and 12 college credits already under my belt. Yah..I went above him and made a formal complaint and seeing as tho I wasn't the first, he got fired. Oh. Darn.
author: Dawn Walker

label: negative
message:
My seizures started in my sleep --- and when I was told by my girlfriend at the age of 22 that I was having seizures in my sleep??????? 

It's all good yall----- always make sure in life you are around the people that would do the same........ Think and think again about what I said-----
author: Allen Zadeh

label: negative
message: The only person who didn't  treat me differently was someone I wasn't particularly close to though we did spend a lot of time in the same company.  he asked me once, "If you have a seizure, is there anything I should do or anyone I should call" . Once I answered him, that was the end of it.  I appreciated the fact that he asked since we were together quite a bit and I appreciated that he did not treat me differently once he knew.
author: Lori Morgan

label: negative
message: Lost many so called friends
author: Nancy Clark

label: negative
message: of course it does.  but there r those that have the compassion to except.  have had a seizure prob since age of 16 and im 61 now.  of course im at that age where I could care less what others think about it.
author: Nowka Guinn

label: negative
message: I've had epilepsy for 50 yrs.  A lot of people are afraid of the sickness itself not you yourself. I've had ignorant people ask me if they could catch it. Believe me there is a light at the end of the tunnel.
author: Pat Trombley Lewis

label: negative
message: My family and friends were very supportive, but I was very embarrassed to be around people because I was afraid I would have a seizure when I was around then.that was just me thinking that and made me more of thinking up excuses when friends and family asked to to go out or over to their houses.
author: Dean Leong

label: negative
message: I have had it for a long time. Thank god meds work. One medication.if people don't love me for who I am and the way I am I just cut them off because its BS 99 percent of the people I know are very cool about it

label: neutral
message: mostly they dont. But it does happen because Im outspoken about it..
author: Scott Hesse

label: neutral
message: The same happened to me at work.  I was no longer allowed to fill in at certain position with in my department.  Once co workers found out about some of my drug interactions they would attempt to make my job difficult by be hostile toward me.

label: negative
message: Kids make fyn of my daughter all the time
author: Jennifer Kimzey

label: negative
message: My kids friends did not like coming over because of my seizures some them thought it was funny so my kids told them too get lost
author: Terressa Lake

label: negative
message: Well they begin very good to my son he grow up with he's friend from school and they take care of him and they call me and let me know and they bring him home so it being okay always have some one that knows what to do when he  or she gets sick very important don't let him hit he s head put some thing under he s head please  turn him on his left side so he can breath if u don't know what's happening call the emergancy911  ride away my god bless u and family
author: Gloria Gloria Lopez

label: neutral
message: My son was born with seizures on he's fathers side
author: Gloria Gloria Lopez

label: positive
message: It always did,whenever I was younger. But now,that I'm an Adult: & I know how to tell when my Seizures are & aren't going to happen. I've learned my limitations. I'm capable of Working w/Power Tools, Driving, & much more. As far as Other Epileptics They must push themselves; to find out what they're capable of.
author: Cristobal Patino

label: neutral
message: It changes you, even if it's just the heavy meds....
author: Nancy Hollifeld

label: negative
message: Because of the stress from being raised to keep quiet about it, then being told I gre out if it, then being old I really did not grow out of it the emotional roller coaster was all mine to ride. Finally, after many years of reading and reasoning with doctors and my Mom, I went to a Neuro. Guess mine are invisible or mostly limbic. I finally let the cat out of the bag this year since I have to face it. When I was little my friends didn't like my Mim not allowing me to twirl, spin, climb trees, ride skateboards, etc, etc. She was very ovetprotective because as a child they manifested as dizzy spells. There ARE jerks who get off on deliberately setting me off by bullying me. I know when to avoid stress and understand that not everyone needs to know. I couldn't tell you when my last seizure was because it involves things I am not conscious about. There is anxiety, stomach trouble, forgetfulness, insomnia, restless leg when tired, migranes. I try to focu on the symptom, not the cause ince that us familial from both sides of my family. I think it' vital to hsve a decent doctor.
author: Cathy Martel

label: negative
message: Very true Angelina for me as well. Those close to me have been extremely supportive but there was so much misunderstanding surrounding epilepsy. I was diagnosed in 91 at age 9.
author: Ashley Taylor Lenzi

label: negative
message: I have this since 84 and I have distanced myself from my family because of the way they have excepted  and reacted to my epilepsy. Feels like being discriminated against sometimes I feel like a freak because the way people have treated me and this is my opinion I have felt like this has been a curs.
author: John Saldana

label: neutral
message: I had epilepsy since I was 9 yrs. Old but you truly find out who your true friends are. Ive had the same friend since first grade and Im 52 yrs. Old.  To me if GOD made us equal then why did he make people with EPILEPSY MORE PRECIOUS THEN EVERYONE ELSE?
author: Tina Runyon Johnson

label: negative
message: you know whe ever i would have one people wouldnt
author: Pattie Myers

label: neutral
message: have been an epileptic since i was 4 years old, when going to school i did get maid in fun of.
author: Pattie Myers

label: neutral
message: No they don't because I tell them and prove that I can do anything they can do except drink alcohol and have a license. I have one friend that whenever I do something wrong he blames it all on seizures.
author: Thomas Potter

label: neutral
message: I have had epilespy since 1971. I have never been treated differently. I would do just about anything that other kids would do.
author: Josephine K Miller-Rott

label: neutral
message: Yes some do but most of them just treat me the same they asked a lot of questions which I never mind anyone asking. My son Richard Mckay was treated very different in school and some of the kids either didn't want to be friend's with him cause of it or they just treated him different and made fun of him all because they just didn't understand.
author: Michelle Credille

label: positive
message: People always treat me differently, ever since the day I've been diagonosed with Epilepsy people have alaways treated me like I'm an alien from outter space when I'm really just like them, some people are just rude.
author: Allison Weiner

label: negative
message: It's really sad about the stigma and the ignorance of people,no one is perfect!
author: Kathleen Quain

label: neutral
message: I have had Epilepsy since 1983 and have been thru a lot of Discrimination and still do!
author: Angelina Vilchez

label: negative
message: I lost my son to this he also started at the age of 19.He died at college never got to graduate the following year 6 months
author: Pat Edwards

label: negative
message: I've gotten treated like a leper , so I just keep my health to myself and live the life of a hermit , I'm happier that way , anti-social .
author: Andy Z. Guitarzan

label: negative
message: I am not an epileptic, but had a seizure disorder from a scar on the right side of the brain causing occasional seizures. I still take  medication, but it has now been 35 years since I even had a hint of trouble. I ccan sympathize with those who do have epilepsy. I have been blessed with no more problems and when I had them I did not go through near what others do. Take your medicine as directed. Don't skip it because you are feeling well and think you can go without it. Get plenty of sleep, dont spend a lot of time using a computer as watching the screen change with each click can trigger an episode as I am told. Never tthink you are less than anyone else. You are just as good as anyone. People have problems and this is something you cannot help, and it is certainly nothing to be ashamed of. Hold your head high, trust in God, and take care of yourself. When I did have seizures I found out that people were more compassionate than I thought and were willing to do whatever they could to help
author: Chris Boston

label: negative
message: I looked for something like this when I went to college. I couldn't find anything. It was 06/07 that I started. More publicity please.
author: John A. Steinhable Jr.

label: neutral
message: My Uncle Bobby died at age 18 after  suffering  all his short life with Epilepsy.
author: Linda Webster

label: neutral
message: Marisa Verdugo, Wendy Galvin Verdugo
author: George Verdugo Jr

label: neutral
message: Sucks...  All I can say.  Mine started at 47 years old.  No reason in the world...  Sucks....  All I can say.
author: Jackie Moore

label: neutral
message: I had my first grand mal seizure when I was 14
author: Katie Huff

label: negative
message: I had my first Grand Mal Seizure when I was only 18 also exactly a month after I had my first son who only lived for three days. After being in the hospital for two days again I was diagnosed with Epilepsy that has changed my whole adult life. I did get to have three more children and they were never affected by my medicine or being diagnosed with it and no one else has it but some reason I do have it. I had four different Grand Mal seizures but haven't had one since December 2007 but I do have partial onset seizures and they are not easy to live or deal with when it happens.
author: Lara Diane Miller

label: negative
message: Mine started after. Katrina. Hurricane. It's. Really. Bad. Diease finally got mine somewhat. Under control. I am still bothered by aura. Of smoke smell like house. Burning. Down. First was dead bodies. Sewage, then burning rubber, now only smoke right before. I have. Seizure. Meds. Are doing great.
author: Lois Mccarty

label: negative
message: I am so glad that there are sites like this one because it helps to read about other people experiences, challenges and positive achievements. My daughter has epilepsy since she was 15 and is now 23.
author: Maria Corrales

label: negative
message: I never knew there was such a thing as a epileptologist!!  I have only been to a neurologist and my medical doctor!! Need to change doctors!!
author: Maria Rivera

label: negative
message: I have problems because I have epilepsy and I have made some changes in my life. I just met a lady who hikes with her family, and she told me about her asthma. Their family, along with her, have made changes in their lives, but they still enjoy hiking. We must understand our conditon and not let our conditions controll us.
author: Mark Allison

label: negative
message: Alot of people dont realize that epilepsy effects the brain with cognitive and memory problems. I wish it was discussed more. I am impaired. My executive function is impaired.
author: Michelle Kutner Callaghan

label: positive
message: I have epilepsy for years, I have positional tremors and more so on my head.  Last year I started to go to a Tai Chi class for health in a Senior Center.  With tremors and all I decided to take the certification class when it came up.  I passed despite the fear that I may look silly with my head bobbing.  I am still in class and still feel that I will overcome this somehow.  I feel being positive and knowing that I CAN helps me.  I play games on the computer, cross word puzzles just to keep my mind working.  Good luck to you all!  :-)
author: Linda Fuentes

label: negative
message: I haven't, all issues I have had all my life are worse especially with AED's.
author: Kevin Landrum

label: negative
message: I have memory issues and nerve damage from all the seizures I've had over the past 33 years. It's frustrating, not only for me, but my friends and family as well. They try to act like it doesn't bother them but their faces and tone of voice give them away.
author: Robin Blakeman

label: negative
message: Giving up alcohol, controlling my mood swings & emotions & adjusting to not spending time alone & depressed.
author: Nicholas Humphrey

label: negative
message: Yes, when I was in high school . Teachers and other students didn't understand it. So instead of giving me a chance I was treated like an outsider. I understand I probably scared them when having them. I just think they should've given me the opportunity to explain it. Back in the 80's I was pushed away or picked on because of my behavior. I was scared and wished I had friends then. That's why today when I see someone with this disability I listen and offer my attention in every way. I let them know I know what their going thru. Working at a hospital I will go and talk to them on my break sometimes. They always say,"thank you" for listening.
author: Brian Cox

label: negative
message: It can if they see you experience a seizure like mine that are not grand mal.  I try to explain that mine are similar to a Pc needing to reboot, my brain goes offline just for a bit, I sweat buckets then come back.  As long as I keep my stress under control my seizures are for the most part.
author: Tami Cross

label: neutral
message: Yes!!!!  Especially when I'm around children.
author: Debbie Krebs

label: neutral
message: They do now, because they now understand my conditions. Positive Reinforcement.
author: Nicholas Humphrey

label: neutral
message: I think it scares my friends that ain't been around me having seizures. So when i have seizures they dont want to be around me hanging out having fun. My friends that i always be around they dont treat me any different. My friends understand and is there for me. I have my meds. with me and go where ever and just be chillin. We do the things i like doing for fun.
author: Sheika Prettydarkbrowneyes Sanders

label: negative
message: I have seizure disorder and I get treated like a leper! Love Tynk I also have cancer and that makes it worse!
author: Tina Morrison

label: negative
message: Yes, I have worked around people for periods of years before and they treated me as their friends until they found out that I was/am epileptic. The next day they went to our boss and requested that they not be assigned to work on the same job site with me because It "freaked them out" to work with me. Shortly after it was revealed to my boss that I was/am epileptic, I was promptly terminated. If you think that the Americans with disabilities act protects you and you live in a "right to work" State, think again.
author: Roger White

label: positive
message: I had so many seizures I was unable to attend college. The final straw was when I busted all my front teeth I front of everyone on campus having a seizure...never went back. I hope to now after 5 years now, just getting my license back, seizure free for a year, things looking good.
author: Matthew Wallen

label: negative
message: Not my family or fiancé, but others yeah, they are scared that I will hurt myself... Like I'm not capable of doing anything,,,like I'm a liability or something...I call it ignorance
author: Hod Freet

label: negative
message: I have it also and iv lost a few friends who are scared they see me in different way it's not fair
author: Christine Neidert

label: neutral
message: What causes Epilepsy. My Mother had Epilepsy. I never knew why she had these seizures. I was just a child when she had them. My mom passed away when she was 35 yr of cancer.
author: Caroline Franco

label: negative
message: Yes!!! I had a dentist treat me like I had ebola/rabies and was going to gnaw everyone hands off at any given moment. I'd been there before + tried to explain I was seizure-free but he was still an ignorant douche
author: Courtney Lynn

label: neutral
message: Cannot post to pull up to read
author: Maureen O Krupa

label: neutral
message: Marisa Verdugo, Wendy Galvin Verdugo
author: George Verdugo Jr

label: positive
message: The not remembering is the most difficult.  I have to write everything down. And even then I still forget sometimes!
author: Cynthia Hudson

label: negative
message: Ask questions. That's what I've been doing and I bought a medical school textbook on neurology and find it is not only informative, but also therapeutic.
author: Kevin McNulty

label: neutral
message: Plain and simple, this is why I don't drive.  Better safe than sorry if you ask me
author: Robert Fraioli

label: positive
message: Things like this are also why cities without decent public transit should be ashamed of themselves.
author: Greg Martin

label: positive
message: Be sure you are taking your medications as your doctor or neurologist has prescribed.  Be consistent.  Get seven or more hours of sleep per night and always Think Positive.
author: Robert A. Fiore

label: negative
message: I totally get this and was not upset about the times my license had been suspended for seizures, but what about people with diabetes and such? There are so many more medical conditions that make driving dangerous other than just epilepsy
author: Kailynn Dawn

label: negative
message: I had a license but no longer you must think about other people who could get hurt or killed its just to much to handle. I dont know how id live if i  was responible for hurting someone couldnt live with that happy not driving im58
author: Debbie Trumpie

label: negative
message: Where I reside the transportation system is terrible esp. if you commute to another city. You pretty much have to quit your job or take a medical leave, or go on Disability if you lose your license. If you support yourself and reside in an area that family do not reside in, you don't just find travelling to work or to the grocery stores, etc. doesn't make getting around "just a little more difficult", it makes it impossible. That's why so many people have a seizure and will not be open to tell their health care provider as they don't want to be reported to the MOT or DMV. It's can be totally life changing for the worse. I don't blame those who do not report their seizures to their doctor, esp. when they will lose their source of income, job, independence, etc. etc.
author: Susan Gilman

label: negative
message: I dont know when im gonna have a seizure im epilepsy i wasnt able to get my license im 33yrs old now
author: Sheika Prettydarkbrowneyes Sanders

label: neutral
message: Yes, It's Hideous!! While They Treat As Though You've Committed A Crime In Their Judicial System
author: Cathy C Sandford

label: negative
message: Public transit in my area sucks, (MBTA) but I have no choice but to use it. I can't afford a car of any kind and I can't afford to get a permit either. I just made the 8 month seizure free mark for MA this month too. Hopefully someday.
author: Jennifer McDonald

label: negative
message: I see comments here about not driving. using public transit, depending on friends etc. I saw one that suggest receiving disability as an option. I have no public transit available to me, my friends all have lives of their own and cannot be my personal chauffeurs, I have applied for disability and was turned down because I am otherwise physically able to work and inability to drive is not a valid reason to receive disability. What I see here are people who are afraid to live and choose to use their epilepsy as an excuse to not do so. People who are not epileptic have vehicle accidents every day and it is usually due to carelessness. Risks are a natural part of life and driving a vehicle for anyone is a risky thing. Yes you should take precautions to avoid the possible negative effects of risky behavior, but taking risks in life are necessary, if you avoid taking risks, you fail to live life to it's fullest. If you marry some one, you take the risk that that marriage might fail, but you will never know unless you take the risk, come what may. Use as much caution as possible, but take the risk and get out and live.
author: Roger White

label: negative
message: I lost my license for 6 months due to a seizure it sucked but luckly got it back
author: Jane Muserlian

label: neutral
message: I don't have a driver license, but my friend has one. She has the same thing to.
author: Donna Chambers

label: negative
message: After my gym teacher in HS was cleared to drive after being seizure free for 5 yrs he went for a drive and had 3 friends in the car with him on the parkway. He had a seizure. No survivors. I was 16yrs old just officially diagnosed finally with epilepsy and had a driver's permit. After that incident I went home, parked the driver's permit in the draw and I'm 50yrs old now and still don't drive. I have a full life, seizure more or less controlled I am allowed to get a license if I so choose. But I'll be damned if I'll be responsible for putting other people's live's at risk because I am so very much in need of an independence I can achieve in other ways. It just isn't worth it. I'm a successful teacher, sole support in my household, use public transportation, and friends, family...and I do not drive.
author: Lori Marks

label: negative
message: I only have simple partials, auras during the day and complex partials at night. I'm in my 50's and have never had a seizure while I've been driving. The head of the epilepsy monitoring unit at the University of Pennsylvania fought the DMV to get my license back!!!  I promised the DMV I would not drive while I'm sleeping.
author: Robin May Ruggie

label: negative
message: Every time i even think of trying to get my license, i start having seizures more often. Which tells me, i don't need them.
author: Jimmy Patterson

label: negative
message: I just happened on to this site,  and I too have controlled epilepsy  caused by a brain aneurysmn that leaked , resulting in brain surgery which left me with scar tissue. My peeve is not being able to receive an implant to control the seizures or at least combine the two, thereby resulting in less need for the medication and it's unwanted side effects, such as liver damage. I haven't had a seizure in at least 2 years, that I am grateful for as I have gran mall.
author: LaVelle Haney

label: positive
message: I have had epilepsy. For 41years.  Was never able to drive.   But better safe than sorry.
author: Patti Duncan

label: neutral
message: Logical, of course. And yet, once again,    my lack of...freedom or whatever makes EVERYONE'S life more difficult.  <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+0095>
author: Jennifer Ditty

label: neutral
message: Ya I have had 2 seizures behind the wheel thank god nobody was hurt but me and just cuts and brooses
author: Christine Neidert

label: negative
message: Its not that easy,we don't have buses out where I live and if I don't have a neighbor that is going out..I'm stuck and its the worst feeling like your helpless and can't do nothing for yourself.
author: Sherryann Smith

label: positive
message: Better stay safe for and for others
author: Marta M Gonzalez

label: neutral
message: Yes it is very difficult to get around. I have had seizures since I was 9mo.old So I have never been able to drive, or work. I've had seizures, and still do. But thankfully not as bad as I used to. For in 2013 I received a VNS implant. I am doing great my dr.is pleased with progress.<ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+0080> But now, I am starting to try to find resources for other means of transportation for myself to get around.
author: Nicki Kinder

label: neutral
message: Sheika Sanders, I am also 33 and have never driven
author: Robin Blakeman

label: neutral
message: I've never driven. I am lucky to have friends, family, and some one from the VNA to help me get around when I can't walk to the store.
author: Robin Blakeman

label: neutral
message: It ruin my childhood im making up for it now chidhood sucjed
author: Debbie Trumpie

label: negative
message: The Ignorance that follows it. that Anyone that has Seizures can't Work. I've  Worked on Job Sites, As an Automotive Technician, in Stadiums & held many Other Positions. As long as I Worked I didn't have Seizures. I couldn't just sit on my ass like so many.
author: Cristobal Patino

label: negative
message: I have to be careful when I'm sick so I don't throw up my meds, plus there is only so much you can take! I would like to take cold-eeze but don't know how it would interact with the meds I'm on!
author: Karen Carrozza

label: neutral
message: How does someone with Epilepsy (myself) become an Epilepsy Advocate?
author: Amanda Markovich

label: negative
message: I am currently having memory issues, where i also have had to give up career choice because of it. Comforting to hear im not the only one.
author: Jen Rondina Domschine

label: negative
message: Had to also give up nursing career and have to take 3 seizure meds which causes memory loss.  I was born with epilepsy but my 1st seizure didn't start til I was 23.  Now I'm 33 and have a nursing license that I can't use.  Was fired on multiple occasion because I am a liability in their eyes.
author: Crystal Dawn Clark

label: negative
message:
I also have lost several great careers due to epilepsy. I have memory, speech, and language issues. No one wants to retrain anyone over and over. I go through times where I do not remember my name or how to spell my husbands. After a seizure I don't always know who family members are. It seem that sometimes the medications we take for this make the memory issues worse.  It is scary. 
Thank you for sharing. It is helpful to know I am not alone.
author: Cheri Nelson

label: positive
message: I have 2 Degrees one in A.S. Computer Network and Security Management, and one in A.S. Medical Assistant. I am not able to use either due to the obvious hazards in each field.
author: Thomas O. Moudy Jr.

label: negative
message: Awilda Coll, I know what you are saying. I understand. There are things about my son's childhood that I can't remember. I see pictures and will ask when did that happen? Or family will talk of evens and I can't bring it to mind. It it frustrating.
author: Cheri Nelson

label: negative
message: I also was a nurse for 20 plus years started having trouble remembering why I was doing for that Dr. That's when I was do with complex partial epilepsy couldn't drive an had to quite work because I could become dangerous.  I cried for years over losing my job I wanted to be a nurse since I was a child. Then within a few months my whole world stopped an started in a new direction I was unsure of. My family is awsome I've not worked in 10 years now an I still become sad about not getting to nurse I loved it so much but God has me by the hand an we will win in the end God bless you all
author: Melody Lewis

label: negative
message: Hi Ivonne, i began having memory loss after my third seizure. I went back to work realizing i had no  idea what to do. People stared at me in disbelief, and this is probably the most frustrating part. I used to be a 4.0 student. I tried going back to college and failed misserably! I couldnt pass any test. I get frequent migraines, my vision isnt the same so it makes them worse, i cant concentrate, and the memory loss is no help at all. Is your son having issues in school? Maybe you should consider it as a sign. If not sit down and talk to him. I think it's  great that you follow this page, and trying to learn more. It is very difficult  to have to accept that this is our life. The headaches, losing  careers, and not remembering the most important event in our lives. It is always appreciated to have someone who cares and understands. Goodluck to u Ivonne.
author: Lana Ayla Smith

label: positive
message: Long Term and Short Term Memory issues have made life very frustrating. Thank Father God and Mother God for the Social Security Disability Act, or my family would not have housing, food, etc...
author: Thomas O. Moudy Jr.

label: positive
message: When did you guys start to experienced memory loss? My son has epilepsy and I don't know if he is having that issue...he is 19 years old?
author: Ivonne Whitaker

label: negative
message: I have memory loss also, was fired from one job, & had to leave one to have brainsugery.  My memory is gone out the window, but the main side effect I have is speech. Just about every time I talk, I have 99.99 percent of people lookin at me with that confused look on their faces, or they come right out & tell me they don't understand what I'm saying, not my friends, just people who don't know me. Yes, for "2days & 2hrs" it hurt my feelings to hear that, but I'm not letting that bother me anymore. I knew I did the right thing, & I'm VERY glad I did. I would rather have lack of memory & speech problem, than having petit mal seizures "every 2mins& 2 secs!!
author: Lori Mc Miller

label: negative
message: My son quit high school at 16 because of the epilepsy. He is now 24 and has went through Hodgkins Lymphoma and has alot of the same issues. Glad he's not alone but where is the help?
author: Evelyn Lane Cross

label: negative
message: I can't take classes anymore because of my memory:(
author: Shane Saulque

label: negative
message: My oldest daughter is in the same situation,fired from a job of almost seven years,she lost all her benefits after another year on leave. Then the doctors,after 72 hour EEG in hospital stay,inwhich she did not have a single seizure,lol,go figure. The long term insurance company which was paying her long term leave pay cut her checks off immediately. Reason was the doctors found nothing wrong during her stay. She has little seizure meds left,and we cannot afford almost a $1,000.00 a month. This just causes more stress and ofcource more seizures. Without some kind of help from somewhere,her condition is only worsening. She was getting scheduled by her primary doctor to go to the Mayo Clinic,but with no insurance and no income things are not looking to good. She has multiple seizures back to back,and it's not good. Since January 1st,she has had episodes daily,but in that time she has had 5 days that she was seizure free,a Blessing. I have been writing done her episodes on paper,but who in the long pays for her condition is her. She has been having seizures since age 12,the last 2 years have been ridiculous. I pray for her all the time. Her 9 year old son has seen it all,and it scares him to death every time,ad it does me. Thank you for letting me vent a little. May God bless us all
author: Herbert Gregory

label: negative
message: I had seizures in 2010 and life has not been the same since. I have segments of long term memory that seem to be missing. I also have trouble with organizing my thoughts and remembering tasks.I am on meds for epilepsy
author: Kim Garza

label: positive
message: Thank you for sure lost memory too
author: Liz Ryan

label: negative
message: My memory is terrible I often only can remember things after someone mentions it. But sometimes even then I don't remember it's very frustrating.
author: Denise Davis

label: negative
message: I have lost certain parts of past memory such as when my kids bring up past events I can not remember them. It makes me feel so inadequate!!
author: Awilda Coll

label: negative
message: Please ask your Dr. about SUDEP, it has no age boundaries and my Daughters Dr. Did not tell us about it, we lost our 32 year old and had no clue it could happen.
author: Gib Kuspa

label: negative
message: I told my girl friend after a couple dates. You have to feel comfortable enough with the person.
author: Buck Smith

label: negative
message: I've always been open about it on the first date. I'd rather they know, just in case, and hopefully understand and stick around. If something I can't control is what chases them away, why invest emotionally?
author: Morgan O'Hare

label: negative
message: As soon as I meet anyone I let them know, I would rather they know why I am on the floor then wondering why, if they can't handle or accept me for who I am then they aren't worth MY time.
author: Leslie Small

label: negative
message: I do because my eye or hand may twitch and it eleviates the need to get any deeper involved if they can't deal with that
author: A Roy Brown

label: neutral
message: I have to really know and trust them before I say anything.
author: Dona Ellison

label: neutral
message: I told who is now my husband on our first date.
author: Shelly Landry Koonce

label: negative
message: I told my husband before we started dating.  He helped me learn to control my  seizures, havent had any since 1994 :)
author: Lorinda Coleen Fournier

label: negative
message: My daughter would always let then know about her Epilepsy before they even went out on a first date.
author: Laurie Barnes

label: negative
message: I tell people right away.
author: Zach Arellano

label: negative
message: I tell them before we ever go on the first date. I'm not going to hide something very important in my life. If he doesn't have an open mind about it then I'm not going to waste my time!
author: Shannon London

label: negative
message: I actually had one on our 2nd date. I figured if he stuck around after that he was a "keeper". We have been married now for over 8yrs and have 4 children. <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+0089>
author: Jennifer Wortham Berger

label: neutral
message: Men in general don't want to hear about chronic illnesses.
author: Susan Williams

label: neutral
message: I don't think it would be a big deal unless you are not well controlled.
author: Mary Parrish Holmes

label: negative
message: I let my wife know on our first date. She tells me that I had one that night.
author: Michael Roque

label: negative
message: I've had epilepsy since I was 15 and I didn't feel comfortable talking about it with people that I just met, but when I had one on a date I decided to tell them right away.
author: Shane Saulque

label: negative
message: Leslie Small, I agree with you 100%. I let everyone know right away. I also tell them what to do if I have a seizure. If they want nothing to do with me after that, oh well. I also have other medical conditions and told the guy I'm dating about everything before he ever asked me out. He is very caring, supportive, and protective of me and we are very happy together. My friends also call to check on me if they can't visit
author: Robin Blakeman

label: negative
message: My wife of 10 years, started noticing symptoms when I was sleeping at night.
author: Nathan Farris

label: negative
message: With this one guy (now my boyfriend) I didn't tell him until our 3rd date, I was still nervous when telling him. But he was totally understanding.
author: Lindsay Marie Della Ratta

label: neutral
message: In the past I told my dates on the 4th or 5th date then after I told them I would never hear from them.
author: Lindsay Marie Della Ratta

label: neutral
message: I tell about epilepsy right away.
author: Nancy Mestepey

label: neutral
message: When they experience your Gran,Mal seizure with them
author: Herbert Gregory

label: negative
message: I tell people right away, we shouldn't be ashamed of what is happening to us. I was not born with, up to this day no Dr can't tell what caused it but can tell only tell where it's triggered from in my brain. Be Brave and stand up.
author: J Strétch Mereigh

label: negative
message: If he really cares  and loves you like he said he dose then take you no matter how you are.
author: Janie Gant

label: neutral
message: I tell them right off the bat, if they are the right person for me they will be compassionate and understanding!
author: Darcy Healey

label: neutral
message: Can you grow out of this? My son was five when he had his first.
author: Maria Brown

label: neutral
message: I have Complex Partial Seizure Disorder with second Generalzation according to my Neurologist I have been seizure free for 4 and half years going on five in August 28th
author: Katie Kristin Wilkinson

label: neutral
message: I have had seizures since I was 14 years old, now 32 and if I miss medicine  doses I am likely to have one. I have nocturnal grand mal seizures. I am so thankful that medication controls them.
author: Jessica Vp

label: neutral
message: I have a cousin, now deceased, who suffered with seizures. I find this information very interesting and informative.
author: Judy Walton

label: negative
message: Mine started about 17 yrs ago, and were frequent until I was prescribed the right meds and made some lifestyle changes (stopped drinking like a fish).
author: Wister Haines

label: neutral
message: I decided years ago I would never drive. I can't always tell when I am about to have a seizure and I refuse to get behind the wheel and play Russian roulette other peoples lives.
author: Robin Blakeman

label: negative
message: If you take seizures don't drive.  Common sense more than anything.   If they are controlled then you can call motor vehicle and they'll tell you 6 months and some states 2 years seizure free.
author: Patricia Pollard

label: positive
message: My doctor has said and I have read,its up to the doctor,if you are safe to drive or not.Myself I do drive & have for the last 38 years,without any problems & still do.
author: Glenn Gilbert

label: negative
message:
3 months in NE - which I think is ridiculous!!
I can't remember the last time I drove- I take the city bus to and from work.
It's not ideal but I'm thankful to have the option.
author: Amanda Townsend Summers

label: negative
message:
Even though I had brain surgery over twelve years ago, I'm still skeptical about getting behind the wheel.

I get real nervous getting behind the wheel and I'm afraid that that will make my seizures even worse after having this brain surgery.

I don't want to make the seizures worse after the brain surgery has helped out on controlling the seizures even more making it to where I hardly have them at all.
author: Troy Miller

label: negative
message: I got discriminated against and fired at my last work place because of my epilepsy.
author: Theresa Brown

label: negative
message: People have ways of hiding it but most places do discriminate. Who wants someone collapsing on the job and adding all that liability.
author: Melissa Smith

label: positive
message: Oh please I worked for a Community Health Center for 7 years. If you google my name I even made national headline news for them! Never a write up or anything. I complained to the EEOC about my sons epilepsy episode and they did nothing. I was ultimately fired. There is no help.
author: Sun Dee

label: negative
message: I'm 33 yrs old now and a nurse, I have had jobs tell me I am a liability for them,  and I have been fired also because of my medication side effects. So I am sitting here unemployed with a nursing license.
author: Crystal Dawn Clark

label: negative
message: My husband has been fired from jobs because of his epilepsy. They claim they don't feel comfortable with him there. I call bs
author: Samantha Vaughn

label: neutral
message: My husband had a seizure at work, 2 months later he was the first one laid off due to downsizing.  Now he's on disability because of his memory issues.
author: Eileen Calkins-Poindexter

label: negative
message: Workng ib a right to work state, been fired from 3 jobs because of my epilepsy.  ADA won't help.
author: Nikki Price-Larison

label: positive
message: THANK YOU AMERICAN AIRLINES FOR NOT SENDING ME HOME. GOD BLESS !!
author: Lydia M. Salinas

label: positive
message:
Well, I had a seizure at work today. Running LATE to catch my flight and boom it happens.
But, I survived and off I go to continue living my LIFE. YEAH!!  MY LIFE NOT EPILEPSY 'S !!
author: Lydia M. Salinas

label: neutral
message: Now, if we could only get Employers to give us a chance.
author: Cristobal Patino

label: positive
message: as of right now, my job is working around my sons appointments and working with me. I hope it stays this way
author: Kelly Case

label: neutral
message: Crystal Dawn Clark I understand completely
author: Emmie Parks

label: neutral
message: I knew, both Emergency &Departmental RN's in The Texas Medical Center.
author: Cristobal Patino

label: neutral
message: There's a difference between disruptions, Drunk, & Drugs.
author: Cristobal Patino

label: positive
message: Unless your disease impacts your ability to do the job. Why sue if you cant so it as well as others. Sometimes i have alot of muscle spasms and things can break etc. I would not keep someone like me on the job if i couldnt do a good job consistently.
author: Jeremy Williams

label: neutral
message: Thank you, Chris!  Thanks for sharing!
author: Terese Kvasnicka

label: positive
message:
I have memory problems. I have been having seizures for 15 years. Sometimes I don't know my name or how to spell my husbands name. I am lucky to have a good support system. I have had seizures in public and that can be really embarrassing. I have learned that the people don't forget but aren't rude. They will ask how I am or just say hi. I have been blessed to live where there are kind people. I read a comment someone said they had a hole new meaning to short term memory, I understand that and can add new meaning to long term memory. Things we learned as young people, every day things, I sometimes can't remember. It is frustrating that I cannot work. However, I put my self in the shoes of an employer, and I know that it would be impossible to retrain someone again and again. 
I am greatful to epilepsy advocates lto be able to share with people who live life with a similar understanding. Thank you all for sharing.
author: Cheri Nelson

label: positive
message: I feel you! "Short-term memory" has a whole new meaning now! It is not a joke!!!
author: Carissa Armstrong

label: negative
message: I always walked with my head down, and living in a busy city (L.A.) is scary because I never knew what would happen if I had a seizure (rape, arrested, or run out in the street and get hit by a car. My auras terrified me and the thought/fear of having a seizure scared the living ----out of me.  I never left the house by myself
author: Gina Butler

label: negative
message: Yes, it is very embarrassing and strange and frustrating.  I've learned to make little eye contact with people on the street and in establishments, etc., as I so oftentimes do not remember them, but they remember me.  I've learned as well, especially now living in a very small town, not to engage in very many stories or day-to-day experiences, as I have had people say that I told them that before.  It's usually little things, like a cute story of a local dog, etc., but I just don't do it.  All the same, I guess without asking for it, because I do police accountability with regards to abuse to the disabled, the elderly, children, and dogs, they more and more know who I am anyway.  As my work grows, but my memory flails, I guess my message is delivered and brings attention all the same.  I just wish the attention never feel on me.  It does all the same.
author: Gina Goodman

label: neutral
message: Viví con mi hijo 20 años de amargura y profundo dolor hasta que finalmente mi hijo falleció en una crisis y estaba solo y durmiendo. Lo peor es que la persona no quiere tratamiento de por vida .La lección más dura de mi vida.
author: Myriam Amparo Lopez

label: negative
message: How about, Stop telling Every Epileptic, that they can't Work. Working Hard Controls my Seizures. And I don't mean sitting on my ass in front of a Computer. I mean Working on a Job Site around Heavy Equipment, Up underneath the Hoods, Building & Remodeling  Homes.
author: Cristobal Patino

label: neutral
message: i never tell..im always worried about getting fired
author: Judy Golden

label: negative
message: You guys should do a series on service dogs, how they help, and where we can find them for a reasonable cost or free. A lot of trainers want $50,000 for a dog.
author: Rebecca Price-Larison

label: positive
message: Releasing the hurt your able to receive the hope. I love that!
author: Sufia Martinez

label: negative
message: Thank you for sharing, Mike. I also experienced viral encephalitis, which left me in a coma for two and a half weeks. When I awoke from the coma and since then, I've had auditory agnosia, memory loss, and epilepsy (which I was only recently diagnosed with.) For years, I lived in constant fear and anxiety. I still struggle every day with some of my disabilities, but I'm so thankful that they've also opened me up to so many opportunities and blessings that I never would have dreamed of before. Your story really touched me. I'm so thankful that I'm not alone in these struggles. I'll be praying for you and all those who struggle with epilepsy and the trials that come along with it. Love to you all
author: Julie Weilage

label: negative
message: It's very hard because put me in a room with 10 people who don't suffer and you couldn't guess. Often it's very isolating and you feel very alone.
author: Rick Sheehy

label: negative
message: Ive been so frustrated with my epilepsy and now being diagnosed with Mild Spinal Canal Stenosis wasnt the outcome I wanted.. now to see if I get Laserspine surgery.. or live in more pain for the rest of my life and im 35.
author: Melinda J. Lombard

label: negative
message: Amen to all I all so have a son with seizure he gets sad I there a cure for seizure hope there is so every body that has them can life a normal life amen to all
author: Gloria Gloria Lopez

label: neutral
message: i find support in the barn with my horses and dogs!!
author: Judy Golden

label: negative
message: We have such a whopping case of Intractable E that almost no one can relate. And, have been at the forefront of science as well, so again people can't really relate.
author: Vicky View

label: positive
message: I agree with Debbie a lot. I talk to my pharcacist. I rely on my neurologist to prescribe the medications that are helping me greatly, but that pharmacist is the person who knows even more about medications. I alos rely on my pharmacist.
author: Mark Allison

label: neutral
message: Debbie C. is a GREAT Person. She has helped so many for years and years.
author: Robert A. Fiore

label: neutral
message: I was never offered any kind of help from the epiliesy foundatian
author: Debbie Trumpie

label: neutral
message: i have drove since September of 2014 when my doctor took me off the road be cause of a eye problem better safe then sorry
