label: positive
message: Lay down and rest till I can speak than usually sleep
author: Valo Bam

label: neutral
message: I sleep in a pitch dark room in the quiet.
author: Megan Hetrick

label: negative
message: Partials,  I talk to my husband. He can "pull me back to reality" the grand-mals, I have to sleep, once I wake I check on my kids go to the restroom and then my husband "pulls me back to reality" I am always in the same spot (my bed, just after going to bed at night). I have had 1 without my husband.  It was probably one of the most scariest things I've went through.  I couldn't be "pulled back to reality" as quickly as my husband can, I was by myself. I didn't recognize house.
author: Dusty Reid

label: negative
message: Partials I usually just need a few minutes & maybe a drink of water.  A full tonic clonic I need sleep & then time when I wake up to process what happened.
author: Jessica Smith

label: negative
message: Not doing anything until I feel better sometimes I nap
author: Anna Flack

label: negative
message: I have to sleep with cold rag in dark. Sometimes even a soak in bath. That help me with nausea.
author: Jamie Duke Bunton

label: negative
message: Sleep I get the worst migraines afterwards
author: Breanna Bala

label: negative
message:
Does anybody else feel like they need ta hold there breath whenb
 having one of these?..For some reason I feel its going to help n idk why..Just seeing if anyone else does..
author: Brian Krueger

label: positive
message: Hope for a cure !! For the whole brain
author: Mir Rahman

label: neutral
message: Yawn & stretch. Holler while I'm stretching. Take a nap.
author: Cathy Martel

label: neutral
message: I usually sleep, for a few days; after any type of seizure.
author: Marie Andres Workman

label: positive
message: Sleeping mainly. Going through normal/ everyday routine. But all of mine have been grand mals. Except lately my neck has been tight and hurting, like pressure building
author: Carissa Dennery

label: negative
message: Since my meds are working my seizures have changed from full blown to partial is this common?
author: Wendy Misikin

label: negative
message: plenty of rest and no stress my last seizure was in 1997 a few days after my daughter was born for me i dont drive i take the bus seizure free for 18 yrs
author: Nancy Stone

label: positive
message: i will throw up and sleep alot. Also wont remember what happened.
author: Penny Gatica

label: negative
message: Sometimes a small nap helped!
author: Jennifer Cortez

label: neutral
message: Nap.. and something for the headache that normally comes along.
author: John David Williams

label: neutral
message: Oh and the rest helps restore my eye sight
author: Ashley Taylor Lenzi

label: neutral
message: Sleep as my head hurts so bad and all my energy is completely drained
author: Ashley Taylor Lenzi

label: neutral
message: Two to three maybe four hours of sleep
author: Ryan Oran

label: neutral
message: Cold wash cloth all over. Never shower!   Talking to someone,  helps.  Because I am so confused and frightened afterwards.
author: Syd Spackman

label: negative
message: How can we get in contact for future information about partial complex seizure in females!
author: Leticia Letty Perez Garzoria

label: positive
message: I've had it for 11 years almost died 4 times a lot of sleep works for me I get dizzy afterwards
author: Timothy Cobler

label: negative
message: Bunny, I'm just talking from my personal experience. I never see or feel one coming. Wish I could in a way. No auras, nothing. I know I had a big one when I wake up on a stretcher. Less scary now my family/friends know what to do. Plenty of rest after always helps.
author: Jennifer Szewczyk

label: neutral
message: I used to wipe my face with cold water,sit and compose myself.A coke thecaffiene helped
author: Renee Peek

label: negative
message: I just ride it out thought the pain in a safe place (bed/reclining sofa) then try to just cool off and relax and get medicated <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+0096>
author: Sean Page

label: negative
message: My daughter is not aware when hers are coming on and the are gran mal seizures. She normally sleeps off and one the rest of the day but is fine after that.
author: Misty Beard

label: neutral
message: Sleep. Partials seem to drain me physically and mentally.
author: Jeremy Zwart

label: negative
message: Someone around me reassuring me that I'm ok.  Sleep but then they still continue in my sleep.
author: Haley Childs Radford

label: negative
message: My daughter has them in clusters, so we know they are over, or that emergency meds aren't needed when she finally feels like sleeping (and does).  After some sleep she is usually back to herself.
author: Bridgitte Krupke

label: positive
message: He never knew when they would come n didnt remember them n slept hrs after.i kept him within my sight.i knew.
author: Michele Manning

label: negative
message: My wife has complex partial seizures. Usually what helps her is to do almost anything that will keep her mind busy. If she is alone she will usually get pretty anxious afterwards. But if she is around other people it usually helps.
author: Neil Kramer

label: neutral
message: My grandson also has to sleep for several hours and suffers from headaches afterwards
author: Cheryl Ramirez

label: positive
message: I usually need to just lay down for a couple minutes or curl up in the fetal position worked a lot when I was a kid
author: Haleigh King

label: neutral
message: Juanma Anguiano Sandra R. Lopez read this article
author: Eduardo Anguiano

label: negative
message: When I wake up, I'm lost I hate that feeling, but then i feel my body and my head hurt bad. So I take a hot hot hot bath and try to relax. This last one I had I pulled sumthing n my thigh. I'm better now but without that bath when I first wake up I dnt know what I would do.
author: Kristina Allyse Banda

label: neutral
message: My 2 family members get a lot of sleep
author: Juanita Coco Cavazos

label: positive
message: I have to gran mal seizures. The only thing that works for me is plenty of rest.
author: Michele Penkul Guzofski

label: negative
message: I am scared of where I am at but my daughter talks too me when I clam down I go sleep for about 1 hour or 2 but I am still tried so I relax the rest of the day
author: Terressa Lake

label: negative
message: Other times I am so tired I fall asleep
author: Tom Curran

label: negative
message: Sleep. I also usually feel cold, even in warm weather, so I use a blanket or sleep under the covers.
author: Michael Roque

label: neutral
message: I have to sleep after mine because Im drained out after them and also the quiet helps too.
author: Kimberly Gollach

label: negative
message: I usually get sleepy but it's hard to rest afterwards if I'm at work, the store, etc. Sometimes I get a headache.
author: Melinda Crumbaugh

label: positive
message: I sleep for at least a couple hours after a partial seizure, although if it secondarily generalizes into a full on tonic clinic then I sleep all day....plus yes some sort of headache-migraine medication for those god awful headaches some people like me get afterward.....
author: Erik Tessman

label: neutral
message: Sleep and then a bit of exercise afterwards
author: Nylan Hynek

label: negative
message: My 6 yr old is the one with seizures we turn him on left side and talk to him till he can get up on his own...
author: Bobby Wheeler

label: positive
message: My son usually lays down and naps or rests for a while. He has complex partials and within the last.couple months started having grand mals or tonic-clonics. He bounces back a lot faster then I do from them.  Haha.
author: Emily Flynn

label: negative
message: I get very confused. Anything with caffeine helps. 3-4 hrs of naps helps as well
author: Iddy Garcia

label: negative
message: My daughter last abt 30 second r longer but they got her two kind of medicine now
author: Anne Regina Pitts

label: neutral
message: My son has absence seizures then graduated to tonic clinic seizures. Typically lasting 5-6 minutes having 3-5 seizures back to back.  He usually sleeps for 24 hours after having them. Thankfully he only has them 3-6 times a year.
author: Donna D Gro

label: neutral
message: Lots of rest for the next couple of days but mine usually last longer than the 30-60 seconds you are referring to. Mine last 10-20 minutes with two of my longest lasting 45 minutes.
author: Jayme Judd

label: negative
message: Sleep. Lots of sleep and someone to take care of me for the rest of the day
author: Lisol Monreal

label: neutral
message: Lots of sleep and medicine for my massive migraine afterwards.
author: Julie Greenleaf

label: neutral
message: After this type of seizure my son sleeps 8 to 10 hours
author: Marc Rinaldi

label: negative
message: Agree with Willie Korte. Take it easy, stress free time and a nap.
author: Lana Glasgow Jensen

label: negative
message: Some sleep and time to process what has just occurred.
author: Meg Callahan

label: neutral
message: Knowing my husband is by my side helps me.  However I get really sleepy.  I normally sleep really hard afterwards
author: April Lamm Edmonds

label: negative
message: Time. Sleep, and plenty of ice to suck on.
author: Nick Shute

label: negative
message: Well I'm going to have to agree with everyone else rest nap chilling out
author: Korenn Eddy

label: negative
message: I need rest, after one I can sleep up to 12 hrs, I also drink a little pop
author: Leslie Small

label: negative
message: My son falls asleep for hours after feels like he looses his whole day when he has one :(
author: Kacy Marie

label: negative
message: Rest....for SP's. Lots of rest & some emotional support for TC's!
author: Jessica Morgan Reeder

label: neutral
message: Sleep & dark quiet room.
author: Melody James

label: negative
message: I need sleep if I loose consciousness. Even if it's a 15 minute nap.
author: Kimberly Knudsen Byers

label: neutral
message: I agree with octavia lindsay sleep is the best.
author: Jim Rourke

label: negative
message: I really try to pretend it is not happening, if that don't work I use my magnet on my VNS , I am fine afterwords , I do try to keep a diary of them for my Dr. Thank God they do not last longer or get worse.
author: Juanita Brown- Stephens

label: negative
message: Seeing my Friends and or Family around me always helps me feel better, recover and know everything's going to be ok. And then a nice nap! ;-)
author: Andy Carrasco

label: positive
message: Trying to distract myself/not thinking about how it can lead to a worse one for me. Air, breathing lots of fresh air deep.
author: Andrew Hasler

label: neutral
message: My middle brother had a form of this after a boxing match in witch he was knocked out for many years he had episodes it has been many years he is doing well now
author: Peter Johanneck

label: neutral
message: Usually sleep, in a dark quiet room. I usually  get headaches afterwards,  so that is when I sleep  it off.
author: Nicki Kinder

label: negative
message: I did not get a positive response from the neurologist when I did this.
author: Angela Braford Tuell

label: negative
message: Just walk in with a smile and wait for them to talk and ask any questions you feel you need to. Their usually pretty patient understanding and knowledgable
author: Madison Suessa-Joelle Angeline

label: negative
message: Oklahoma doesn't require it, I'm obeying because it seems like the right thing to do.  Causes a lot of problems, but I would hate to hurt someone accidentally <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+009F>
author: Jerri Carr

label: negative
message: I don't think people are selfish if they are under control. Each state has a rule of how long after. Even if your Dr don't have to report they tell you that you can't drive and it is noted if you do and something happens. If you have them non stop then no you should not but if you are seizure free and under control you should be able to drive and have a life!!
author: Lisa Schultz

label: negative
message: Ok I have a question ....my son is an Epileptic  so  know he can't drive yet.  But I want to know why an insulin diabetic can drive ? There sugar buttons out they pass out. Or there sugar goes so high they go into keto acidosis. ..that's dangerous too......
author: Nancy Stinson

label: negative
message: I have never been a good driver; failed the driving test twice lol. I'm 27 & had 2 seizures in my first 2 decades and they were considered unrelated. I began having multiple seizures when I was 19 & was soon diagnosed with Temporal Lobe Epilepsy. I look at it this way: my failing the tests was just a sign of not being safe for other drivers <U+263A>
author: Carissa Armstrong

label: negative
message: I'm in Delaware just got my license back after not for 8 years been seizure free for almost 2years now
author: Gale T Taylor

label: neutral
message: Makes it hard to get a job if u do lapse the seizure time period
author: Melissa Smith

label: positive
message: I don't disagree with these kinds of laws completely, but I do think it's strange that doctors aren't also required to report other illnesses that can be dangerous when driving, like tremor and spasms, chronic pain, insomnia, etc. (Or are they, and I just don't know? My state, TX, doesn't require docs to report.)I would always hope that people would be personally responsible enough to not knowingly endanger other drivers on the road when they're not well enough to drive, though.
author: Chelsea Keesler

label: neutral
message: As long as you follow your doctors orders this should be private. Not regulated by the state.
author: Cindy Lapham Cordova

label: neutral
message: I just dont drive. it's not worth another life.
author: Michelle Brown

label: negative
message: I drove after the doctors thought my epilepsy was under control since I had been seizure free for awhile. Then I had a massive absence seizure and rolled my car at 120mph in 8:00 rush hour traffic. I shattered my leg and had 30 operations on it in 4 years. The next surgery is an amputation. I wish the doctor had taken my license. I'm going to be an amputee because of driving with epilepsy. Btw- I've been seizure free after a temporal lobectomy 11 years ago.
author: Kathryn Hardaway

label: neutral
message: If they don't want to allow me to drive, then I want disability. If I can't drive, I can't get to work. MS doesn't have adequate public transportation.
author: Michael Ross

label: negative
message: The state of NY now provides Medical Transportation. I've been through h*ll for over 4yrs trying to use this service & most of the time it does not seem worth it. If I drive I risk injuring other people. When walking (and this has happened several times) I risk having a seizure & NO ONE CALLS 911 even though they see me laying on the sidewalk convulsing. When I call Med. Trans. (it is used only for medical appts.) many times I am faced with rudeness, accusations of missing paperwork, questions that involve digging into my personal life. One of the most common questions is "Do you live within 1mile of a bustop?" And yes I do. Sometimes this ok, sometimes not. The problem with that: when people drive or walk right by you as if nothing is wrong when your life is in serious danger! So if I can't drive, and I would not want to anyway so as not endanger innocent people, what do I do? I walk as often as possible. But the options are slim when it comes to seeing my neurologist who is 2hrs away.
author: Carissa Armstrong

label: neutral
message: I think every state should be required to report you. I live in Texas and they are not.
author: Stephanie Atkinson

label: positive
message: I had no problem with waiting the 6 months seizure free.  I had a problem with them making me take something called adaptive driving.  Some glorified name for drivers ed at 100 dollars an hour.  The number of hours was not state controlled, the company had the ability to make it as long or short as they saw fit.  Hint don't dress like you can afford it.
author: George Burke

label: neutral
message: I would love to share my story to anyone who feels like they can't do it cause of epilepsy. Especially a young man. 23 years old and 6 years clean. Owe it to god
author: Alex Ruggiero

label: negative
message: You should have to be seizure free at least a year and every state should have to report it. It's sick how many people still having seizures drive and put everyone else at risk for their own selfishness.
author: Trisha Ramsey

label: negative
message: This is exactly what I just posted a reply to another person. What is seizure control? When you've been diagnosed with epilepsy seizures can happen at any time. No matter how long you've been seizure free. So, no matter if it's been a year or 6 months of a waiting period.  I believe this is a matter between patients and their doctors. Because not all seizures are alike nor are there impacts the same on each person. Again as I stated, most ppl don't joy ride I think unfortunately, some ppl may drive because they don't have any other choice. It's just my opinion. I don't condone driving knowing your not feeling well, but for me that's not just with epilepsy that's across the board with any illnesses.
author: Lakeisha Parnell

label: negative
message: I had a seizure while driving after being seizure free almost 3 years. My young children were in the car with me and no aura. Apparently I drove through a fence during a grand mal seizure and almost hit a house. While seizing, they had a very hard time getting my foot off the gas peddle. Of course I lost my license and continue to have seizures. One dr says seizure free for a year, but my dr says she never wants me to drive again. My girls' beg me to please never drive. As inconvenienced as my life has become, I don't think I can drive again. I even have nightmares abt it. Sensitive issue in my house. :(
author: Melinda Gail Mink

label: negative
message: Reported it not, required or not, if you drive before your waiting period and have an accident, you could still be liable, just like drunk driving. If they find the diagnosis in your medical history (think insurance company lawyers), it's on you. Be safe everyone. I know I did not even feel like driving for 3 months. The last 3 were bearable because my wife and I work together and could carpool.
author: Jeremy Spivey

label: negative
message: Husband hasn't driven in 6 years and will never get it back. He hasn't been controlled by meds and should not be driving. I believe a person and doctors need to take ownership of health problems. It is never ok to a say I'll be ok then kill a family just cause you feel that you should drive. It's actually something jersey does right <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+008A>
author: Danielle D'Orto Green Lily

label: positive
message: I was always told by my doc that i won't be able to drive
author: Penny Gatica

label: positive
message:
i have a group called The Games my Brain plays about living with this disorder, epilepsy and aspergers. Please join and please visit the website of the same name. Any suggestions, commentary welcome. I do not have children, so the topics are generally work, adult focused, job-related,getting family to get a clue (!), etc.
Unlike ·
author: Gerene Keesler

label: negative
message:
Im Virginia...Due To Epilepsy...Lost My License 2 years ago!!  You Are Treated Like A Judicial System Criminal.
This Lifestyle Certainly Has Changed Me Forever.
Prayers For All In Epilepsy...Its Not What I Went To School For, Or My Lifelong Career<U+2661>
author: Cathy C Sandford

label: neutral
message: I have never been able/allowed to drive in my life.
author: Lupe Farran

label: positive
message: I changed my profile picture to show you what can happen if you drive with epilepsy. This accident will ultimately make me an amputee.
author: Kathryn Hardaway

label: neutral
message: Yes  u have to be 1 year  free. Before u drive
author: Chasity Raedon Travis

label: neutral
message: My doctor knows I don't drive.   He knows I'm not able to do much of anything.
author: Pamela Rowlett

label: negative
message: It's not required to report in TN either, however, 3 months sz free is the law. I keep my license and just don't drive. I only use them for ID, otherwise, around here, even though I'm disabled, people would just treat me as though I were a convicted DUI offender... No way! I'll keep my license, thank you very much!
author: Pamela Rowlett

label: neutral
message: Doctors everywhere will it doesn't matter the state.
author: Robin Stoddard Sivertsen

label: neutral
message: This is unethical. The only thing doctors should report are dangerous contagious viruses that can wipe out a lot of people, and signs of traumatic child abuse.
author: Sara Dawn Randazzo

label: neutral
message: I've been in Colorado, California and Illinois. California is required to report. Colorado and Illinois are not required to report but the doctor will if they think you are going to drive.
author: Christy M Miller

label: neutral
message: I lie so I can keep driving. If I were on welfare, I'd be bashed for that since I'm a seemingly healthy 36 y.o. Male.
author: Michael Ross

label: negative
message: I have a mild disorder and my neurologist was cool about it. She didn't report me she covered her ass and told me about not driving for a set time after a seizure and all that stuff. She probably figured I'm a grown man, she told me and now it's on me
author: Lenard Lewis II

label: negative
message: This information is not correct; FLA must be notified as well and there is 12month requirement seizure free accompanied by DR approval. EDUCATION PEOPLE, damn it doesn't take that much to educate yourself on the law. Not to mention how would you feel if you decide to drive and have a seizure and KILL someone else's entire family.
author: Aireana Hylton

label: neutral
message: Fl doesnt require it, but some neuro do it out here, and some don't. I do have my liscense but its only for id purposes, its nvr used, cause I cant drive or work.
author: Athena Ramirez

label: positive
message: @John Riley & Trisha Ramsey (And other readers)- Seizures are definitely a tricky and unknown topic. A lot of exploration is needed. I commented earlier about being 27 and only a few years ago being diagnosed as being epileptic. As it turns out I have been having them my entire life. It never really scared me until my husband and I were blessed with a baby girl in December 2012. I had surgery in hopes of helping the seizures but to no avail. We have another baby girl on the way and still I do not worry about the seizures harming me since I have been having them for so long but really I worry about other people, my husband and children. Some people don't understand this but it makes sense to me.
author: Carissa Armstrong

label: neutral
message: My neurologist wasnt required to report it (florida)
author: Melissa Smith

label: negative
message: My husband was having confusion moments for 9 months before he told me about them.  We got in to see a neurologiest, she put him on anti sesure meds but that one made him so depressed, for about a year.  He finally got taken off that and had an MRI and they found his hipocampus was enlarged on one side possibly casing the episodes.  He was given the option of not going on another medication cut,  but, if he had a driving accident he would lose his license for 3 months at least.  Let alone the guilt if it caused someone else injury.  For his and my peace of mind, he stated on another medication and this one seems to be agreeing with him so far.
author: Janice Dodge

label: neutral
message: I live in Illinois and one doctor didn't report me but when I switched doctors he did....I'm off work for 6 months cause I have to drive at my work and they won't let me until the 6 months r over!!
author: Janice Engesser Nylin

label: negative
message: I'm in Ohio and my neurologist was required to report me however he is also licensed in pa so maybe that's why
author: Mariahvidamoondancer Stamm

label: negative
message: I think all 50 stays should.   I have heard sprouts of people driving because it's not reported.  It is entitling selfish of seizures aren't controlled to keep driving.  Anyone who thinks their provide of driving is more important then the life of someone they might kill is foolish.
author: Kelly Porter

label: negative
message: Not only is it embarrassing but it's also frustrating. Sometimes people forget that I have epilepsy and get mad when I can't remember sometimes...it happens, I can't help it!
author: Lisa Corpus

label: negative
message: I am new to the epilepsy world. I had my first seizure (complex partial ) in June 2014. I am currently on 3 medications and I am still having seizures often. I am glad to know that the memory issue is common. I really thought the dr had misdiagnosed me and I had the beginning stages of Alzheimer'. While this epilepsy thing is so crazy and I hate it, I have to say, I am thankful. I know things could be so much worse. I can get up everyday and put two feet on the floor. I wanted to wish everyone  a good day and let's hope we all have a seizure free day.
author: Erin Mateer Goulet

label: neutral
message: Short term memory issues, and yes it sucks!
author: Thomas O. Moudy Jr.

label: negative
message:
I was recently diagnosed
About 9 months ago. I had been having seizures since I was 15 (16 years ago) I have mild seizures with the feeling of déjà vu, and neausous and super tired after . Couldn't drive for 6 months. Meds made me tired at first but now it seems to be ok, mild memory loss. It some days is exhausting. I also have 4 little kids. Prayers
author: Michelle Lee Castillo

label: negative
message: Great job Chris! Memory is definitely a challenging journey  when dealing with epilepsy. I think having a pen and paper, notes apps on a cell phone, reminder alarms and having cognitive therapy are all great tools to help combat such a challenge. It's hard and extra work but so worth it!!
author: Lakeisha Parnell

label: negative
message: My seizures started when I was 25 or so. I can't remember most of my childhood and have problems remembering things now as well. I can write down some things like to remember to get milk or pay a bill, but losing important memories is what really bothers me.
author: Christy M Miller

label: positive
message: we all can relate and I wish you all a smile and a positive attitude with this.  Life, make it a happy one and just focus on you and forget what ppl think or say.  I can relate though it happens to me, however if the other person has a problem with it, then they have to deal with it.  I just excuse myself and explain that's all I can do and move forward.
author: Linda Fuentes

label: negative
message: ive had epilepsy since i was 18 months old and it sux ill b in the middle of a conversation goin good then i stop and have to ask what we were just talkin about i really hate it
author: Laurie King

label: negative
message:
What about short term memory loss? I use to have great memory. My daughters couldn't pass anything on me because if they told me, I'd remember. We'd go to parties and people would challenge me to remember their names. 
Now somebody can tell me something and I turn around and can't remember. I'd blame it on medication, but not sure. 
It's not severe memory loss. I just have to be embarrassed and re-ask and then all is good.
author: Lynn Makelke-Baker

label: negative
message: had brain surgery and haven't had a seizure since so it doesn't affect me anymore
author: Canary LeBlanc

label: negative
message: yup have had tonic clinic seizures since I was 17 and I am 56 now. memory is terrible. have had 2 brain surgeries . my doctor put me on permanent disability. i've worked for forty yrs. sucks
author: Ellie McCarthy Weaver

label: negative
message: Jobs. No one wants to hire me
author: Amanda Hubbard

label: positive
message:
I Call It..."Battle With The Brain"
I Use To Try And Hide It (Epilepsy)...
It Is Embarrassing!!!
With Epilepsy...Family, and People Treat You Differently!
Thank You For The Inspiring Video, It's Great To Know We're Not Alone.
author: Cathy C Sandford

label: negative
message: Me too chris! Me too! And journaling i have found has been very helpful for me also!
author: Bradi Stallings

label: positive
message: I've had seizures for about 2 Years now due to a very large meningioma tumor. It is so very frustrating to experience this memory loss because I used to have such a great memory. I enjoyed watching this video. It helps to know I'm not the only one going through this.
author: Tara Carty Kilgore

label: positive
message: Tony Herzog, Alysa Herzog very informative article.  I've learned a lot from this site. Sign up
author: Pam Herzog

label: positive
message: So frustrating :( I was diagnosed last feb .. And have a very tough time with short term memory .. Very frustrating ! Try to stay positive but some days very difficult ..
author: Denise Gideon

label: neutral
message: Makes sense Orah.  Thanks for sharing,
author: Becky Condello

label: negative
message: I too have had epilepsy for many years..i was 7 when i was diagnosed.I am 51 now I am a nursing student who has a really REALLY hard time with memory during stress times..like exams!!This is my 3rd time trying to get my licence,i managed to get through most of my classroom work the first time,the second time i did 3 months of classroom work and 3 stages.now i have to wait til October 2015 to do the last stages.It is a long process but that is how I need to do it to pass!!And I too have memory problems with names..helps to write it down!!
author: Judy Golden

label: negative
message: Im fairly new to epilepsy I was diagnosed in October don't know if I can go back to work yet all I know is that I can't drive till I'm six months seizure free I'm on three meds and still having seizures don't know what to do I've had memory loss and alot of sore arms legs my jaw and my chest area on my right side what could it be?
author: Valo Bam

label: negative
message: I no longer have "short-term memory" as a result of my brain surgery. I stopped being embarrassed from my epilepsy, years ago. I have learned to live with my condition - I write things down often. Epilepsy isn't easy, it's a tremendous challenge and very frustrating, but get over any embarrassment.
author: Edward Crane

label: negative
message: Its horrible!! I got demoted $2 an hour@wrk because my boss says I'm not giving a100%. I've gotten to where I just pretend that I remember and make detailed notes, but that only gets you so far. Pisses me off...thats the only way to describe it for me!!
author: Stephanie Clark

label: negative
message: I started having seizures about 12 years ago. On this last Christmas, I had 3 complex partials. First time I have ever had 3 in one day. Since then I haven't recognized places. I was at my sister's last week, and didn't recognize anything in her backyard as being there before, such as the boat, the patio, the double grill. On the way to the dr today, that I've had for 11 of the 12 years, I didn't recognize much of anything. If anyone had taken me other than my brother, who usually takes me,  I would have told them they had taken a wrong turn somewhere.  I go there about every 4-6 months. Not good!!!
author: Tracy Howell Copella Hanson

label: positive
message: Becky Condello what we were talking about today ...
author: Orah Stanish

label: negative
message: People that makes fun of people like you guys should have it see how. They relate to it.You have to live one day at a time be patience with your selfs.people are very mean
author: Pat Greenlaw

label: negative
message: Ive had seizures since i was 2 mon old too. And btwn my seizures and my meds i went from having a very active mind to being empty in my head. Im dazed most days, like many of you i dont remember my own childhood. Most days i dont even remember my age let alone my kids date of birth. Its embarrassing to have to ask for help for ur own date of birth or stop because youve confused ur birthdate num w ur social or phone numbers. Im right there with you
author: Athena Ramirez

label: negative

label: negative
message:
I will post this again and again to hopefully get this out to everyone. 
I was Diagnosed when I was 18yrs just like my mom. Grand-mal seizures and diagnosed as genetic. Here is what I have noticed with myself and wonder if this can help anyone else that may be born with this disease naturally. I am 36 now and must had a baby a year ago.
Here are some factors or things I have noticed. 
1. Hormonally related. Around my period cycle I get (what I call) seizure activity. My mother told me the doctors show on bt had a big debate about new talk about hormones. For me, this is a connection 100%.  I went on birth control (nuvaring since they don't have to up the dose of estrogen in that one). And I felt better!!! Being pregnant I had never felt better in my life and this includes of days of NO SLEEP which normally is a huge trigger for me! 
2. STRESS AND SLEEP is always a factor and always will be. I do my best to control and stay happy with Activities I enjoy, relaxing a lot and making sure I get plenty of sleep. 
3. DIET! CARBS!!!! Carbs are always told its a NO NO bc it makes you fat. WRONG. Your brain cannot function properly without carbs. Anabolic is the term used when your body is starved of these. Don't forget your brain needs these! Make sure your morning has them and keep them consistent through your daily meals!  I have felt seizure activity when I am low. Fast metabolism ppl really need to be careful. 
4. You all know alcohol is a bad idea. It's when the brain comes down from the buzz that you "detox" from the substance and that's when  you are seizure prone. 
Please feel free to contact me for more information on remedies you can do yourself to help. I won't clog up this post with a book lol. I hope this has helped anymore. God bless and stay safe everyone!!
author: Jessica Pettengill

label: neutral

label: negative

author: Lindsay Marie Della Ratta

label: negative
message:
I had petimals as a young a child. I started swimming and I outgrew it. 
It 2002, started having grandmals. In 2009, I started running and doing marathons and triathlons. 
When I run, I get to enjoy the outdoors and what's around me. When I do triathlons, I find myself more alert and quicker thinking. When I do training or events, I'm free of stress and fo
My Neurologist supports me as they are finding that exercise does help the brain. I even had a seizure after mistakingly seeing a 3D movie. I came out of it quicker than normal and wasn't exhausted at all like I normally do.
author: Lynn Makelke-Baker

label: negative
message: Jogging is one of the best things ive done to help control my stress and my seizures.. i cant jog on busy streets because of the sound and movements of traffic but on trails in the woods its so helpful..

It truly breaks my heart because she cries when sees over it. It sucks cause I can't even do anything to stop I it. I just hold her till she stops and then I fight back my tears cause I have to be the strong one.  She has three type of seizures clonic, tonic & partial. And the one she has is from PSTD. She's really19 now. Just saying.
author: Vicki Wilson

label: negative
message: During a simple partial seizure,  I would just have an aura. That was it. During a complex partial seizure,  I would have the usual aura followed by automatisms (uncontrollable automatic behavior), which I would have no memory of. There was almost always a strong feeling of the need to escape with a complex partial seizure. One time I was in a college class and had a seizure. Afterwards, I was told that I started making hiccup-like noises, got up, walked around the classroom, out the back door, walked around the building, and back into the main lobby where I sat down and recovered from the seizure. I freaked out some people that day. I had a complex partial seizure while riding in a car one time. I opened the car door and tried to get out at an intersection. Scary stuff.
author: Tristin Seagraves Johnson

I have almost died numerous times because of this. I have always thought I was alone with my situation. Doctors say I have a very unusual case because the causes I have to trigger them. I'm in the hospital every month and the last one scarf me really bad cause I cracked my skull open and was alone for hours. My kid found me unconscious and was very scared.there's so much I would love to say to get the help and support with my condition. I hope one day I can go without having them.

label: negative
message:
I will post this again and again to hopefully get this out to everyone. 
I was Diagnosed when I was 18yrs just like my mom. Grand-mal seizures and diagnosed as genetic. Here is what I have noticed with myself and wonder if this can help anyone else that may be born with this disease naturally. I am 36 now and must had a baby a year ago.
Here are some factors or things I have noticed. 
1. Hormonally related. Around my period cycle I get (what I call) seizure activity. My mother told me the doctors show on bt had a big debate about new talk about hormones. For me, this is a connection 100%.  I went on birth control (nuvaring since they don't have to up the dose of estrogen in that one). And I felt better!!! Being pregnant I had never felt better in my life and this includes of days of NO SLEEP which normally is a huge trigger for me! 
2. STRESS AND SLEEP is always a factor and always will be. I do my best to control and stay happy with Activities I enjoy, relaxing a lot and making sure I get plenty of sleep. 
3. DIET! CARBS!!!! Carbs are always told its a NO NO bc it makes you fat. WRONG. Your brain cannot function properly without carbs. Anabolic is the term used when your body is starved of these. Don't forget your brain needs these! Make sure your morning has them and keep them consistent through your daily meals!  I have felt seizure activity when I am low. Fast metabolism ppl really need to be careful. 
4. You all know alcohol is a bad idea. It's when the brain comes down from the buzz that you "detox" from the substance and that's when  you are seizure prone. 
Please feel free to contact me for more information on remedies you can do yourself to help. I won't clog up this post with a book lol. I hope this has helped anymore. God bless and stay safe everyone!!
author: Jessica Pettengill

label: negative
message: I was experiencing the De ja vu syndrome before I was diagnosed with a brain aneurysm my Dr at the time told me it was anxiety attacks it took her a few more months before sending me for a cat scan unfortunately my aneurysm ruptured and I ended up having to go in a medically induced coma to releive the pressure I woke up two months later and couldn't walk for two years   lost my job, car, everything finally just started walking again and my Dr is tapering me off my anti seizure meds as I have been seizure free for two years :-) new Dr also BTW new insurance as well
author: Lynn Helmn

label: negative
message: Ive had seizures all my life, and id have to disagree active pos is just as hard to live with as if u were having active tonic clonic. Luckily my tonic clonic is controlled but my pos and absense are not. I get lost wen standin in my own house, my memory is gone from one point to another, the headaches to migraines omg. I cant focus on but 1 thing at a time. Then of course theres the mood swings.
author: Athena Ramirez

label: negative
message: My partial seizures start as deja vu. Then I smell something in the air.  I lay down and have to close my eyes.  I can but talk while having the seizure.  I have a swallowing reflex because I feel nausea as if I will throw up.  Finally I have a thought in my head.  It's always the same thought however I can not remember the thought.  I'm also disoriented and tired afterwards.
author: Rachel Savage Gross

label: negative
message: I know when my first seizure was 25 years ago. It was that day at work when I had that sudden feeling of deja-vu. For some of us with epilepsy, that's not a good feeling.
author: Mark Allison

label: neutral
message: It is so frustrating to live with these. Nobody can understand what we go through.
author: Lisa Butts Parrotte

label: negative
message: I have had seizures that I go into convulsions, but I also get  auras. When I get them I can loose control of my bladder. Also when the temperature changes from going into a cold room to a hot room and vice versa. I also get my auras around the time of the month.
author: Lindsay Marie Della Ratta

label: negative
message: Does anyone get a ring in your ear or getting muffled hearing like you are under water but can talk and are fully aware of what is going on?
author: Lisa Schultz

label: negative
message:
POS are surely easier to live with than generalized tonic clonic, but I find there's also less understanding from both doctors and peers. People hear seizure and have an idea what that looks like. POS don't fit that mold and are are often dismissed. Mine wouldn't respond to activation and a doctor wrote them off as PNES for the sake of a research thesis. 

After 6 years of POS I think the worst part for me is the doubt. So many doctors initially said it was psychiatric thst I actually doubted what was happening. Even with a diagnosis, there's still that lingering doubt.
author: John VanHez

label: negative
message: I suffer from these as well and I had a VNS put in back in 2013.  My seizures have reduced a lot but they will never be controlled by medication.  My deja-vus normally last for 15-20 seconds but this past Sunday I experienced one for 2 and a half hours... I knew what everyone was going to say before they said it.  It was a very weird feeling.  Has anyone ever experienced that long of a deja-vie?  Thanks in advance!!!
author: Krystle Thrasher

label: neutral
message: I used to have those when I was younger...especially the de'ja vu thing... it was just WEIRD!
author: April Almeida

label: negative
message: I'm 20 now, and I've had POS since I was 9. I would always get a deja-vu feeling sometimes before, sometimes after my seizures, but they were always there. My seizures have been under control for about a year now, but multiple times a day, I feel like I'm starting to get that deja-vu feeling again. It kind of rises up as a feeling in my throat, but doesn't come all the way. It's like my body's teasing me. I'm nervous that my body may getting used to my medications again and that might be what's causing it, but I don't know. I hope not; I've been on tons of different meds already and have already considered surgery. (Was only put off because my seizures were better controlled). I've caught myself spacing out too. I'm still aware of everything around me, but I just have this urge to stare and I'll do it for what feels like 5 minutes. I tried asking the neuro about it, but I didn't get any answers. She didn't seem concerned when I told her. Should I be concerned?
author: Jennifer McDonald

label: negative
message: I've had partial onset seizures all my life. Didn't know what it was so I never told anyone till after I was diagnosed with epilepsy at 17 when I started having petite mal seizures. Even then I didn't believe they were partial onset seizures I thought they were anxiety attacks but my doctor said because of the deja vu it sounded more like a partial onset seizure. Mind if I ask a question? Has anyone ever felt an intense feeling of doom and fear during a partial onset seizure or know of someone who has? I have a bunch of crazy symptoms during one but I don't think I've ever heard of anyone else having these two symptoms as well.
author: Sarah Hahn

label: negative
message:
a couple yrs ago a friend found me in the middle of a field ....sweeping the grass with a kitchen broom.... in the rain.... thinking that was right where i belonged and what i was supposed to be doing.... i never have just one... so can be in status for hrs or even days... sometimes that means hallucinations ... sometimes that means blackouts.... they do occasionally generalize into convulsive seizures... those i will have in nasty clusters as well... as for the hallucinations...    
i have often had hallucinations of all 5 senses at once.....some times they hit in stages...almost like stacking upon one another..... tastes...smells....feelings....sounds....and finally the visions.......
and at times it will only be one or two senses....any combination is possible...

they come when they want...usually with little in the way of warning....

i hear voices as well...
always a womans voice.... 
sometimes singing...
sometime chanting....
but always repeating.....
a phrase...
or a few words....
always something of great meaning....always something i have always known but have a hard time remembering when i am not there......sometimes i will hear a cupple words together...someone saying them...irl or on tv/radio......
and the rest of the world fades back...becomes detached....and those cupple words just repeat....
first in the voice i heard them in ...then in her voice....
then as the vibrations rise in each and every cell...
the music comes....music i can feel as much as hear
 the taste comes...
and all the world turns red......
everything closes in from behind like a head rush gone bad......
blackness swarming and alive with stars closes in around me....
finally even this tears open ...and for just a moment...i am offered a look ...a peek ...into the place the music comes from
and then i am back here.....they always abandon me back to this world ....again and again......
what i wouldnt give to stay there!!!!!!!     - i could go on and on...how much you want to hear?
author: Lewis Short

label: positive
message: They are a form of seizure and should be guided like most even if its not a grand mal.It can become very bad also! I have had this since 1983!
author: Angelina Vilchez

label: negative
message: My husband experienced deja vu for a long time before the seizures started. He would also get goosebumps and feelings of impending doom. I thought he was having panic attacks. Now those same symptoms are preludes to seizures.
author: April Sykes

label: negative
message: I had deja-vu all my life, it was very strange, it was like I had been there before in a dream.  I really noticed can them when I was 5 years old.  I would be walking or playing and a situation would catch me, a buzzing feeling would start followed by this intense feeling like I hand been here before in some prior life, then a metallic tasting would fill my mouth, I break out into a sweat and sometimes it would over power me to ware  I could function and sometimes I could function through them.  As I aged I was able to control myself during the event.  I was a poor performer in school, some areas I did well such as history.  College I failed, and could not understand way I could remember or spell well.  I had a grand mal seizure 3 years ago while asleep, scaring my wife to death.  I had always complained about these events and she always told me to see a doctor about, I should have listened.
author: Kevin Landrum

label: negative
message: I've felt sick almost my whole life. Started grand mal seizures in sleep at 4 have had a few years i remember no seizures,  just feel weird most of the time. Spacey,  tingly, sometime it looks like i couldn't feel my legs if i touched them and the air looks and feels thick with bright black spots and tiny squiggly lines.
author: Michelle Brown

label: negative
message: I'm 37 with partial seizures since my stroke at age 28 then another at 29. They are not under control right now. I can't drive and the meds either aren't enough or make me an emotional wreck. Typically I find that the left back side of my head and neck hurt. I'm moody, and in a lot of pain through out the left side of my body which is already affected from the strokes. For a long time I've dismissed the pain thinking it was just something from the strokes. Now I wonder how many seizures I've had over the last 8 years that's have gone undetected. The last one I had a couple weeks ago I almost passed out was anxious and thought I was gonna throw up. Thankfully I was able to sit down and my husband was home.
author: Layla Marie Coady

label: neutral
message: I always have a sense of impending doom before having siezures. That is my cue to stay close to the floor.
author: Kristine Boyd

label: negative
message: I get migraines when I know something wants to happen or I start biting my lower lip softly like some type of nerve issue there. I can say I get a lot of dejavu but mostly I start starring and I do catch myself doing it! Hallucinations are more likely I should say!!
author: Laronda Prado

label: negative
message: I was diagnosed with epilepsy whn i was three months old. it has been a constant struggle bettwen POS and grand mal and surviving. My seizures leave with one or two feelings. I dont know who i am for that moment or i feel empty.
author: Cierra Smith

label: negative
message: It is a creepy feeling and it's also in the chest for me, because my heart rate speeds up.
author: Stephanie Writes

label: negative
message: My worst was when I had the flu for a week and couldn't keep anything down so I missed my meds for a few days. One morning I didn't show up for work so they called me to ask where I was and they said that I told them I'd be there shortly but have no memory of it. They called my hubby & mom who found me unconscious with no memory of anything. When they took me to the er I couldn't even speak. They kept saying that I tried to kill myself by overdosing. They did a cat scan several hrs later & found nothing.
author: Angie Holsinger

label: negative
message: This is happening to my Daughter for many years, she feels tingling & pain in her knee then falls, moans, her arms extend,  &'hands curl...she can hear but can't answer...she cries after the episode. She has had a small brain bleed from a fall & now wears a helmet...also, she has fallen so much she has cervical spine problems...the doctors say it's it's behavioral, but I know it's not...She falls a few times a day. She really needs help! I have taken her to many, many neurologists, still can't find answers. She is on meds that control her partial tonic seizure disorder. She is 40 yrs old & is mildly mentally challenged.
author: Diane Rizzo-Lentini

label: neutral
message: I cant remember most of things after I have seizures.....
author: Mariana Andaló Rocha

label: negative
message: Yes i have partial seizures witch is called flickers most of them are comeing from my tunnel vision when the pressure goes up an the lights in the house get real bright
author: Max Taunton

label: negative
message: Walking around routinely like an elderly person, especially when crossing the street. U r lethargic,when this happens.
author: Susan Williams

label: negative
message: My son is 12 and he get disoriented and he spaces out for a period of time going from 3 to 5 minutes. The seizures have affected his memory and speech and balance he been having them since two.
author: Katie Pagan

label: positive
message: I live in a constant state of dejavu and bad headaches. Bad memory, sleepiness.
author: Rachel Thompson

label: neutral
message: I had my first seizure 14 years ago when I was 15
author: Lindsay Marie Della Ratta

label: negative
message: I'm alert but I am in convulsions. Sometimes they can last all night and they can get bad. When I say bad I mean I can loose control of bodily fluids and I feel tingling on the whole right side of my body.
author: Linda Fuller Snyder

label: neutral
message: These sound a lot of what I'm going through since having the vns put in
author: Micheala Faulkenburg

label: negative
message: The deja vu, the brother and sister arguing,  the hot metal smell, the loss of speech, the feeling my brain is being squeezed, and then it goes into tonic clonic. One time I came to and found out I had pooped all over the house. I always lose peristalsis, and this is very painful, and a long process to rebuild. The pos is never controlled. I take 25 meds.
author: Nancy Clark

label: negative
message: Sometimes my fingertips are so tingly it feels like they will pop ? Is that from my seizures?
author: Michelle Brown

label: positive
message: Is it possible to have the partial onset seizures in more than one lobe?
author: Tara Carty Kilgore

label: neutral
message: mine is the temporal lobe also
author: Dianne Eddy

label: neutral
message: I have these kind my Dr. says these r one of the hardest to control
author: Amanda Russell

label: neutral
message: Check this out Sheila West,  Sylvia West,  and Josh West Llopis..
author: Linda West

label: positive
message: When I have Seizures the best i could describe is like the humming and buzzing from a vibrator being put directly on your bone.  Only you have to magnafy that feeling to a thousand times more.  On top of that, it feels like there's a Monster inside of you trying to get out and you can't fight it.  No tingling tho.  Just thought others might relate to this also. God Bless
author: Chris Bridges

label: positive
message: Toyota has a safety package where the car senses if it's going to run into something and automatically brakes. Had a bad reaction to a new med and seized while driving. Ran into light pole, but because car slowed on its own, I wasn't hurt.
author: Sally Willis-Watkins

label: negative
message: Im only seizure free a month and definitely not driving..its very hard losing that independence!! God willing one day I'll be able to drive and feel safe doing it but the thought of hurting someone if I ever have a seizure while driving terrifies me even if I'm 3 yrs seizure free. Time will tell I guess...I thank God I have a husband that has been so very supportive, I honestly dont know what I'd do without him :-)
author: Stephanie Clark

label: neutral
message: My biggest fear...especially with my kids in the car!
author: Nicole Formica-Kieffer

label: neutral
message: I will be seizure-free for three years after five years of having one every month or two. My doctor said that I'll be considered to be in "remission" and I can start to taper off my anticonvulsants but that will never happen. I'll take them until I die if it means that I'm less likely to seize.
author: Kari Kuntz

label: neutral
message: I lost my husband 07-10-2013, he had a seizure while driving.
author: Amanda Baggarly Pfeil

label: negative
message: Hubby was having "monents" for 9 months before he told me about them.  When he finally did, we got into see his PCP who set him up with a neurologist right away.  These "moments" stopped three days before we saw her, but he started on medication for the next 10 months, which depressed him horribly,  so when fall hit and he wasn't getting outside as much the depression got worse, he told his PCP that he had feelings of not wanting to live if this is how he was going to feel. So we saw his neurologist three months before the year was up being on that med, she weaned him off of it before we saw her. He was not having any of those "moments" at all since taking the meds, but without them, or some meds, there was always the chance of having another, and, perhaps having an accident.  That was enough for him to agree to continue taking some kind of meds for the possiblity.  Before meeting with the neuroologiest hubby did have an MRI which showed that on one side of his hippocampus near the base, there was an enlargement.  He will have another MRI in Feb to see if there is a change.  I asked her point blank if she saw any signs of Alzheimers and she said, not at this time, but if soemthing else, it is a very difficult area to remove something.  You have to be brave to get old, he is only 66.  Thanks for reading this, it helps me to put it in type.
author: Janice Dodge

label: negative
message: even though I have not had a sesizure for a whole year I still know I have to take my meds just in case.
author: Bonnie Boyce

label: positive
message: It's annoying that I can't even drive . But I rather not have seizure and crash.
author: Alyssa Gonzales

label: negative
message: unless i have someone to be there to asist u in your day t day life needs , food , meds , children needs ext ext ext what is one to do not excist hold a sign epileptic please help for get that!! people dont understanding nor care,
author: Brad Mayo

label: positive
message: Driving Driving Drivng ! sounds so like something I would love to do, just get in the car take myself to the court and play a game of raket ball all by myself. Now after a decade of fighting this disease and having the driving privilege taken from me, now over ten years of having 2 brain surgeries and trying over 15 different meds and even being seizure free for 18months,  still these seizures just stop. I offically have to say with having seizures is it really ever to drive?
author: Krysten Michelle

label: negative
message: I crashed a truck into a big open desert while driving home from work. Someone saw it go down fortunately, ran over and did the good citizen thing. He kept asking me how much I drank and I wasn't at the talking point of my seizure yet so it took about 5 minutes for me to gain my composure and explaine to him what was happening to me
author: Derek Roemermann

label: positive
message: the last major one i had I was driveing to an one hit  me an i pulled over an the only thing that remember is wakeing up in the er so that ended my driveing ater my Nuro said i had tunnel vision witch that was what I have
author: Max Taunton

label: negative
message: It's been 4 months without a seizure.. I do drive but if there is someone else that can drive I let them.. It is very scary losing self control..
author: Carie Lynn Lewis

label: neutral
message: I never have gotten an aurora.  I haven't driven since 1969.
author: Richard Witte

label: negative
message: I stopped my meds cuz i felt so clouded on the meds and ill still have seizures anyway but i am not driving currently but i will in the spring.
author: Nici Chereè

label: negative
message: I've had one in the car. Pulled over put it in park and pulled my e-brake got my seatbelt off and turned off the car tilted my seat back and was able to catch the time beforehand.
author: Amanda Dietzler

label: negative
message: I was always told I would never be able to drive because of them. It is hard to be dependent  on  others  to go places.  I would only hope that I could, but I don't  know. I wish I could though. I wish I  could  do a lot more  than I can. It seems the older  I get the more difficult  it gets to get around.
author: Nicki Kinder

label: neutral
message: Important Question: if a child with Epilepsy says there tongue is "burning" cud this b a type of seizure. Sometimes afterwards she gets tired and wants to sleep. We have had allergy testing done, as we though maybe food allergies. But I'm wondering if maybe it's a "metal" taste (aura??) She's getting.
author: Tracy Holum

label: neutral
message: This is very true I have been epileptic for 32 years. I have epilepsy but it doesn't have me.
author: Ralph Miller

label: neutral
message: Dec. 22nd will mark my 37th year since I've had a gran mal seizure! May I NEVER have any more of those!
author: Dennis Carlson

label: negative
message: Thank you for educating on this there are many people who are not aware of someone who might be having a partial onset. More education is needed to help all the people who suffer from all forms of epilepsy.
author: Maclain Jobe

label: neutral
message: yes they are call partial onset seizures, BUT what they SHOULD be called is POS, piece of sh## , I have them and they are hard to live with
author: Gail Graefe

label: negative
message: I have both I was able to get my grand mals under control its the partial I have a problem with have them every day
author: Mandy Boyer

label: negative
message: I have epilepsy but when I got my EKG done the dr said he couldn't see what was triggering them. I had to wear a monitor on my head for 3 days and 4 nights. And still can't figure out what my brain waves are like he says I have a shock in between ever 4-5 min. But I don't feel any different I have been seizure free since I got pregnant back in summer of 2013 almost a year now. Although I do get triggers of one coming on I try not to panic
author: Ari Barrera

label: negative
message: It seems like the pos seizures are the hardest to control :(
author: Malissa Sapienza Emerick

label: negative
message: I suffer from both. Its tough finding a medicine that controls both, so I need more meds. Just ugh
author: Rebecca Fernandez

label: positive
message: These graphics are great! Keep up the good work!
author: Epilepsy Foundation Eastern PA

label: negative
message: Thanks for clearing that up for me, I also have no memory that anything has happened , after having a partial onset .I have cut myself of  any contact with anyone , I live alone with no friends, no partner , and no family.
author: Bonnie Dunbar

label: positive
message: i have a POS then a Tonic-Clonic. It is the worst. I pray for us all a cure.
author: Kellie Renee

label: positive
message: My daughter is suspected of having these types of seizures.  At times they do progress to her losing consciousness and then she does have some convulsions but the convulsions aren't as severe as a grand mal seizure (involves only her head, neck, shoulders, upper body not arms and legs).  They only happen when she is active not at rest so we have not been able to capture them on an EEG.  We are being offered either a medication trial or more EEG testing in the hospital.  I don't think she will have one in the hospital since they make her lay still, but I'm nervous about giving medication without a confirmed diagnosis.
author: Angela Braford Tuell

label: negative
message: I find this a little odd considering I think I have both. I JUST came out of a seizure that I didn't remember and one I heard things and thrashing around and one i don't remember I just know I'm very tired and my husband knows what truly happened.
author: Whit Hebert

label: positive
message: Before me seizures were controlled through meds, this happened to me. It took neurologists 15 years to find the right combo of meds that worked.
author: Susan Williams

label: negative
message: It could be ask the Dr. about that they should be able to tell you.
author: Ralph Miller

label: negative
message: For years I had both but as I got older I grew out of the partial siezures. Still have grand-mals.
author: Noah Smith

label: negative
message: I have had epilepsy since I was 2 months old and I'm 34 now and I have experience both grand and petite mild seizures and is caused by a scar on the left side of my brain and are very hard to control at times
author: Katherine Dalton

label: neutral
message: I take meds every day any thankfully haven't had a seizure in probably five years.
author: Ralph Miller

label: neutral
message: I been dealing with granmal and petite seizures sense I was 11 and I'm 24 now
author: Toby Gabriel

label: positive
message: I been living with seizures sense I was 11 and i had to use the paddles on me because my hart stopped but thankfully I'm still hear today. Because I have such bad seizures I can't drive or do a lot of things a regular person could do
author: Toby Gabriel

label: negative
message: i have granmal seizure ive been having fhem since 2007 doctors got them controled with meds but no help from government yet i still dont know why im having them because i never had them as a child just started having them
author: Valencia Olds

label: negative
message: I have complete partial and grand mal seizures. I'm 53. My seizures started at 3 years old. My memory is not good. In addition, I have high blood pressure and arthritis . My seizures are pretty much controlled by meds. However, my drivers license was taken and told I need to be seizure free for 2 years. If I'm seizure free till August, I could get my license.  I seem to not get help with confirming my memory problems. Neurologist tells me it could blood pressure or depression. I have psychological test that indicates memory problems. I don't know what else to do to move forward.
author: Carol Brown

label: neutral
message: My son was hit by a car in 2007. A year later, the partial-onset started. It progressed to tonic-clonic. The doctor has run all sorts of tests, but can't find the cause of the seizures.
author: Vanessa Irby

label: positive
message: I have Epilepsy.  I have Grand Maul ones usually 1 a month.  Sometimes if I have a lot of small shaking spells that's when I'm going to have a big one.
author: Mindy Putt

label: negative
message: I go online and see what's new about epilepsy every once in a while.  Was just reading about this a week or so ago.
author: Nancy Anderson

label: negative
message: I had these all my life and did not know what it was, until I had a grand mal 3 years ago.  I have been seizure free, but the side effects of the drugs are worse than the seizures.  I know I sound crazy, but it is true.
author: Kevin Landrum

label: negative
message: I had so many different kinds. What happens with partial onset ones?
author: Bonnie Boyce

label: negative
message: I am so glad that I shared this. I thought I was going crazy. Now I know that everything that's wrong with me is from the seizures.
author: Kathy Fowler

label: positive
message: I find it very difficult to describe my own seizure activity to my doctor. Considering  that seizures that generalize include lapses in memory even I don't fully know what happened to me. Imagine the frustration the doctor must have trying to piece that together. The biggest clue to me is if a doctor pretends  to know everything it is time to find another one because no one does. This is  a very very complex field and the answer " we don't really know for sure" is an acceptable one!
author: David Winn

label: neutral
message: It's funny, I learn more from these post then the dr appts.
author: Tisha Asbury Combs

label: negative
message: I experienced partial seizures since I can remember I always felt it was a supressed memory caused by depression because of my "background" I literally always felt I was just crazy...I mean I felt crazy trying to explain that deja vu feeling. I had my first tonic clonic seizure at 22 and the second neurologist I visited confirmed I    had always had partial seizures.
author: Lana Ayla Smith

label: positive
message: Hang in there and don't stop in believing. My mother gave me her 110% determination and motivation. 20+ years after my surgery I now only have partial seizures. Ive been happily married for 21 years and I look at what I have now and love my mom more every day. I hope for the very best for you and your family.
author: Brian Cox

label: neutral
message: I give God all the praise honor and glory he healed me 20yrs ago from grand mall seizures
author: Alicia Espat Jones

label: negative
message: This is so true, and I hate admitting that my Partial-Onset Seizures sometimes turned into tonic-clonic.
author: Mark Allison

label: negative
message: I was always told my daughter had complex partial .. i do not understand anything anymore new doctor i like but.. im so confused!!!
author: Kathy Fowler

label: negative
message: Please support my son Justice
author: Sun Dee

label: negative
message: I'm Brian Cox mother. Twenty years ago when Brian was having so many seizures he couldn't function his doctor just kept changing his medication or increasing it until Brian spent most his time like a zombie. I one day had enough and stormed into the doctors office and can still remember what I said "if you don't know what to do then refer us to someone who does",  I was so angry!  Long story short he referred Brian to hosp in Madison. WI and he's pretty much told you all the rest.  It's really hard on a parent to see their child go through but think how hard it has to be for a child. I'm out. You all have a good day.
author: Lynda Bergman

label: negative
message: I found out that my son had partial seizures the HARD WAY. In February 2014 my son fell to the floor and had a gran mal seizure he wasbadly bruised and I lost my mind!!! I called my boss (that no longer works for the company I used to work at) and reported the situation. He stayed on the phone with the police and medics until my son was rushed to the hospital. I was terminated from my employment the following week. The CEO chalked his diagnosis up to be  "fake".
author: Sun Dee

label: positive
message: Thanks Lynda! My son had surgery in 2009 and was seizure free for 5 1/2 years. This past July, everything has started up again. Tonic clinics are the worst and he had to get a medical withdrawal from college. He is in his 3rd year at school and has been blind sided by all his seizures reoccurring. He is forging ahead as best he can. I am in awe of how he tries so hard.
author: Maureen Wood

label: neutral
message: Danny Wendt, Krystina Wright maybe we can find out more info about Tabori and you krys.
author: Tammie Wendt

label: negative
message: I wish I had gotten an education like this, years ago, but experience took its place, with some bumps along the road.
author: Susan Williams

label: neutral
message: This is solo true, knowledge is the best help.

label: negative
message: We and our loved ones are strong enough to defeat this. I'm so happy when I read about others who didn't let it defeat them.
author: Brian Cox

label: negative
message: My mom has seizures how do I know when to call 911 or when it may not be necessary?
author: Dawn Holley

label: negative
message: After I have one I get extremely tired and I get a headache. For me I go to sleep for a couple of hours and the room has to be dark.

label: positive
message: I pray when I feel one coming on and when it is over I am tired. Prayer always helps me to have peace. God is good. He who keeps me will never sleep nor slumber.

label: neutral
message: My mother has grand mal seizures and a person doesn't know what is happening during seizures it appears they do but they are unaware just be sure that the area he is in is clear and nothing can hurt him also try to remain calm it helps them to be calm afterwards....

label: neutral
message: SLEEP and pain killers after chewing up my own tongue.

label: negative
message: I loose part of my memory of what happened that day.... But a nap always help

label: positive
message: I'm so lathargic after a seizure that I usually stay where I landed and stare into space. I eventually come to, collect myself, and pray I did not break any bones or bust my head open in the process. I'm pretty good about knowing when one is about to happen and alert whoever is closest(usually my mom). Sleeping follows suite in a dark room with silence.

label: neutral
message: Sleep and have my room complete darkness

label: negative
message: The simple partials I really don't need anything special just a few min to reorient myself & maybe a quick drink of water or something. If it's a full blown tonic/clonic then I need some quiet time to rest & something for the killer headache I will then have.

label: positive
message: After I have one it is my time to rest or just be quiet it's like u have a film over you for little while

label: negative

label: positive
message: a short nap usually works   or some rest time

label: neutral

label: neutral
message: It helps me when I sleep I wake up feeling a lil better

label: positive

author: Thomas O. Moudy Jr.

label: neutral
message: Sleep sleep and more sleep.  A 20-piece chicken nugget from McDs helps too ;)

label: negative
message: Time and sleep. Consistency in schedule and meds. Regimented routine and bedtimes, all of which are not consistent with teens!
author: Susan Wilson

label: negative
message: Before my left temporal lobectomy in November 2008, I would have partial and complex partial seizure clusters, one approximately every two hours, sometimes for days. The postictal state of having seizure after seizure was more immobilizing than the seizures themselves.  Seizures were always followed by a migraine headache and a need to sleep, as well as what a doctor called Alice in Wonderland syndrome--the present seemed really dreamy and I always felt really tiny in size after seizures.
author: Tristin Seagraves Johnson

label: negative
message: Usually I help my mom lie down and give her some time. Other times she naps. She gets so confused and just needs time to gather herself.
author: Rella Kalagian

label: negative
message: Sleep & my dog. He hasn't left my side since I had a seizure today:)
author: Peter Wilkes

label: negative
message: Sleep,getting alot of rest
author: DonaldandYolanda Bess

label: negative
message:
When I come out of my grandma seizure it's usually 
 awareness finding out where I am
Then I'm embarrassed
Then I'm angry
So usually I need compassion
Understanding because of my embarrassment
And then don't take it personally because of my anger
My tongue has usually been chewed so I have to have some kind of painkiller
 They say the grand mal seizure is like running a marathon so of course rest sleep is the only way to recoup
 Hydration is Big
But hydration and eating are tough because chilling on the tongue
author: Roger Spence

label: negative
message: I have simple partial seizures and recovery is more than brief for me. I need a nap for a couple hours and am still "off" when I wake up. It takes about 8 hrs for me to normalize.

label: negative
message: Dawn Holley, your neurologist can help you with this. It's usually if the seizure continues for more than 4 minutes but each individual is different. She may have emergency medication that is to be given after so many minutes also!

label: positive
message: was just wondering if there's anything i can do to help him through them or just let him b till its over

message: hi my 12 year old son has autism and is non verbal  and suffers from seizures,was curious while having one does he realize what's happening or is it just a blank? try to calmly talk to him during, but not sure if he can hear me,any insight would b helpful,i just feel so helpless during his seizures thank you!!

label: neutral
message: I think of the help my family friends and eating the wright way too
author: Susan von Stade

label: negative

label: negative
message: what helps me come out of one is havin someone talk 2 me
author: Laurie King

label: negative

author: Jamie Duke Bunton

label: negative
message: Sleep and to bring me out it helps someone to talk to me. I was born with Eplepsy. I was brought off my meds at 14y/o. At 19 with my second child I begin to have seizures again. I was put back on medication. I am now 35 and still on medication due to them becoming worse. I will have to take my medication all my life.
author: Jamie Duke Bunton

label: negative
message: I am diagnosed with seizure disorder. I see a neurologist and he says that when I have my little spells it's anxiety. What I dont understand is when these happen I can see myself shaking in my left side,and feel distant from everything around me. This is usually brougt on by an episode of violent coughing. When these do come I am wakefully seizing and it takes up to about a little more than a minute to come around,when I do I am verry disoriented. I am hoping thatn somone here can help me figure it out
author: Greg Miller

label: negative
message: I can't eat at all but I fall asleep all day. I get plenty of rest while family members monitor me when I sleep to make sure I am OK.
author: Laronda Prado

label: positive
message: Sitting still trying to figure out what happened where I'm at and collect myself then legs feet hands all hurt muscle wise then I have to just rest a while n pray

label: neutral
message: Sleep or at least laying in bed for at least an hour.
author: Michael Ross

label: neutral
message: It depends on the seizure but I usually just pass out for a bit.

label: negative
message: Just talking to myself and finding a focal point. Helps me get a grasp of things then I can start to calm down.
author: Alyssa Olaya Oliveira

label: neutral
message: Cold wash rag,and sit down a few minutes
author: Tammy Floyd

label: negative
message: Sleep and getting sick... always bite my tongue and tht hurts for days after :-\

label: negative

label: positive

label: neutral

label: neutral
message: Knitting helps me recover. Just a simple knit stitch not following a pattern. Keep large needles and simple yarn with me, especially when traveling.

label: negative

label: negative

label: negative
message: I'm 49 and have driven since I was 15, won't risk it now until Dr. is convinced it's safe.  Sucks, takes away my independence and hurts my pride.  That said, I won't take the safety of others in my hands, that would be totally irresponsible <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+009F>

label: negative
message: I live in florida and have had seizures for 10 yrs I was 18 and 6mths pregnant when they began. I now have been seizure free for 18 months and have recieved permission from my doctor and the state to drive.
