label: neutral
message: My first diagnosed seizure I was behind the wheel.  Luckily at a red light and a good Samaritan blocked my car with hers so I didn't drift through the intersection.  Also I was in a stick shift vehicle so when my foot slipped off the clutch it stalled.  I am now controlled with meds so it is safe for me to drive as long as I'm taking my meds properly.
author: Anita Pilson

label: negative
message: Is there also a number for people who become seizure free every year? This month makes 2years seizure free for me as long as I don't miss a dose of medicine for the first time since 2005. I was diagnosed with epilepsy at 9mo old
author: Dan Rodgers

label: negative
message: I have never seen anyone have a seizure so when my baby girl had one..I was freaking out..but now I know whats going on with her..I'm ok with it..I know I have to be strong for her..
author: Sarah Friend

label: negative
message: I'm not really mad that I have it because it can always be way worse. We are way better off than millions of people out there so the way I look at it is why complain about it? I never really let anything get to me and have a positive outlook about every situation because things can always be much worse. I don't even argue with people and that upsets so many people when you dont argue back lol. Its actually kinda funny. If I ever miss a dose of meds I'll call in to work the next day just to be on the safe side because there's always that slight chance. I'm just grateful I don't have the problems many others do. Its not worth complaining about neither is anything in life really because regardless of any situation things can always be much worse
author: Dan Rodgers

label: negative
message: Sarah people freak out really bad. My last one was @ karaoke a few years ago. I usually have 2 or 3 beers when I was to go out but that was through the course of 3 hours. The bartender the next time refused to serve me so I threatened her with a lawsuit lol. But that's off topic anyways. I was just trying to get at is that if you know anyone who has epilepsy that goes to bars and such tell them to take it light on the drinking. I'd also always wait a few hours between drinking and taking my meds so they wouldn't mix. Oh and they called the ambulance for me and I declined service from the ambulance. They told me I had to sign a waiver that in case I died the medic's weren't responsible since they offered me service lol. I still have a copy of that lol
author: Dan Rodgers

label: negative
message: Probably my worst was when I had multiple grand mal seizures and my kidney failed and I shattered my front teeth. I thought I was never going to get better at times like that, the moments of your life when the icu becomes your second home, it's hard to see the bright side of things, but these doctors are miracle workers. Now I'm 9 months seizure free.

label: negative

Just couple cuts nothing big
author: Devan Woodworth

label: negative
message:
Hello, my name is Walter, and I would like people to know that it is possible to overcome. I was diagnosed with epilepsy at the age of 15. I was having seizures at least once a month up till I was 25. I also had three grand mal seizures in that 10 year timespan. In 2005 I had a grand mal seizure that landed me in ICU for three days, and in the hospital for a a total of a week. Because of these seizures and state laws, I was not able to get my license to drive. People were telling me that I needed to get used to the fact that I may not ever be able to drive. But, I kept telling them that I would drive some day. To make an already log story short, In 2006 I finally got my drivers license. Also, I have not had a seizure since 2005, and  am not currently taking medication for it.

I just want people to know that you can overcome. Don’t let anyone tell you cannot do something because you have epilepsy. Epilepsy is something we have, not who we are.
author: Walter Merilic

label: negative
message: Everybody has setbacks in life, but the way we deal with them defines our character and personality. I've noticed that people with Epilepsy as well as other chronic conditions overcome such great adversity, so now I believe there is no seizure, problem, or loss that this community can't bounce back from! Happy Epilepsy Awareness Month and God Bless!
author: Jeffrey Demitrack

label: neutral
message: We can persevere over epilepsy if we have faith in a cure

label: negative

label: negative
message: .If you have epilepsy , don't let it define who you are. You have goals and dreams like anyone  else. Fight for what you believe in. For those  around you  and those who still need to learn about epilepsy, accept the person who has epilepsy  for who they are not what they have, fight for a cure and educate yourself about epilepsy before  making the choice to shut the person out.

OmGoSh!!*

message: My beautiful grandson who is 5 yrs old now, started having seizures at age 3. The last dr said that according to all the test they have done, he should be MR, but he has started kindergarten and is learning more every day. God is so good, and we are praying that the dr that he has been referred to can help him even more. Thank you all for your post, very encouraging .

label: positive
message: I've had Grand mal Seizures sence I was 14 months old, followed by a stroke when I was just 2 years old.I can't have a driver's license eaither but I'm greatful & blessed to be here.the thgood lord keeps me going.put your trust & faith in him & you will be alright.the last time I passed away was in 2009 from having a grand mal seizure, I don't remember anything when I have one.I had short term memory loss for 3 weeks.

label: positive

label: negative
message:
It took a little less than 10 years, but I finally found a system for me! 
I just took the tv out of my bedroom so it's not a temptation to watch late at night or just too much in general. I also wear a night mask over my eyes so I don't wake up to light. If I'm traveling and there's noise outside that's keeping me up I will listen to my "sleep songs" playlist on my iPod (a HUGE lifesaver). A big thing I do now is make my to-do list as I'm getting ready for bed so once I'm in bed my mind is relatively clear then I pray.
Hope someone may find any of these tips helpful! Seizure free for 1 yr & almost a month now! =)
author: Amy Rachelle Walker

label: negative
message: I fall asleep with the tv on but not to loud..Seizure free for 3 months thank God :-) :-)
author: Octavia Lindsay

label: negative
message: Only go to the bedroom for sleeping and your mind knows it's for sleeping. Do tv watching, computer and other things in another room. That way your body and mind associates that room for sleep.

label: negative
message: Sounds crazy but i have a fan in my room to help me fall asleep

label: negative

label: negative
message: My daughter has had seizures since she was four years old. She was stable on meds at age 11.  She went six years without a seizure. Now at age 17, she's having a grand mal one a month around her period. Her meds were increased once again, and now we have to really watch her next month when she's due to start her period for any signs or symptoms of a seizure. Hormones are serious things, especially with an epileptic.

label: negative
message: We must also remember not only 1 in 26 will be effective but some seizures attacks are harmful and even deadly. message: I'm in desperate need of advice. I have been diagnosed with epilepsy and have been disabled from law enforcement since 2008 and I have two daughters currently on meds for epilepsy. My oldest daughter was hired on at Walmart as a cashier in July 2014 with them full aware of her epilepsy. During this time on occasions her memory would come and go in which they were aware. Being as a cashier she had issues with remembering to put cash back in the drawer or be in the middle of getting change for her register and would forget leaving the money on top and without honestly thinking walk away from the register doing other things her job requires. They gave a verbal warning and a written warning and both time she explained she "zones out" at times and forgets. Well instead of moving her to another position in the store they want her to come in tomorrow and fire her for the same thing that happened to take place Saturday night. I don't know what to do. I don't know if there are discrimination things taking place due to her disability. If anyone can help or point me in the right direction I live in Arkansas.  My number is 870 250 0878. Thank you and God bless.

label: positive
message: So glad to hear when others have been without seizures.  Unless someone has had one, or is very close to someone and knows them, they do not understand.  My epilepsy was likely brought on by septic infections during breast cancer surgeries/reconstruction failures.  All to say, breast cancer and all that came is nothing compared to what the seizures (and memory loss) has done.  But with it has come blessings, as in waking me up to the world in ways I wouldn't have.  I have even had a hospital, recently, during a very bad grand mal, treat me basically like epilepsy is not even valid.  I'm glad to have found this group.

label: negative
message: it affects my life in many ways! from not being able to be around any sound at all in the morning, to having to remove myself from stressful situations, to doing everyday things that most "normal" people can do.  And it affects my family and relationships too.  As those of you know whose seizures aren't visible to others, people think if you can't see the disability, that it doesn't exist.  Either way, I try my best to manage my lifestyle to decrease my seizures to the best of my ability.
author: Hannah Keyes

label: positive
message: I have also been an Epileptic for 30 years and have been blessed in that it has had little impact on my daily life until recently because medication managed it very well. Recently though as my body has changed after having kids and growing older so too have my symptoms. I have to make sure to take my medication every morning and every night around the 12 hr mark other wise the partial seizures and headaches start almost immediatley. I also have suffered some minor short term memory loss due to repeated partial seizures. As long as I take my pills though I am able to live a normal life. I can drive, raise my children and participate in nearly anything I want to. It just sucks to have to be so dependant on a medicine bottle to have a good day.
author: Lizzy Sands

label: negative
message:
I have been Epileptic for 29 years.  And through childhood and adulthood it has affected my days very dramatically.  I am grateful to have God and my family in my life to help me take care of myself.  

As a 12 year old first experiencing seizures  I always told myself by God's grace i would live with epilepsy and thank Him for letting me live through each episode. 

Today as a 41 year old wife and mother i thank God for all He has blessed me with.  My family is a very loving family and is ALWAYS by me when i have an attack.  I love everyone who has accepted me regardless of the seizures. 

You can live with epilepsy!!!

label: positive
message:
Can you tell I've been reading lots of comments written by poorly educated people?  
My epilepsy messes with everything I plan.  I'm blessed to have a pretty standard pattern based on hormonal changes that helps me know when my safest days are to be more independent, unlike a few years ago when they were entirely sporadic.  It changes where my mother parks when I am with her, what stores we go to, (sizes are important, and some stores seem to make me have seizures if I'm in them too long.  Is it lighting, a security system, something else?  I don't know) where I sit in church... -the end of whatever pew, hopefully near the back/other door.  It has an effect on everything I do, but I really try not to let it control what I do and how I think.

label: negative
message: First I’d like to say, thanks to everyone for having me here today and for making this Epilepsy awareness project happen! I don’t think there’s any way we can’t say that the world needs to be more aware of Epilepsy – we just can’t say it enough! I’m retired now and I spend a lot of time speaking with individual families and schools – basically anyone saying “I need a mentor – someone who has been here and lived through this.” When I was a young teenager, I would have given ANYTHING to have met someone that could give me guidance who knew what I was going through – but I didn’t get that until I was in my forties. That personal connection is so important. So I’m hoping today to be that resource for people going through what I went through.
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message:
Once you’ve reached Acceptance, you’re going to start asking yourself: “What are the things I can do to tell if I’m getting better or getting worse?” So I usually say: “If you don’t play to win, why keep score?” While this isn’t a game, we still want to win – so it’s important that we keep score! So what does that mean?

You MUST keep records of your seizure activity. Whether it’s daily or weekly, you need to find some way to keep records of: frequency, severity (how tough), time of day (asleep or awake), and any additional triggers – for me, I track relative stress level (for example, somewhere between 1 and 10).  You need to do one additional thing: it’s important that you can find a way to SUMMARIZE this at a level that is easily understandable by your physician. In my case, I’ve done it at monthly or quarterly levels (though I usually do monthly at this time). In these summarizations, you need to point out any particular changes you’ve had in your personal lifestyle (career changes, stressors, treatment changes, etc) so that you can see patterns that correlate to the activities around you. 

In this picture, you can see an example of a chart I’ve created over the years to share with my physician.
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message:
Our first question of the day is from Lisa-Marie W: “How do you explain epilepsy/ prepare your students for a possible seizure during the term?”

I first taught in a very rural area in Missouri in the mid 70s, so there was very little information or awareness of epilepsy. I actually never stood up in front of my students and told them “I have epilepsy” – the awareness just wasn’t there. I didn’t want to tell my students because I knew A) they wouldn’t understand and B) there was no way for them to really educate themselves about this disease (remember, this was the mid-70s!!). In my case, I would have about a 10 second aura warning. I would just exit the room and have my seizure in the hallway, collect myself, and then re-enter the room and make some excuse. In two years, I never had a student come up to me to ask what was actually wrong – and this happened to me roughly every two weeks for two years. If I did it today, I would certainly sit down first with my students and say “Today we aren’t going to talk about math – we’re going to talk about Epilepsy.” I would want to talk through exactly what epilepsy is and what it means to me. I may even let the students watch me have a partial-onset seizure at some point just so that they could learn and have first-hand knowledge since so few people actually know about epilepsy.
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message:
When I speak with patients across the country, I like to focus on 5 important factors: 
-	Acceptance
-	Keeping Score
-	Predicting
-	Playing by the Rules
-	Should I give up?

I’ll touch on Acceptance first. It doesn’t matter if you’ve been recently diagnosed or were diagnosed 10 years ago, at some point you’ll go through the 5 stages of grief: Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression, and finally Acceptance. Throughout the first 3 stages, your seizures are still there; and when you move into depression (which you will likely do), your body may respond with increased seizure activity purely as a factor of enhanced stress. 

Until you finally Accept the fact that you have Epilepsy, then (in my opinion) you’re never going to be able to take charge of the problem yourself and be able to take important steps to correct this. “I accept it; I know I have it; NOW what can I do?”
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message:
When I was younger, I played basketball and would have seizures on the court. My coach would burn a time-out and get me off the court. After that, he would check on me throughout the game to see how I was feeling and see when I was ready to go back in. This was the same case for baseball, football, etc. Today, people learn they have epilepsy, then go online and find so much information that it can scare them. In my case, I had people in my life who were willing to sit with me and learn what was happening to me and push me to be better – as opposed to just assuming the worse. 

We ended up discovering exactly what was happening to me when I was in seventh grade: we saw a public service announcement on TV that showed “little Johnny” having a seizure on TV and I said to my mom “that’s exactly what happens to me every day” – from that point on we started doing the research it would take to find a way to make me better! My parents gave me an option: they said, do you want to stop doing these things you’re doing or do you want to work hard? I wanted to keep doing these fun activities that I was doing and the only way to do that was to keep on pushing for better treatment. My parents were true mentors for me – they pushed me to keep finding ways to improve my condition.
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: positive
message: This concludes today's session! I want to thank everyone for spending their day with us! My main message is to never give up and that you must play by the rules if you’re going to succeed. Playing by the rules means working hand-in-hand with your physician to figure out the right path for you and sticking with that; while at the same time making sure you’re putting yourself in the best situations to manage your epilepsy! Thanks to everyone for your time today and we look forward to continue connecting with you all in the future!

label: positive
message:
Once you’ve started tracking your seizure activity, you can begin to notice important patterns and/or triggers. For me, stress is a major trigger. My normal stress level is at a 5 – if I’m sitting at that normal stress level, my seizure activity is normal for me. Now, if I suddenly take on new projects and my stress level spikes to an 8 or 9, then my seizure activity wouldn’t change significantly either. This was good. Unfortunately, as soon as my stress level DROPPED (let’s say down to a 2), then my seizure activity would go up significantly. So it wasn’t during a stressful time that seizures happened – it was actually after the stressful periods when it occurred. For instance, when I was playing basketball, my seizures would occur during time outs or during free throws because the stress had stopped. 

So what does that mean for me now? I have learned how to step myself down from my high stress level down to a normal stress level to avoid the large drops that trigger increased seizure activity. I work to keep my stress levels fairly consistent and avoid significant up-and-down swings in stress. This is the pattern I learned about myself by observing my charts and data – it will be different for any of you for sure, but that’s how it works for me.
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message: I have had seizures sense I was 11 years old. I am 29 now and up until September 20, 2013 I was having seizures every 4-6 once in that time period. I had Grand Mal seizures! I never asked for this I wasn't born with it. I was in a wreck. My mom calls me her LITTLE BABY MIRACLE! Bc the doctor's have told her I should be dead, a vegetable,  paralyzed, and brain dead before but God has aloud me to go over a year without a seizure now. I don't know if my seizures are under controlled or not. But this is the longest I have ever been without a seizure. And all who continue to face the struggles that come alone with seizures I will pray for each of y'all daily bc this is something very hard to live with. May God bless each of y'all life's as he has blessed mine.
author: Allie Pauline Stanley

label: negative
message:
The best route to ANY successful treatment for seizures is JOURNALING! I've lived with this battle my entire life and nothing helped me more than A DOCTOR THAT LISTENS & A JOURNAL with date, time, activities, and before/after symptoms. .....
This JOURNAL (Bible of my EPILEPSY) helped my doctor understand me, my seizure triggers, my mood swings, and  get closer to MY CORRECT TREATMENT! ...
I'm not completely controlled but from 1-10 TONIC-CLINIC seizures a day; Now 1-3 month of simple partial. AS FAR AS I'M CONCERNED, I'M ALMOST THERE!!
author: Lydia M. Salinas

Thank you, advocates for your site and the work you are doing to educate even a retired healthcare worker like me!

label: negative
message: This is a good informative graph that speaks to my experiences of POS. It's becoming my experience  that people don't really seem to know or care unless they see it first hand. Is it necessary to bomb FB with useful information they will likely need if they don't read it? Those too busy, too ignorant or too proud to take 2 mins of their time will just run in the corner scared when they could in fact actually help somebody someday. I have learned not to be ashamed or embarrassed to tell people I have epilepsy. It's a part of who I am and something I'm going to overcome. ..but I've learned that in telling people,  you learn who your real supporters are.

Why doesn't your page have a place where those with epilepsy can post there stories, I was undiagnosed for 13 years have had 3 brain biopsies and was finally diagnosed in Aug of 
 2013 with a rare form of Rasmussen Encephalitic mixed with MS on top of that I have also had fibromyalgia since I was 10 or 11 and was officially diagnosed with it as well I have every test point and more is what the rumotologist said. I'm losing the left side of my body because of my epilepsy. And my seizures are in fact aura related however because two of my seizures medication are considered narcotics my doctors are reluctant to give them to my self even though I've never changed dosages and I was recently called a drug addict at my last eptologist doctors appointment....I've stopped the med. There having a fuss about I take vitamins and two out of 3 of my seizure meds it's almost been 3 months seizure free

label: negative
message: I have nothing but praise for those that care for those suffering from epilepsy     I am one of the fortunate . I was diagnosed with Epilepsy at age 5 suffered from Petite and Gran Mal siezures I went through the battery of medications with varying results I was a regular at Harbor view epi-center and was put on a federal blind drug study for tranzene at the age of 16 ,my seizures diminished, the program ended when I was 18 but I continued on the medication , by just after my 21st Bday I was seizure free . By age of 27 I was off meds- I am now 55  still seizure free, whether the meds kick started something or I simply grew out of my siezures I do not know, I have had numerous EKGs over the years and all seems to be normal. For all the family and friends ( and the local fire dept) I give thanks as  Epilepsy effects all of those around them.

author: Tim Tilt

label: positive
message:
Good to hear Alan's story and glad you continued to live life. 
I had petimals as a young child in the 70's, when they still called them fits and nobody talked about it. I out grew them, but in 2002, had my first grandmal/tonic clonic seizure. I've always been active and as long as my husband & I took precaution, I started running which then turned into doing triathlons. I just completed a half Ironman. 
My seizures had been under control with 2 medications and with that, have been seizure free since 2006. I did have one, after seeing a 3D movie, but as bad as it was, because I am active, my Neurologist believes I came out of it quicker than years past because of my activities. 
So I encourage those, that if your seizure are under control, then live life. Life is precious and so much to experience.
author: Lynn Makelke-Baker

label: negative
message: Had my first grand mall 3 years after my accident and don't know how may predict mal seizures I had before that.  It  took 2 more years to get answers and med balances that worked.  That was 40 years ago.  Still have questions no one seems to have answers for.

author: Fred McCallum

label: negative
message:
My mom was 13 years old in 1952, and several things happened that year:.  Hard to picture now, but Mom was a bit of a tomboy in those days.  She liked to play with her two brothers, both younger, who of course did Not want to play with big sister.  They decided, "Let's play follow the leader on our bikes.  That'll lose her."  They jumped a ditch, Mom got scared and slowed down, fell off and broke her arm.  She started her period that year, and she was in the shower when she had her first seizure.  Ganna(my grandma) found her, and man she was freaked.  She'd barely even heard of epilepsy.  
Also in that year, they moved from a house to basically an empty lot.  The five of them lived in their garage for the first year or two.  They carried everything in the kids' little red wagon, on foot; no one helped them.  Perhaps all related to Mom's epilepsy, maybe not.  Mystery.
author: Marinda Boydstun

label: neutral
message: I love this!! What do I say to my son who has been having seizures since he was 6 months old, but LOVES playing basketball and football? label: neutral
message: Wearing purple sharing posts and stories and continuing to research all i can about epilepsy and seizures.
author: Paula Lay

label: negative
message: Talking about epilepsy to people around me; sharing my story.
author: Loretta K. Boileau

label: negative
message: Been fighting the EP for 6 years now and im not gonna lie, I have no idea what im doing.... Its taken so much from me, things Ill never be able to get back but yet none of the doctors ive been too seem to want to listen...Im apearantly to young to have the symptoms I have.....Im 26, of course im too young, if i was 80 and had these problems i wouldnt be seeing a doctor because it would be NORMAL....Anyone have any advice or something, im sick of the Lepsy kicking my A** and do any of you guys with EP struggle with just day to day life??
author: Cody J Johnson

label: negative
message: Wear purple and share my story! I live with grand-mal seizures; since age of thirteen. I need help please, I would like to drive and live independently with confidence. I am terrified of driving with epilepsy. I'm twenty-eight years old and still live with my grandmother. I do not drive but desperately need to. Does anyone have information on how to obtain a seizure trained dog? I cannot afford to purchase this dog, is there a foundation who can help me with a trained pup? I wish to own one, as this dog could help me to live independently and save my life, Amen.
author: Krystal Wright

label: negative
message: I'm so sorry for your loss, and I feel your pain and frustration.  So few people realize that Epilepsy can be life-threatening.  I lost my sweet baby girl at age 4...from SUDEP (sudden unexplained death due to Epilepsy).  She passed in her sleep and we found her the next morning.  It was devastating.
author: Danelle Davison Veillette

label: negative
message: At this point, probably filing a lawsuit.
author: Greg Martin

label: neutral
message: I help spread awarness by word of mouth and facebook due to my own expiriences of having Epilepsy myself since 1983 age 16,I am now 46!
author: Angelina Vilchez

label: neutral
message:
I will spread awareness on the campus of UNG-Gainesville, a university that: -refuses to accommodate my son;
-Is working hard to get him kicked out.
author: Pam Laurooson

label: negative
message: attending "Epilepsy Awareness Day at Disneyland Resort" with my "Service Dog" named: ALEPO and educating the public about "Epilepsy" and how "Service Dogs" help me fight my battle.

label: neutral
message: Wearing my purple ribbon with pride.
author: Tracy Crowe Washington

label: neutral
message: Wearing purple every day and then explaining why to all the people who ask me!  It has been fun to share this in a new city!  I'm getting lots of questions and getting to tell a lot of new people about epilepsy!
author: Audrey S. Autrey

label: negative
message: People keep asking about the Kansas State hat I'm wearing. I wear it for November and I've gotten a lot of attention here in Dallas. I tell them, "This is Epilepsy Awareness Month, and purple is our color." I've answered questioned and found others who have family and friends with epilepsy.
author: Mark Allison

label: negative
message: In loving memory of my mother, Shirley Shull, who had severe epilepsy. If you knew my mom, please wear purple at least once this month!!
author: Angie Shull

label: neutral
message: By having a good neurologist, a great support team in my wife, and educating about the kind of seizures I have so the proper treatment plan is in place. Praise God I have all of the above.

label: neutral
message: posting articles and other awareness links through my facebook! I'm already helping spread the awareness!

label: positive
message: I am wearing purple everyday that isn't a Chicago Blackhawks game day. I also made a lapel ribbon which has several teachers asking what it stands for. I need more epilepsy education so let's learn together.

label: neutral
message: oh, and getting others to wear purple ;)

label: positive
message: try to educate Anybody, even if it's a little, explain Why i'm wearing purple :D

label: neutral
message: Having a Gran Mal in public probably.

label: positive
message: Wearing purple and helping others who struggle with diagnosis and everyday issues

label: neutral
message: Never giving up, and helping people understand this neurological condition !!!!!!!!!
author: Mike Booj

label: neutral
message: Teaching people NEVER to put anything in a person's mouth when having a seizure, they may bite and break the item  and it may lodge in their airway,  Please, people think before you do! Teaching Seizure Awareness!!
author: Cindy White-Jimenez

label: neutral
message: Promoting epilepsy awareness, and donating to the cause

label: neutral
message: Getting  the word out at the 2 public schools  I work at.
author: Mark Geist

label: neutral
message: Wearing purple, bringing awareness and supporting epilepsy research.
author: Fran Ryan

label: neutral
message: Wearing purple talking to friends and co workers and hugging my grandchildren every chance I get.

label: neutral
message: By wearing purple everyday to bring awareness and support my son!!

label: negative
message: Submitted story to local newspaper, and website.
author: David A. Watson

label: neutral
message: Teaching my fellow workers about epilepsy
author: Kelly Case

label: negative
message: showing pictures of myself at events and my story!
author: Joy Kirlin Stewart

label: negative
message: I co-own a dance company - my director's solo at this past Saturday's annual variety show included many of the movement's I do pre, mid, and post seizure (post dictal) of my absent, petite, and grand-mal's. The song stated "Blame it on the night, don't blame it on me" (acoustic version ) as my convulsive seizures only come at night and my guilt of night time for myself and family is deep...The song ended abruptly before anyone would of thought, just as some normal days or nights do for some of us. The choreography was simple and I did not execute it to mu fullest potential in several parts, as sometimes I cannot live to my fullest potential. I had a friend in the audience who was recently diagnosed, and her girlfriend in my company had purple streaks in her hair. <3
author: Adam N Marcia Cloutier

label: neutral
message: Supporting my son and spreading the word about epilepsy
author: John Mojica

label: positive
message: I am spreading awareness by selling purple bracelets and donating the money to the epilepsy foundation of America. I also have my entire school wearing purple every Wednesday to support epilepsy awareness and I'm challenging my family and friends to donate $20 to the epilepsy foundation of America and I am thanking those people by taking a pie in the face with each donation to help #SmashOutEpilepsy
author: Emily's Epileptic Days

label: positive
message: To learn more about reporting side effects, please visit our Adverse Events Reporting tab. Remember you can always report any side effects that you experience directly to your doctor and the FDA by visiting www.FDA.gov/medwatch or by calling 1-800-FDA-1088.
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: positive
message:
Just let me be , let me gather myself and let me continue on with my daily routine.i don't like to be "babied " 
It is what it is. Let the seizure do its thing and we can carry on .
author: Jessica Jones-Wilcox

label: positive
message:
I usually sleep, when I wake up, my husband will remind me that I've had a seizure, answers my questions and makes me lay Down or rest where I will relax, most of the time I sit in my recliner next to him, as I gradually remember everything that led up to the seizure. I take cocoanut oil gel tabs, 100% pure, within two weeks after I started taking these I was able to retain my memory, remembering things I had long forgotten - even remembering, at times. being in the middle of a seizure. I have Gran Mal seizures. But these gel tabs have worked wonders with my memory! 
I don't let my seizures keep me from going after what I want or allow it to stop me from trying new things. I wasn't born with epilepsy, but started having them at 13 years old, I've had them for over 43 years. I have a career, husband, two children and five grandchildren. Don't let someone tell you, you -CAN'T until you've at least tried. <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+008A>
author: Denise Walker McGrain

label: negative
message: Mine are grand Mal, it takes at least a day for me to recover
author: Brian Tilley

label: negative
message: This has got to b the most AMAZING cite I have ever found. I am 58 yrs old n mother of 2 grown sons. I have partial complex seizures,with an aura prior to seizure. I am fully conscious but don't kno anything that happenens until after seizure. Then I ask my spouse n he explains it all. I went 15 months with NO SEIZURERS,until last week I had 2!!!! I HVE had seizures 54yrs n NEVER in all those yrs did I go more thn 3 weeks w out one. So after 15mos I felt blessed. So now I just go on. Again thnk u so much for this cite...
author: Lynne Meyer

label: negative
message: My son is about to be three and he has complex partial seizures with secondary generalization. Reading all of these has helped me so much in learning ways to help him after a seizure.
author: Tori Schmidt

label: negative
message: My son needs rest and assurance he is ok.  Also we try to talk about the seizure and what he remembers.
author: Barbara Whitehouse

label: negative
message: I can't tell you when i have one its like blacling out wake up and dont know what is going on 2yrs seizure free
author: Sonia Mills

label: positive
message: A supportive wife and the good Lord
author: Ron Rosencrans

label: positive
message: ...sleep. After I come out of a grand-mal eizure I have no idea where I am.
author: Cindy Lou Holmes

label: negative
message: Time to recover. I also want a soothing and understanding voice to comfort me. I have a very hard time relaxing my brain during and afterwards so sometimes a dark room helps.
author: Mary Beth Runnels Neal

label: negative
message: I don't always need to recover, sometimes I don't even notice! But if I need to remember something I'm talking about or doing, it could just take a minute or two of just being still and thinking to myself..
author: Christy Coombs

label: neutral
message: I was diagnosed when I was in I think first grade but should have been earlier. Now I am a college graduate. thought this would give some encouragement.
author: Sarah Belle

label: negative
message: Sleep. Quiet.  Like a computer rebooting.
author: Lisa Mitchell Parker

label: neutral
message: I have juvenile myoclonic epilepsy and just sleeping afterwards makes me feel a lot better.
author: Raeschelle Phillips

label: negative
message: I have nocturnal temporal lobe epilepsy and when I have them what helps me recover is a soothing voice and someone telling me it's ok. My body hurts really bad afterwards for a while so just time and rest also and getting my meds adjusted as soon as possible.
author: Stephanie Leighton

label: negative
message: For me sometimes I need a little time to recover but not very often.  I try to keep still and try to relax.
author: Mary J Mahoney

label: negative
message: Having people around me.  I tend to cry.
author: Alex Bear

label: negative
message: I have psuedoseizures but whenever I have one I don't want anybody to even talk about it. Like, I know I just had one so you don't have to point it out. It's the norm for me so there's no need to pause life. Just....don't even mention it and if I look tired, slow down for me. Just be normal.
author: Holly Whorton

label: negative
message: I have auras before seizures. They are probably the worst part of it all. I feel so much better it is all over that I just want to get back to what I was doing.
author: Angela Ray

label: negative
message: Deep breathe, stillness, and calm my mind and thoughts to get back to where they were
author: Breanne Dancel

label: negative
message: It had always been a very difficult thing. But I have found Rest, family support, and determination to get back up have sustained me throughout my many years. God is good.
author: Linda Verge

label: negative
message: I need a short nap to give my brain a rest period.
author: Susan Smith Hittle

label: negative
message: I kind of recognize when I'm going to have one and let others know I feel off.
author: Nikita N. Grimes

label: negative
message: I have complex partial seizures. I just need sleep and quiet.
author: Tanya Willard

label: positive
message: I have these and grand mal. When i have these i come to quick and then I'm either aware or unaware of what is going on.  After a grand mal i sleep a lot. Like for a day or two.
author: Sabric Queen

label: neutral
message: Assurance,rest and some to be there for me for comfort.i have petit mal seizures.
author: Sarah Groeneveld

label: neutral
message: Lots of sleep and water and my love ones to be there 2
author: Rhonda Smith

label: negative
message: we generally time my sons and then let him sleep and answer his questions and just keep him comfortable
author: Evangeline Smith-Hubbard

label: negative
message: I watch Anne of Green Gables. For some reason the simple story is for soothing for me.
author: Diane K O'Hara

label: positive
message: I have to sleep.. There is pretty much all I can do.. I can't remember having a seizure most of the time
author: Sherry Dugas

label: negative
message: Complex partial seizures are similar but you lose consciousness. Simple partial seizures are more like auras and may be a warning that a bigger seizure is coming.
author: Megan Fincher

label: negative
message: lots of rest and no stress or drama at all... I agree with you jenny and Jessica..
author: Amy May

label: neutral
message: I will take a long nap. My memory takes a little longer to recover.
author: Michael Roque

label: positive
message: Sleep bad headache and a lot of muscle pain.
author: Mary Monroe-Maley

label: negative
message: Same,grand mal,in pain for days,confusion for about 30min,already have heart arithmia and almost always hit my head and injure myself,docs dont care,they give no ivs,nothing for pain,i dont go to hospital anymore cuz they make me sit there for hrs send me home anyway
author: Cassandra Bunn

label: negative
message: A bit of quiet rest & something for the headache.  Then it's back to my day. If it's a simple partial I just need a couple minutes to get my equilibrium & I'm good to go.
author: Jessica Smith

label: negative
message: Do any of you who have seizures remember anything during them .. Do any of you continue to do things you where doing while in a seizure? My daughter can whistle and talk( usually gibberish) and many other things .. I just wonder if its normal..
author: Amanda L. Whiteaker

label: neutral
message: For me just sitting down for a minute and getting something to drink helps.
author: Jeff Richards

label: neutral
message: Ive made edibles, to relax and gather myself
author: Jme Penz

label: negative
message: Left alone. I have partial seizures everyday and grand mal seizures monthly and I hate the questions afterwards. I'm fine I'm confused shut it
author: Lindsey Vetter

label: negative
message: I'm TBI survivor, I'm on a drug study and my seizures mostly nocturnal in my sleep. and no memory. My husband good caregiver knows it. Always, we call my neurologist specialist let them know time and date..I need  to do extra special care..After math, always been so hard on me. I'm very weak in bed for week. Always, doctors orders  plenty of bed rest and liquids. Stay calm. and breathe. For right NOW here is some good news. My study have be working for me. Now, I have been seizure free for 6 mths!!! I have good regiment! I take my meds on time. Do a seizure diary. I eat good diet. Exsercise and don't dehydrate. Take one day at a time!!
author: Joy Kirlin Stewart

label: neutral
message: I find that bright light such as turning on the lights helps me recover. TK
author: SuAnne Kistler

label: negative
message: Telling anyone how will listen about it and educating as many ppl as possible..
author: Staci Pruett

label: negative
message: I've had both where I don' t lose conscienceness,but mostly I usually always do. Either way I can't close my eyes because I still see halos anr heve a fear of going into another...so I just think about horses or dogs.
author: Valerie Hanson

label: negative
message: i was just born and my mom let my dad hold me but i was a shooken baby and i ended up having seizures
author: Devon Knight

label: negative
message: some nice cold water and a wet cloth behind my neck does it for me.  I have complex partial seizures.  I then may get a headache and feel tired and sleepy, when I wake up its as if it never happened.  God bless you all bcus I know many people could never fathom what it feels like.
author: Linda Fuentes

label: negative
message: Sleep and a dark room. I usually have migraines after my grand mal. It takes a good day or two to reboot. I use heating pads and massage on my muscles
author: Andy Thornock

label: negative
message: The statement that brought u p isnt always true.  Im not being negative, but i do know head on.
author: Lisa Wheeler Chapman

label: negative
message: Depending on the seriousness of the seizure I have , I can either lay down for a few minutes or just relax. I also have to be careful since they have found another damaged brain cell a few years ago.
author: Candace Mason

label: neutral
message: I usually have mine when I'm sleeping so I roll over and finish sleeping throughout the night
author: Elena L Bernal

label: negative
message: @Don I've had many differ types of seizures..I have worked full time got treated fairly...most of time...l have worked & raised a family...also have need control my meds.. l was sent to top of line surgeon.... Said as long as lm mainly control w meds ... it's not worth to have the surgery!!  to be down that long and leave my family and it ended and not knowing what's going to outcome be that he suggest I stay on the meds even though I still have partial mal,  all every now and then it's worth it to me to be self sufficient control my family control my feelings you know what's going on I can deal with that I'm not having so I'm doing okay.....I've had it over 50 ,yrs...plus...
author: Sylvia Silvas

label: negative
message: Anyone get a vagus nerv stimulater?
author: Bud Glass

label: neutral
message: I close my eyes and try to calm down by breathing slowly
author: Bud Glass

label: negative
message:
I jus suffered an epilepsy attack about 2 hours ago in ma sleep.......
 My tongue is all bit up I got a headache nd I'm very weak
author: Antonio Vuelvas

label: neutral
message: Just getting off my feet and turning off lights
author: Emily Griffy

label: positive
message: how many of you are employed making a good living and being treated like you would like to be treated.                                                                                           another question.  how many of you are married and raising children and do you feel  fairly by those who do not  have epilepsy and lastly.                                         if you were told tomorrow by your doctor yhat you could have surgery that the surgery could end all the hurting that you have suffered,  what would your dreams be.

label: neutral
message: Being able to relax and get my thoughts back together.
author: Sandy Lawson

label: neutral
message: For people to wait for the seizure to finish and remind me what I was saying
author: Tracy Harth

label: negative
message: I don't even remember what kind I have anymore cause I've had my meds changed 3 times. but I don't even know when I have one. I know I sometimes feel one of my legs or arms go numb but I just make myself try to walk or move my arm. then I am good.
author: Sarah Belle

label: positive
message: I have 3 types of seizures. But with a simple partial I just need a minute for my heart to stop racing (and realize that it's not going to turn into a complex partial or grand mal). I need a minute where no one asks me anything and I can breathe deep and smile because it's over and it wasn't bad.
author: Sarah Tice Heinz

label: positive
message: I don't see the option to be able to send messages on here, nor even for members to create new postings. So I'm going to take a shot to post it on here to see what will happen. Sometime yesterday I posted a reply on here, but don't see it anywhere. Was it deleted?
author: Bruce W Moreau

label: negative
message: My daughter's simple partial seizure last a lot longer. Sometimes all day.

label: negative
message: I need more information in Spanish please

label: negative

message: Denise how does coconut oil gel tabs help with seizures??

label: negative

Her sister, my oldest daughter, can look at her and can ID before a seizure strikes. I'm her mom, and I can't tell! <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+0094>
author: Kelly Williams Brown

label: positive
message: Let me do my thing and make sure I don't fall
author: Jordan Gruzinski

label: neutral
message: prayer and mine are complex and last longer

label: negative
message: I usually sleep all day after I have one I be to weak to get up for anything!
author: Antonio Vuelvas

label: neutral
message: I lay down for a little bit.  Usually takes a few hours to feel somewhat back to normal.
author: Rachel Savage Gross

label: negative
message: Many seizures last only for for a few seconds, the person doesn't even know they had one.  Le them be.  Life is good!
author: Tammy Peterson King

label: neutral
message: My son has them an sleep usually helps him the most..
author: Melissa Sousa Matias

label: negative
message: Time.  Its at the point now when I lose consciousness & come back idk anyone around me. Including my husband & kids. Its horrifying.
author: Natosha Jaydens'Grandma Wilson

label: negative
message: My 14-year-old son has tonic-clonic seizures. He sleeps for 10-12 hours and has an excruciating headache. After his first seizure and after his most recent seizure, he had a weird kind of amnesia that lasted for about a month. He was unable to access any new memories. If anyone has had this happen to them, I would be very interested to hear about it. Hardly anyone has heard of it (only his current neurologist, who is head of Epilepsy at the hospital).
author: Margaret Perry Shea

label: neutral
message: I usually have grand mals and after all the confusion wears off, i throw up a few times and have a massive headache. I drink water and stretch (cuz of sore muscles) and then sleep it off. It def throws my whole day off.
author: Lucy Loom

label: negative
message: My daughter has seizures daily, usually multiple per day & always needs to sleep afterwards.
author: Heather MacIntyre Kluck

label: negative
message: Nap! Food! And someone who I feel really truly loves me. It eases my stress.
author: Vivian Baum

label: positive
message: Sleep, sleep and a little more sleep. :)
author: Missy Poole Brenton

label: neutral
message: Rest. Patience from those around me. Redirection and having them remind me, you just had a seizure, stop being so hard on your self. Counting on and using that support system. <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B2><U+009C>
author: Cathy Leavitt LaPointe

label: neutral
message: It helps me to stay busy in order to stay POSITIVE...
author: Lydia M. Salinas

label: negative
message: Take a deep breath, drink some water, and if I'm not weak/tired, I GET RIGHT BACK TO IT :-) :-) :-) :-) :-)
author: Lydia M. Salinas

label: negative
message: Sometimes my partial seizures last all night. I have to sleep the next day to recover.
author: Linda Fuller Snyder

label: positive
message: My son requires extra sleep or just a little extra time to regroup.
author: Kim Caufield

label: negative
message: Simples come all the time and so long as they do not progress into a complex all is well.  Seldom will anyone but my wife ever even realize that I am in a simple.  The biggest thing that I always fight to remember if it begins to progress is to breathe.
author: Chad Martin

label: negative
message: I have had seizures for over 20yrs I was able to get my grand mal seizures under control with a VNS implant but just can't get my partial under control but I also noticed I Will have about one or two a day but when it comes to that time of the month I will have up to ten in less then a hour and have no control over my bladder I have tried many meds and still can't get them to stop Yes sleep helps but I still need to take care of my kids
author: Mandy Boyer

label: negative
message: My son need some alone time and he's normally very tired
author: Kathryn Sawyer

label: positive
message: When I was little I had a warning tummy ache I grew out of the warning. And if I was alone when I had a seizure  I would be tired afterward
author: Mark Geist

label: neutral
message: a nap mama used to mix sugar and orange juice to head off a seizure
author: Ginger Dehart

label: neutral
message: Id lie down or go to my mom
author: Renee Peek

label: negative
message: My daughter lays down for 20 minutes no sounds or lights. My son just has to cuddle with me for 45 minutes.  It the touching that makes him feel safe.
author: Cynthia Gilbert-Kucsera

label: negative
message: Our youngest child , our daughter has seizures and is being sent to a neurologist this month ..hers can last several minutes and it takes sometimes up to an hour for her to respond and talk . This is terribly scary as a parent . The doctors call these focal seizures . Does anyone know anything about this type of seizure and what might cause it ?
author: Stacy McDaniel

label: neutral
message: I just had a seizure the other night at work, haven't had one in over a year.. I've had seizures since I was 3 and now I'm 56.. I was at work so needless to say, I was taken by ambulance to the ER, given a shot and etc..stress and lack of sleep is what causes mine.. I'm a nurse by profession and have been for 30 years.. Hopefully I won't have another for a years..
author: Frances Garner- Haverstick

label: positive
message: I have simple partial. I used to be able to comprehend what was going on during just couldn't respond. Now I totally black out for the whole minute or so. Luckily I have auras as my warning that a seizure is coming. The worst is after - it takes a good 5 mins to get back to ' normal'. I  just try to go back to whatever I was doing usually. It just stinks. Plus I'm so tired I could pass right out
author: Jacklyn Marie

label: negative
message: Quiet Time & After a bit of a rest back to my normal daily routine
author: Mandy Rae

label: positive
message: Seizure recovery varies from person to person... I like quietness, darkness, and to be snuggled lol yeah I'm a softy.
author: Jamaal Young

label: neutral
message: I eventually grew out of them through puberty which is was nice but I still am very cautious around flashing lights or with other activities.
author: Taylor Kaitlin Marie Smith

label: negative
message: I had Epilepsy from age 5 to 14 and there were days when I could not cope at all...doing stuff with my mom or my grandparents really helped me a lot.  We would watch Disney Movies,go to the Zoo,etc. One day I had to do a sleep study and had to stay up all night the night before. My mom had to find things to keeps us awake and we went to Walmart and bought Hot Wheels and game boards.  We had so much fun!
author: Taylor Kaitlin Marie Smith

label: negative
message:
I have starring were I can hear what's going on but can't respond then for some reason after I come round I'm in a different place and I've injured myself last one i'd fractures my right knee I had fallen downstairs but I wasn't upstairs in the first place I was downstairs on the11-17
I'm having another EEG which I will be wearing for 4 days at home but there really annoying i've also started sleep walking which is not good when your hooked up to a BIPAP machine
author: Debbie Williams

label: neutral
message: my son plays with his cars or watches a movie. he is usually very quiet before, during, and after it happens
author: Kelly Case

label: positive
message: quite time and if possible a nap
author: Patti Tipton

label: positive
message: Caffeine, my husband answering any questions and helping me piece together what had happened& trying to figure out what triggered the seizure. I have had great luck with cold substations helping me feel grounded or still in contact with the"real world" during the event.
author: Alisha Brooks

label: positive
message: This is how my seizures started. Most often ... in the early AM after waking.
author: Crystal A. Reid

label: negative
message: I haven't had a grand mal seizure for over 20 yrs., I do have the partial ones especially if i'm under stress.This is what I do I take another 1 of my pills & drink a mountain dew this usually helps.If not I go to bed & rest. Just leave me alone.
author: Sally Bomaster

label: neutral
message: Rest and or sleep. It's best if once I'm in a safe place people let me be because I say some pretty crazy things@  times.
author: Maya Banda Medina

label: negative
message: Dont ask me any questions....that makes it worse.....i really prefer not to even be talked to after a seizure ...,what helps to bring me around the most is for someone to gently rub my arm until i am out of the seiuzure and aware of   my surroundings...then i am usually weak and tired and often left with a headache. I oftentimes will have to take a mini nap or just go sit down for a few minutes to get myself back together.  This may happen to me several times a day..,.depending on the weather.....
author: Kimberly McLeod

label: negative
message: When i had seizures i sat got my thoughts n rested then continued my day ..
author: Jill Renee Grimm

label: neutral
message: I used to have grand mal seizures. Every time I had them I landed in the hospital cause I would pass out and usually hit my head. It took me days to recover- usually in the hospital since the seizures messed with my heart.
author: Kelly McClendon-Neary

label: negative
message: I just started this journey. I have partials, but sometimes it takes up to 5 mins to recover and sometimes it goes right back into one. Mine are stress related and have found that if I dont get enough sleep, I have episodes of multiple seizures. What helps me come out is touch and talk. Even my grandbabies know, when I start, they get up and come hokd my hand and rub it.

label: negative

author: Sabrina Andrews

label: positive
message: Idk if this is the right place to post this, but I cannot find a way to message you/ the peeps of said advocates. I am an 8 year veteran of Graphic Design, and would love to do either Pro-Bono or paid graphic design/ graphic arts for this group. I have had epilepsy for 13 years, caused by Dercum's Disease, I also am, as my doctor put it..."that one in a billion type of patient that the medical journal doesn't apply to" as I had epilepsy disappear from my world and then reappear in a two distinctly different types of seizures vs. what I suffered from prior to it "disappearing" both in my EEG( I am a person with an EEG reading of less than 9,000, compared with standard epileptics whose reading is 13,000+, which again my neurologist said is impossible according to medical journals et cettera)  and in my life. I am one who has done severe damage to my body thanks to clonic-tonic seizures (for example: fracturing my humerus, dislocating both of my shoulders, cracking my eyebrow and chin on the hard edge of a marble counter-top, and MANY other injuries). Seizures/ Epilepsy has had a strong impact on my self-confidence that has taken me years to recover from and reassert my self-confidence and love for myself, as I have soiled myself in public situations, such as when I accompanied my sister to one of her clients house, and have had seizures right as I was beginning to have intercourse; talk about awkward!
author: Corey Wood Polson

label: negative
message: I have hard time even getting a job People just dont understand it how much we have a hard time... I cant understand the interviews no matter how much i try and research on the net to improve my self. It just doesnt help at all. I always hear others say you need to try harder and find different ways. but honestly people just dont actually understand and how confused and feel not our selfs like a part of us is missing and not treated fairly. I never get a chance to actually work somewhere wont give me a chance.. I know its bad on my part telling them I have seizures and then I never hear from them. I know they wont say it but I know they wont hire someone that has seizures.

I just keep interviewing hoping I will hit get better at the interview process but the meds don't help at all.

author: Melissa A Thering

label: negative
message: My partial seizures I can feel coming on by my thinking.  I notice it, unsure, but watch it increase & peak after about 5 minutes.  Usually I just cant talk and don't understand what people are saying.  As it comes down, I try to say seizure to the ones around (if any).  Last week I was riding my HondaVTX1300 & noticed one coming on.  On a two lane backroad, I halled-ass-trying to find a place to pull off.  I found one across the road, hit the brakes, & went down. two guys stopped, helped me pick up my bike, & waited around until I could talk fairly normal & could ride home.  I was late taking my noon meds, was very hungry.
author: Ron W. Ebbert

label: positive
message: I started having them at age 33 woke up from sleep with a grand mal. I  controlled by meds I have had a seizure 11 mos ago and had a terrible car accident thank the Lord I was not hurt or anyone else. My car totaled. I went through depression and fear. Lost my drivers liscense for 6 mos. I am able to drive now but I still worry because with seizure it's the unknown. Unless you have it you can't understand it. My heart and my prayers to all who suffer with this.
author: Glenda Crockett

label: negative
message: sabrina:  i had seizures for 25 years.  during that time i had over 400 jobs faced bullying and outright discrimination in everyone of them.  before the diagnosis i was a machinist in an area that even in the 50's was highly technical.  after that instead of making 20.00 per hour i made 2.00 an hour.    i went into training thru illinois vocational rehab in 1963 i was trained to rebuild electrical motors.  this was a field i could never be employed in and voc rehab closed there ears to any request for advocacy.  i was 21 when i was diagnosed  in  1962.   in 1981 i went thru brain surgery in chicago a begnine tumor was removed andi have been seizure free since.  i was fired for being well 3 days after this surgery.i had been with the company for 11 years.  my family disowned me after all these years because of constant depression.  i have 4 grand children i will never know.   I have accepted this as reality for my life and sticking around just to see what else can happen.

I was 29 yrs old and spent 3 months in hospital... Also my 30th birthday... I will be 63 tomorrow... Proud for every year... But when a baby dies i ask GOD why didn't you take me.... I was told i had more alcohol than blood.... It took years to get them under control... By changing med...

message: To learn more about reporting side effects, please visit our Adverse Events Reporting tab. Remember you can always report any side effects that you experience directly to your doctor and the FDA by visiting www.FDA.gov/medwatch or by calling 1-800-FDA-1088.
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message:
Hey Guys, A while back I wrote a little poem, I will Post it here, I would really like to know what you think(It may be looked at as negative, but plenty of us are still climbing the ladder towards 'wondering when and if' the people around us will really accept us despite our condition. Let me know what you think and feel because either in our past and even now, I still have these emotions on what I need to do to be considered 'ME'  I titled it 'You Can Call Me'....5/23/2014
 You Can Call Me...

When you're not expecting it,
I can take control
Grasp your mind, thoughts, and body
given enough time, I can pull your heart from your soul.

When you're out and about,
I can make look like a fool
embarrass you outright
Because you are just my tool.

I am always here with you,
And I refuse to leave
I'm right here on your shoulder, 
right on your sleeve.

I can take you anytime,
Yes anytime I want
I can introduce my self at any given moment
My power have I can always flaunt.

I have been called many things,
you can cuss me at your leisure 
Yes, I have many names, 
But you can call me seizure

Written by Brian Spratley
5/23/2014
author: Brian Spratley

message: 2 grown kids, 2 grandkids. My epilepsy started in my 20s now, 20 years later, I've had the surgery,  and have been seizure free for over a year, hopefully off the meds soon. Perseverance is what I bleed. <3 much love & never surrender.

label: negative
message: I have 3 daughters and a son in law! I miss my family who is away, I care for people! I want to get better!
author: Rebecca Duncan

label: negative
message:
I have two Facebook groups of my own and I am a member of many others. I spend a lot of time Helping Other People with Epilepsy HOPE. I just got an amazing thank you message saying that I shared with them led them to find an epileptologist for their daughter and be able to communicate bbetter with the doctor about her seizures. She had a 3 day VEEG were they saw her seizures and changed her medicines. Now she has gone from having about 20 seizures per day to going a whole week with only having 1 seizure. 

That is a real blessing from god for them and a blessing for me to be able to help touch and improve someone's life that much! 

I had a right temporal lobectomy in February and have been seizure free for over 8 months which is a real blessing from God for me!

I also do paintings as a hobby.  :-)
author: Chris Arceneaux

label: negative
message: I have a wonderful husband. I have my son whom I adopted at age 12 years old and is a happy young adult now and has extensive special needs. We also host foreign exchange students which our program we to through is all volunteer. Right now I have a wonderful son from Thailand. I have another son from Thailand and daughter from Germany whom I speak to often.  I also have a Masters and Bachelors in Social Worker. I worked as a social worker full time for years. Now I work per diem direct care for home health and love it. I have 5 animals. I volunteer with people that are homeless often. I love life!!!  Oh yeah I have epilepsy which has been very hard. Epilepsy does NOT define me!! I literally fall down and get back up and start enjoying life again!!  Life is precious and I literally never know when it will be taken away so I enjoy every moment while I am here.
author: Tabatha Dean

label: negative
message: I, like everyone here, has a story. Everyone's is unique to each individual. My self, have had epilepsy since I was 13yrs old(I am 40 now). Lost jobs, suspended(or revoked) Driver's License, I can't remember, it's been so long. I haven't driven since 1999. Been on disability ever since. But unable to drive or work, I still found something I love to do AND make money too. I am now a professional photographer. I am able to to do shoots at my time, when I feel comfortable. I'm not told when or how to do something. I am my own boss! I write my own schedule. So if anyone out there is unable to be successful in the general  workforce, Find something unique to you and begin your own business. So many things you can do, things that come so natural, even to the point you don't even realize you are unique. There are people out there that need what you can do and are willing to pay for your abilities simply because they can't accomplish what you can. If it's a simple service you can offer or a every day thing that you have a strong potential doing, people need it. Find your market, aim for that market, and fulfill the needs and wants of that market.
author: Brian Spratley

label: positive
message: I am a wife..mother of 3...have 1 granddaughter...own a business that cares for others...i volunteer often...i have petit mal seizures which has been under contol for a couple of years thank God!

label: positive
message: I have had epilespy since i was six ..after my youngest son was born ..i was healed i m seisure free after many years ..of epilespy ..I'm living prove u can have healthy kids ..i have four ..n i proved dr ..wrong ..i thank God every day for my healthy children .
author: Jill Renee Grimm

label: negative
message: I am a few months from my 50th birthday and my 4th year seizure free. I am a mother of 2 a son Cary 29 this week and Rachel 25 in January.  I have worked at the Southern Nevada Regional Housing Authority for 26 years. When I was very sick and having sometimes 30 seizures a month they would be the best employee in the world. They have accommodated me left and right for which I am grateful. Anywhere else I may not be employed.  I was unable to perform my job at times but they hung on with me. Today I have gain my health back and am better than I ever was. I love to travel cook bake exercise and disc golf! I especially love my family dogs and friends. Without them I would be nothing.  I am the face of epilepsy.
author: Cheryl Irish Trotter

label: neutral
message: I m seisure free for seven years ..

label: negative
message: 48 year old here. College graduate. Mom to 3 unbelievable sons who have cared for me while i was single. Married now to my soulmate to takes care of me. I work at a police station and my Co workers take great care of me. My life is simple and good, and i have epilep.
author: Denise Milbrandt Hysmith

label: negative
message: 12 years ago, post brain surgery for a tumor I was diagnosed with seizures. My neurologist made it perfectly clear as I've never forgotten his words. "You are not an epileptic, you have epilepsy or if preferred, you have a seizure disorder".  It has never defined who I am. I am a wife, mother, grandmother, aunt, sister, daughter, friend and I find joy and blessings everyday even when I'm not looking. I work full-time and I have a very compassionate boss and very supportive co-workers. I have found ways to accept my seizure disorder through all its ups and downs. Mostly ups!
author: Dawn M Schroepfer

label: positive
message: Still trying to get used to the myoclonic seizures here.

label: neutral
message: I am a Child of God, A wife, a mother of 4 beautiful kids and a Girl Scout Leader to 17 girls! Most of all I am Tricia Mae Haynes and I am a wonderful woman of God.
author: Tricia Mae Haynes

label: negative
message: It is definitely hard not to let Epilepsy, define who I am when people look at financial risks in hiring me, here in the USA.  With all the medical lawsuits that are going on and are allowed to go on, I would rather work where I have been accepted as a competant worker and not as a risk. I am a survivor because, a small country like Danmark let me move there and finish school and helped me with my education until I was 23, I then worked hard at a factoring company owned by a group of Danish banks, There I worked AR and saw something that needed improvement and told my dept.leader, who tried to take credit for it, but I went straight to th president of the company and I was put in charge of  improving the customer lists and consistant sorting of accounts, It gave me enough to buy me an apartment and later move back to the USA.  I thought I would get treated just as fairly and justly, but We the People have a long long way to go in EQUALRIGHTS. for ALL CITIZENS of this country.
author: Maj-Britt Aust

label: negative
message: I'm a 38 year old chemical engineering student, mom to the two most perfect and amazing Korat cats, a pretty loving girlfriend, and I have epilepsy. I have the pleasure of only having grand mal seizures, no variety. My first happened completely out of the blue in 2004, and I injured myself pretty badly. They always last at least ten minutes and have been getting longer with each successive one. I have had 14 concussions, broken my nose twice, dislocated both shoulders, broken one wrist so badly that it required surgery, and numerous painful bruises and cuts. I'm blessed that I have an aura of about 1-2 seconds, so a couple of times I've been able to prevent injury from the seizure by getting to the floor, and the one time I had one while driving, I was able to pull over to safety beforehand. Epilepsy has taken a lot from me: my career as a transit driver in Minneapolis, my ability to play video games, seeing live concerts, this intangible and unexplainable feeling of safety and well-being. You never know when or where you'll be when the next one happens, and uncertainty causes stress for me, and stress increases the frequency of the seizures and intensifies the chronic pain I have from the injuries sustained during seizures. Thankfully, I've found a combination of medications that control my seizures really well; I used to have them every few weeks and now I'm approaching my second year free of seizures. They're very expensive: even as generics, the monthly cash price is more than $500. I hate that I have to depend on money from the government (in the form of an insurance subsidy) to be able to buy my medications, I took great pride in being a self-sufficient, tax-paying, productive citizen, and now I'm dependent. I'm afraid that my hard work in engineering school will be a waste, because what if I have a seizure and I'm working in a chemical plant? I've been fortunate and have always lived where doctors are not required to report seizures to the DMV, so I've never lost my license, but will I be legally able to work in the settings that a chemical engineer would work in? I really love this page, you all are so inspirational, thank you all for sharing your stories!
author: Kari Kuntz

label: negative
message: I'm a sister of 3 brothers and 3 other sisters and have a wonderful boy friend I have wonderful life long friends I work for Beach body and lush cosmetics. Iv been epileptic all my life( 29 years and all the meds later no help) and the doctors can't pinpoint where my activity is to think about brain surgery( 50/50 chance isn't good enough for me) but I wake up everyone morning with a goal in mind and try to accomplish it on a daily basis
author: Jen Sigler

label: negative
message: 10 here had a big seizure from watching the wizard of Oz with the evil witch right when the fiery explosion appeared I seized and my mom gave me my meds for the epilepsy I have and a still was unconscious and I had to go to the hospital
author: Jack Norman

label: negative
message: I am 42 yrs old, a wife, mother of 2 beautiful boys who 5 yrs ago when this all happened out of nowhere thought their mommy was dying.  I was in ICU for a month and barely knew who I was, I lost years of memory that will never come back and everyday is hard.  I couldnt read, write, walk, and now I have become a certified Yoga teacher.  I will not stop fighting.  I have done charity evnts for the past 4 yrs, I do have a facebook page and website that I havent updated recently but its called "journeyforfaith" My name.  My mom said in the hospital, I guess I named her for a reason.  I am on 3-4 medicines and had a VNS put in.  Still not working.  I am going up to NY in the next few mth for tests and then to have surgery, others are scared....me....just get me on the table. You dont walk in my shoes.  Each seizure just makes you feel bad physically and emotionally.  I wont let epilepsy define me, but its been a rough month... Im just not doing great, my Yoga has been a gift and my place I can go to when I just need to be and breathe and let it go.  There is a universe up there, I believe that, not sure why all this happened at the age of 38 but I definitely changed as a person and realize whats important... Got rid of all things toxic... Now its time for me to get better, I have 2 boys, one turning 10 Saturday and the other 12.  They need their mommy....
author: Faith Waingarten-Kaplan

label: positive
message: as an advocate don't shine off people.  they need to voice feelings.  keep this in your mind "feelings are never right or wrong.  they just are"  RESPONDING WITH YOUR FEELINGS WORKS BETTER.

label: neutral
message: I'm a wife, a caregiver, a designer, artist, and crafter, a thrift and vintage buyer, a singer, a book lover, a Halloween enthusiast, a pet owner/lover, I'm active in my community, and I'm a strong, kind person. I have other illnesses, and epilepsy, but they don't define me!

label: positive

I am an artist<ed><U+00A0><U+00BC><ed><U+00BE><U+00A8> and photographer<ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B3><U+00B7>. I enjoy hanging out with my husband of nearly 30 years. Together, We enjoy cooking <ed><U+00A0><U+00BC><ed><U+00BD><U+00B3>camping <U+26FA>, coffee on the porch<U+2615>,our pets<ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B0><U+00B6><ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B0><U+00B1> and each other's company. I may be disabled by epilepsy but I don't let it keep me down long.
author: Pamela Rowlett

label: negative
message: I have an invention that I patented, and will be posting on GoFundMe soon. I also want to make a portion of proceeds to go toward epilepsy awareness and scholarships for students with epilepsy. I wonder if I could get direction, or connections?
author: T Brian Sudbrink

label: neutral
message: I'm the oldest child, brother to 4 sisters, full-time college student (studying computer science), part-time employee, ice hockey goalie, and a bit of a geek.  I have Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy and it doesn't change a thing.
author: Josh Wheeler

label: positive
message: I am a dancer, choreographer, hiker, wife, mother to two amazing felines, and an advocate for education/awareness, tolerance, and empathy.  I got epilepsy the same year as I was accepted into the Joffrey Ballet - a dream cut short too soon.  It took over 30 years for my epilepsy to get to the control level I am at now.  I never thought that I would be dancing, let alone performing, again.  Yet, at the age of 50 I began studying dance again after a 25-year hiatus and find myself in my mid-50's in a new dance community and dance troupe.  Epilepsy has made me a strong, empathetic woman.  I just recently joined this community.  Thank you for your encouragement and support.
author: Irena Shayndela Snyder

label: negative
message: I am a mother, grandmother, writer, wife and love life! Love music, dancing, singing and caring for those who have a hard time doing it themselves and always around to lend and extra hand, I am an epileptic.
author: Anita Shields

label: negative
message:
I have been a wife for five yrs now but with my love for fifteen yrs.  We have one son together (14), I have a son (19), and my husband has three - two boys (19 & 17) and a girl (18).  At their ages you can feel them slipping away into adulthood and it is hard sometimes, there will never be enough time in the world to spend with them.  We are total animal lovers with three dogs, one cat, and sixteen birds!!  They are all an extension of our family; some talk, some play, some cuddle, and some have truly been a comfort to me.  I love helping others and felt I had found a my true calling in the medical office field, even got my BA in Health Care Administration with a GPA I never expected out of myself :-)  My life changed early January 2010 when I had my first grand-mal ever at the age of 32.  Even though I tried so hard not to I lost my job, I lost the independence of driving myself around, and I started to swirl down the rabbit hole of depression.  I still am not medically released to return to work or drive, but I mentally fight allowing epilepsy to define me everyday.  Honestly, it has made me look for my own self worth in places other than work, it has made me appreciate everyday I wake up and don't have my husband stairing scaredly in my eyes, and it has made me more aware of every blessing I am given.  
It is comforting to read your stories and see more strength and/or ideas as to how others can find help.  Good luck to everyone reading and posting, may you all have a great day.
author: Amy Demaris

label: neutral
message: I married woman, a mother, College grad, an avid MJ fan. I'm a humanitarian and environmentalist. And I'm epileptic.

I won't be surprised if I have another one soon with the number of seizures I'm having now.

label: negative
message: I'm actually hoping to get my son understand his type of epilepsy. I noticed many of the websites out there do not cover seizures that occur in sleep. They disturb sleep and exhaust you, as if you've not gotten any sleep. Time clocks thrown off and since most drs including neurologists don't understand it, except for the one who diagnosed him. Ive been having difficulty with primary care. So having trouble finding information on seizures that are simple and turn into complex -put him to sleep- occur in his sleep. Also known as nocturnal epilepsy, but partial not generalized or gran mal. Anyone?
