author: Sharon Hicks

label: negative
message: I have a question....my dog is not a "trained seizure" dog....but he seems to sense when I am about to have a seizure.  Is this possible?  TOO many times I have been with him and he has started staring at me barking and it was right before I went into a seizure.  My boyfriend declares it is too many times not to be that the dog is sensing the seizures beforehand.  This dog is an extremely unusual dog in nature already.  We have raised him from a puppy and he is four years old.  He is overly smart and unusual.  But I have seizures OFTEN,,,,usually just the smaller seizures.....I don't have but the grand mals but about once a month if that often,  But the absence seizures....I may have several a day if there are high pressure systems....but If I am around that dog....he seems to sense it....he will just sometimes stare at me and stay close to me.....like he has to protect me.....its strange.  Didn't know if it was my imagination.....or if it was possible????? without training?  Perhaps he has just been with us long enough that he can just tell I am sickly those days because it does make me very weak.  Just curious....  But he seems to know it BEFORE they start is the weird thing....BEFORE I do oftentimes.....   Oh....his name is T-Bone....LOL....he is half Rhodesian Ridgeback and half Red Nose Pit ....a very unique one of a kind dog....the Vet loves him!!!  =)

label: negative
message: I have a 6yr old daughter "Kaylee", she was Born with CP, Epleipsy and other disabilities. Her left side of her brain is gone she only has 1mm of her left frontal lobe and her whole right side, we knew her seizures started in the left chambers and they connect with the right frontal, we've just learned the she is also having starting points in the right frontal and it's consumed with EP firing and spiking and there are muitipal places on the rest of the right we don't know yet if it surface of coming from the core, she also now has many scared areas, she has problems with sleep emoshion's and focusing she is on meds and they work ok but not that ok she's been having more I feel so alone trying to do what ever I can to hep this last one Friday morning caused her right side to be completely paralyzed for about 3-4 min. She's been having one on her Speach area too. I live in am area where there isn't anything for people with EP and not much know about it. I need help , information.. I want to make a difference I want to do something to help with her expenses and others because here its 4&1/2 hours to see anyone that can help her. She has Focal, multi Focal, Complex Gen, Clonic tonic, and Absent, and I forget the other name,.. How can I get more information? How can I spread the information? Please tag me in any information you can give. I've been begging for help I want to help my baby girl and others... Thank you for listening...

label: negative
message: I have the same type of seizures, caused by Encephalitis Spinal Meningitis at six months old.I had two granmal seizures that lasted for several hours. I was not expected to live or to come out of the convulsions without major brain damage. I survived without any effects. The Partial Complex seizures started at the onset of puberty. I thought I was going insane( hearing, seeing and smelling things that were not there. Knowing what was going to happen before it actually did, De ja Vu. Losing the memory of blocks of time and even whole days. etc) I didn't tell anyone about these episodes for almost three years. It took another year for doctors to find and diagnose the disorder, after calling me a liar and trouble maker.

author: Kathy Millard

label: negative
message: I have, for the most part given up.  I was diagnosed about 12 years ago, and in that time, I've seen 4 different neurologists, and all have said different things about my condition, and between those doctors, I've been on about 15 different medications, none of which seem to do the trick with me.  I'm on three right now.  I've had the VNS since September of 2012, and things just seem to be getting worse with my condition. Whenever I would have a seizure, and the magnet for the VNS would be used, 90% of the time it doesn't work.  The thing I hate most about my condition is that I NEVER know when the seizures are coming on. , I've been on permanent disability since 2010 for my condition, got approved for SSD 2 months later, and just started my full SSD this month.  I had a horrible car accident 4 years ago due to a seizure, & DMV said I'd never be able to drive again, even if I'm seizure free for a year.   It seems that I've lost my best friend, and a lot of friends besides her, b/c I can't drive, and they don't want to take the time to drive a measly 10-15 to come to my house.  I'm just thankful that I still have a great friend I can count on whenever I need him.

author: Traci Maxwell

label: negative
message: I am 55 and have never been able to drive. I went through brain surgery 5 years ago. When I woke from sugery everyone wanted to know how I was feeling. The first thing out of my mouth was can I go back to work and the drs said no. I asked it I was going to be able to get my drivers licence now and again they said no. I have gone 4 years without a seizure. Working and driving are stressful situations, and I can not be under any stress of it could trigger a seizure. After 50 years of uncontrolled seizures I am seizure free. I'll take not having seizures over driving any day. I wish I could drive tho. Having to depend on others is a pain, I don't like to have to ask for help.
author: Megan Geary Blafkin

label: negative
message: It was 1 year, here in CA; I lost my driver license just after public transit schedules had been cut way back, due to the economy = eventually lost my job due to my very large public sector employer being unwilling to 'accommodate' me w/ a slightly modified schedule so I could catch the (only once an hour) bus on time.  And, the commute was an hour each way, way too much time 'on the road'... I was so stressed out I was having seizures in the back of the bus practically every evening on the way home..  now unemployed but (almost) seizure free...
author: Eileen Murray

author: Patricia Pollard

label: negative
message: I've been fortunate to have always lived in states where it's not mandatory that the doctor report your seizures to the DMV. My seizures suddenly started for no reason when I was 28, and I was a full-time city bus driver. I lived alone and owned my home, I needed my job! I realize now how irresponsible this was, but I kept working (driving) until 2006, when I came clean with my employer. I was hoping to be able to get a different job within the company, but it wasn't so. That's been the only real job I've had, I was there for over ten years. So, I'm having to retrain myself for a whole new career…  but that means going to engineeing school, and an 86 mile one-way commute. Thankfully, I've been seizure-free since January 19, 2013 and my meds keep them controlled, to the point where if I stopped taking my meds, I could predict the next seizure to within hours. I live in New Orleans, in a suburban area with poor bus service, yet it's still too dangerous to be out as a single female. I have a 1-2 second aura before the seizures start, and that has saved me from injuries more than a few times. I'm terrified of what may happen, I know that I won't likely live out my life seizure-free, but I don't know how I'd get anywhere if I can't drive, since my support system is virtually nonexistent.
author: Kari Kuntz

label: negative

label: positive
message: To learn more about reporting side effects, please visit our Adverse Events Reporting tab. Remember you can always report any side effects that you experience directly to your doctor and the FDA by visiting www.FDA.gov/medwatch or by calling 1-800-FDA-1088.
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message: I have epilepsy,  it began getting worse about 6 years ago.   I have a unusual case, in that there are two different parts of my brain,  in different areas,  one on either side of my brain.  I am also struggling with the mood swings.   It is affecting my relationship with my fiance,  along with our 3 year old son.   We're starting a business slowly,  however I am becoming more forgetful daily.   It is beginning to become more depressing,  and the outbursts are happening more often. . The emotions are becoming more than we can handle. .   My neurologist tells me it's a side effect of the medication,  however she has been questionable on several occasions before.   I'm happy to find out more about this topic,  so I can deal with it more easily.   Also,  because of the extent of my case,  a lot of the medication has failed in the past.  I've been told that the last option would be the VNS device.    I am scared to think about it. The advice I seek is about the device itself.   Has it worked out for others,  and are there any other people that this has helped?
author: Crys Dixon

label: negative
message: I understand what you are going thought. I have been there. I had brain surgery and found out that I also have an auto immune disorder that causes seizures. Think positive thoughts. You are in my prayers.

label: positive
message: Ive had epilepsy since I was 2 mon old, now that im 28 they are just getting worse. Mine too are intractable, ive been on all the meds which im either allergic to or have bad side effects. After this medication im on my last choice would be VNS which I refuse so my is working with me in hopes i dont become allergic or have a bad side effect to this last medication. My son also has epilepsy.

label: neutral

message: My son suffers from the same emotional outbursts. What did you do to help deal with it?
author: Pamela Gagnier

label: negative
message:
I nap nearly daily, and usually go to bed before 11am. No alarm clock. Dog is quiet until after 8am. I'm on SSDI. Volunteering at hospital now.
People don't understand why I need those naps. I worked as a head injury RN, and I'm the patient now. The medications make me tired. I get over stimulated by lights, TV noise, activity. I try to avoid horrific headaches, and be more functional and active, agreeable when awake.
author: Brandy Weise Taylor

label: neutral
message: Im a single parent w help and up at 5.

label: neutral
message: A shower cool room and a down comforter works for me

author: Stephanie Jeffries Campbell

label: neutral

label: negative
message: Every time I see my neurologist he asks if I'm getting enough sleep. I've cut back on caffeine and it seems to be helping.

label: negative
message: I've noticed that when I don't get enough sleep I get really drowsy and easily agitated, I wish my husband understood that when he keeps bothering me or waking me up out of my sleep talking loud (which sounds like screaming when you're half sleep) makes my nerves bad.

label: positive
message: To learn more about reporting side effects, please visit our Adverse Events Reporting tab. Remember you can always report any side effects that you experience directly to your doctor and the FDA by visiting www.FDA.gov/medwatch or by calling 1-800-FDA-1088.

label: neutral

label: negative
message: Yep, that's the same line my 30 year old son has been given.  If he doesn't disclose his condition and then has a seizure, he's let go for the very reason you stated Wales. If he does disclose his condition, he's not hired for the very same reason.  Applied for disability ... denied. State says he's able to work. It's a vicious cycle.
author: Connie Bradford

label: positive
message: And yet everywhere I go to get a job  they say they can't hire me because of the epilepsy is a danger not only to myself but others as well.
author: Wales Weatherly Carter

label: negative
message: I have disclosed in the past but now I'm not going to.  You are treated different and discriminated against.  All because so many people are uneducated
author: Stacey Burroughs

label: positive
message: I was put on excused administrative leave until I get a full release, to work without restriction, from my physician just because I told my employer that I thought working the new hours (12 days on, 2 days off) will increase the chance of me having a seizure and I didn't want the same thing to happen like in 2011. In 2011 I had a seizure and they sent me home, no one called 911 or my wife to come get me.  I just was asking to stay with the hours I have been working. HR keeps telling me to use FMLA time not ADA reasonable accommodation.
author: Tom Carl

label: neutral
message: Yea if ur able to work u sure arent protected. People dont understand why we need certain accomandations, fear clouds everything.
author: Athena Ramirez

label: negative
message: I'm fixing to file a lawsuit because my manager has harassed me to the point that he wants to see me have a seizure. He made a joke about my epilepsy one day, I was very upset. He has a history of harassing people. However I seem to be his favorite target. I feel as if a lawsuit is the only way to stop his bullying. He has a record for domestic abuse and he enjoys making women cry.
author: Tristan Roberts

label: negative
message: I worked as an 'ADA Workplace Reasonable Accommodation' specialist, in the HR dept of the City of SF Municipal Transportation Dept; became very familiar w/ ADA workplace law.  But, when I requested my own accommodation - a slightly modified work schedule, so I could catch the once an hour bus back home as I'd lost my driver license after a series of gran mal seizures -- I was denied.  All they had to say is "undue burden" or "unreasonable"; they are not required to specify how or in what way.  Thanks in part to my own efforts, accommodations were made to many other employees -- if/when the 'managerial will' was there --  but I'd become known as too much of an 'advocate' for my clients/the ADA process, and they wanted to get rid of me.. and so they did. I consulted the Jeanne A Carpenter Epilepsy Legal Defense Fund noted above, but they were never able to help me.  Every atty I consulted said employers can do whatever they want, and reminded me that ADA law is only as good as those who abide by it..  very disappointing
author: Eileen Murray

label: neutral
message: I was doing my internship had a seizure in the medical field and now I can't get a job anywhere in the field.
author: Courtney Calvert

label: negative
message: more states need to get on board with this.. It is very dangerous to drive and have seizures..
author: Cheri Hager Miller

label: negative
message: Though evidently not required in Texas, when my neurologist found out I was still driving even though my seizures were not under control, he gave me 24 hours to turn my license into the DMV or he would report me.  I was FURIOUS at the time, but Thank the Lord the doctor did so. I would hate to think what might have happened over the years to others on the road, including family and friends, even me, had I continued to drive.  Yes, it's inconvenient at times, and takes me a lot longer to get from point A to point B than I like, but with help from family, friends, and public transportation, I can get anywhere I need to go, I just have to plan ahead.  If your seizures are not 100% controlled, DO NOT DRIVE!!!  You'll survive.  I've been doing it now for 25 years.
author: Tim Tilt

label: negative
message: I gave up my drivers license twelve years ago and I also had to give up my working career (at twenty-four years on the job) as result of my epilepsy (seizures). I could never risk hurting or possibly killing someone due to "my" disability. It hasn't been easy, but I know that I made the right move.
author: Edward Crane

label: negative
message: It is sad that it's harder to get drunks off the road.  One should also remember that people with heart conditions prone to passing out are not required to be reported nor are diabetics.
author: Rick Sheehy

label: neutral
message: Fl now goes way overboard w this law. Ill nvr be seizure free, so it doesnt matter but still the way this state does it is rediculous
author: Athena Ramirez

label: negative
message: This needs to be the law in Every state!! After having a right frontal lobectomy 4 years ago, I've been seizure free and no meds. But that's AFTER I almost killed myself (and quite possibly could have been someone else if other cars were around) bc I insisted I had my epilepsy 'under control' and had aura. Only takes 30 seconds of unconscious to kill someone. I thank God everyday for that guardian angel. I will continue to support epilepsy foundation and this needs to be one law taken very seriously!
author: Stefanie Herdman

label: negative
message: I'd like to know if there are ANY employers who are willing to make these types of accommodations because I have yet to find them.    P.S. Not every city has public transportation either.
author: Connie Bradford

label: negative
message: Yea! I still do, I love the feeling you get with exercise. Anything your angry about gets released into your health and it helps me by putting that stress somewhere healthy and more focused. It also helps me narrow my focus on the situation instead of being overwhelmed by the problem.
author: Gehvyn Gabrielle Kauimeleokalani Stream

label: positive
message: No yoga or tai chi but especially in the winter months I join exercise groups at the local Y. Spin class can be a great calorie burner and stress relief. In warmer months I personally prefer to be outdoors so I focus on bicycling, running and kayaking. Choose an exercise you enjoy and is safe for your personal situation. Consult a doctor first if you have not been exercising. Any exercise is a great stress relief and will improve your health.
author: Bryan Griffin

label: positive
message: Definitely yes and I echo what everyone else has suggested since stress can be a major trigger. Exercise, yoga, tai chi all help to maintain healthy oxygenated blood to your brain, centers you spiritually and psychologically,  and diverts your energy and fears away from our conditions.  My only additional suggestion would to be sure to wear or place an order to have some sort of medical alert bracelet or necklace which states your condition with access to additional important information regarding meds, emergency contacts and phone numbers including MD names in case something should happen during. This way not only are you doing something beneficial to improve your mind and body,  but gives you the additional protection of safety should you be out in the gym or running/walking in the community.
author: Gordon Weiner

label: neutral
message: yes!  they (yoga, jacuzzi, swimming, mild cardio) continue to help me in the pursuits of a healthy lifestyle.  stay in touch with your medical team and do not deviate from the plan.  This is responsible for keeping me seizure free for years.
author: Darren Kinder

label: neutral
message: I kickbox twice a week. It helps me with stress
author: Beth Shifflett Nace

label: neutral
message: My Dr kept telling me to do yoga so I finally did it and it helps out alot
author: Erica Weaver

label: neutral
message: Yes, my sons neurologist recommends it.
author: Catherine Carraro

label: negative
message: I've been doing yoga since high school to help control both my seizures and the pain in my joints from them.  It helps calm and center me when my nerves get out of whack and reduce my overall stress - leading to less seizures.  My husband even got into it last year doing DDP Yoga and was amazed at how much it reduced his old injury pain.
author: Jennifer Chandler

label: neutral
message: I enjoy yoga, but boxing is by far my favorite!

label: negative
message: U don't need to be rich to get ur fitness on...power walk, jog, stretch at home, buy a yoga DVD that's how I did it when unemployed :)

Then there's my 10 year old granddaughter that keeps be busy going & watching her play on her traveling softball team. Life is good , glory be to God

label: neutral
message: My cousin has the same type of epilepsy as I do. LTLE...she does Tai Chi and says it helps her so much. I have yet to try it :)

label: neutral
message: Yoga is great health benefit! It is a total body workout and it helps balance out the stress factors of daily life and work.

label: negative
message: The gym at least three times a week including Spin/RPM (exercise bike) class, and lots of walking seeing that I can't drive.  The exercise helps me relax, partially because I'm and old geezer ;) who gets worn out, but I just feel a lot better if I get some exercise after I eat, especially in the evening.
author: Tim Tilt

label: negative
message: Prayer is nice but this is a serious medical condition that is very scary and very debilitating to many people I kind of feel like that answer trivializes it a bit.

label: neutral
message: True! But if everyone pray for them all that have that problem they will eventually go away.   God will bless us all.
author: Adrianne Bostick

label: neutral
message: False. In Frontal Lobe Epilepsy seizures can be a Grand Mal while the person is completely conscious.
author: Vicky View

label: negative
message: I  do believe everyone seizures are different.  Everyone  had gotten them at different ages and different ways. Also taking different medications.
author: Adrianne Bostick

label: negative
message: If your seizures aren't 100% controlled, DO NOT DRIVE!!!  A relative of mine who is a fire fighter and paramedic, has made runs to multiple auto accidents, where a person with epilepsy, who's seizures were not fully controlled, ended up severely injured or dead, and severely injured or killed someone else in the process.  He's even seen some of the people with epilepsy arrested, because they were driving without a license, caused an accident while having a seizure, but were not injured, though the driver/passenger/s in the other vehicle was/were.  IT'S    A G A I N S T   THE LAW!!!  Don't take the chance of ruining/ending your life or the lives of others.  Sadly, I'm speaking from personal experience.  I was one of the ones with seizures that were not 100% controlled, who continued to drive at the expense of someone else's health and welfare.  Thankfully - that's hard for me to say - when my neurologist found out I was still driving, he made me surrender my license to the highway patrol.  He even checked with them to make sure I had.  I haven't driven since 1989, I live in one of the top ten largest cities in the country, but with public transportation, help from friends and family, and good old healthy walking, I can get anywhere I want/need to go.
author: Tim Tilt

label: negative
message: My seizures were under control & I had a grand mal driving. My license was taken away. I had to go before a jury at the DMV one year later. I haven't had a grand mal since, but it shows that even when they are under control you never know. I also just bought an electric blanket, but I keep hearing that you can't use them if you have epilepsy. I would hate to repeat history.
author: Stephanie Writes

label: negative
message: I, so, agree with Tim....I obtained my driver's license in 1975, & had no driving issues until 2005. I was over stressed from caring for an ill parent, plus trying to complete my master's degree. One morning I left home to run errands, only to have a seizure while driving, & found myself submerged in a body of water. I was lucky. God wasn't ready for me, yet! And, yes, I did not drive, again, until my seizures were under control. Since I lived in a mid-sized community, with limited epilepsy expertise, I relocated to a large metropolitan area, & now have a superb epileptologist.  Until my seizures were under control, I learned to use the train & bus systems. Plus, I've always been an avid walker. Today I am driving, and plan on returning to my hometown within the next 2 weeks. I will continue to see my epileptologist --- 200 miles away.  Should my condition provoke uncontrolled seizures, I will not be driving --- period! It's not worth losing a life!
author: MaryAnn He

label: negative
message: So true many won't give you one at all and others have strong restrictions. I know because I've been there done that
author: A Roy Brown

label: negative
message: I had to give up my driver's license several times even though I only had seizures when I was asleep.   We have a handicapped bus service but I never had to use it thanks to family and friends.  I have been seizure free for 12 years after having brain surgery!  :)
author: Janet Adams Bonzo

label: neutral
message: The ADA is a worthless law at helping protect people with epilepsy.  If an employer is uncomfortable with your epilepsy, they can legally discriminate or fire you as long as they don't blame it on your epilepsy.

label: negative

label: negative

Unfortunately that cant happen anymore... my nuero hasnt allowed me to drive though its officially been a year since anything has happened. How and where am i supposed to work without people finding out and firing me because of it.

label: negative

label: negative
message: I have lost several jobs of the years, due to my epilepsy. They always find another reason to fire you. Then later tell you that it was because of the epilepsy. I have gotten to where I just don't tell them anymore. Just within the last month, I got turned down because of my epilepsy, I didn't tell them about it, but I had worked for the company before and that's how they knew about it. And told me and the client that they could not hire me because of my epilepsy.
author: Dorrie Leighton

label: positive
message: What if a former employer didn't do this even after trying?
author: Theresa Atwood

label: negative
message: My son Matthew died 4 years ago with complications of Epilepsy and pulmonary embolism after years of meds and more meds, vargus implant, brain surgery.  His Daughter has a site on Facebook called My Dad Died and I help put words of encouragement for loss of their Father and loved ones too.  My son was discriminated against by two major phone companies he worked for.  When he had a seizure he was fired both times and was doing a good job.  He passed away March 20, 2010 and he was working on his Master's degree in art he was a brilliant artist and loved his children more than anything in the world.
author: My Dad Died

label: positive
message: I always had an aura.  My seizures happened whenever I was asleep.  That meant at night or even taking a nap during the day!

My right temporal lobe simple partials seizures "auras" only gave a feeling of Deja Vu followed by my stomach dropping like going down in a fast elevator.

When I first starting having these temporal lobe partial seizures I didn't really believe that I was having a seizure because it wasn't like a "real" seizure ( so I was told). I struggle with memory a lot and used to think it was just due to head injury until a doctor told me about memory loss from them. I didn't get correct care for years.. My seizures started with feeling pulled away or something and naseau
author: Donette Smith

label: neutral
message: I guess mine would start in the temporal lobe, cause I have very little long term and short term memory. Its so rough on me it brings me to tears cause I can barely remember the best times with my 2 year old. <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+00AA>

label: positive

label: negative
message:
Cortical dysplasia, a brain deformity where the wrong tissue grows in the wrong area of the brain. I am EXTREMELY LUCKY to be a walking, talking, functioning human. Most people with my disorder are handicapped in a lot of ways. 
I didn't have episodes until I was 25.
author: Sara Dawn Randazzo

label: negative
message: When I was young I had gotten strep throat 6 years in a row. It gave me really high temperatures each time as high as 102.Then several month after it went away on the 6th year, I had my 1st seizure which was a grand-mal seizure during spring break when I was in the car with my dad. For years I had grand-mal until I had brain surgery but that only weaken'd  the seizures to partial onset seizures. I had them for a couple of years. Then after those kind of seizures, I started having Tonic clonic seizures. I have been having seizures for 20 years now.
author: Mike Anderson

label: neutral
message: Had brain tumor removed in 2008. Seizures started in 2009. In 2013 had surgery and have been seizure free since!
author: Mary Doane

label: negative
message: Falling down the stairs in high school.  My head didn't like the cement stairs......
author: Beth Mcc

label: neutral
message: Mine started after giving birth to my daughter.
author: Julie Morris

label: positive
message: Stress but I can say been seizure free for a year now praise the Lord
author: Judi Brewer

label: negative
message: The onset of mine is more of a mystery than their triggers are.  My suspicion is a form of a birth defect.  From what my sister told me a few years back, my mom had been as sterile as hospital sheets when she tried to have me.  Then, all of a sudden, in 1972 she was pregnant.  I had one neurologist back in 1981 who suggested that it may have been caused by a possible stroke during birth.  Fast-forward technology about 30 years later, and my current neurologist disagrees with that prognosis.  Saying that a stroke typically leaves scar tissue behind.  But, according to my latest MRI, there was no scar tissue to support the stroke theory.  So, again, we have what may be the cause but no definitive proof of exact cause.
author: John Tillotson Sr.

label: neutral
message: My seizures started at age 16. I was getting ready for school when my big explosion of about 20 - 25 attacks happened. I was taken to the er and diagnosed with myclonic seizures. No family history of seizures, but I do have cerebral palsy.
author: Linda Perez

label: negative
message: sclerosis/atrophy; etiology-unknown; TLE onset @ age 21; dx age 22; left AMTL age 23; VNS age 35; complete sz control age 36
author: Emily Cestia

label: negative
message: Scar tissue on my brain due to the use of forceps when I was delivered.
author: Amber Burgess

label: negative

author: Maya Banda Medina

label: negative
message: Brain tumor, I had a VNS put in, and better meds ( they found the tumor in me 24 yrs ago) and I still seizures but not as bad.)
author: Michael Johnson

label: negative
message: My husband was diagnosed at age 12. Drs said due to use of forceps during birth...scar on brain. Had VNS implant last august. Better than a year ago. Literature says it can take up to at least 2 years to see full results.
author: Christi Jones

label: negative
message: Trama brain injury. Have the VNS. But doesn't always work for me.
author: Judy Jones

label: neutral

author: Christi Moore

label: neutral
message: Alcohol poisoning. Never let anyone you love drink Jaegermeister.
author: Martha Billian Meyer

label: neutral
message:
You forgot to mention TBI (Traumatic Brain Injury). This can happen to anyone at any age. Unfortunately,  for me this occurred multiple times
while serving in the Marine Corps in Vietnam in the late 60's. It did not start giving me seizures until I had a fender bender 35 years later (in which case I hit my head again).  I am treated at the VA Traumatic Brain Injury center in Martinez CA by some of the best neurologists west if the Mississippi. I've been Grand Mal free for 6 years and have had only 1 partial seizure since then.
author: Michael Callow

label: negative
message: I'm 55 and have been seizure free for over 16 years. I would like to discontinue my meds if they aren't necessary. So a neurologist has scheduled a brain MRI and a sleep deprivation EEG. I have had a few regular EEGs, but next Friday will be my 1st SD EEG -any pointers about staying up all night?
author: Christi Lytal Brotherton

label: negative
message: Im in need of some help. I had started having auroras again two weeks ago...the disorientation and not feel well. I worked out of town and so I resigned because I was aware that I don't need to drive when im having these symptoms.  What are some resources for me? Im waiting to find out  if  will be approved for my unemployment while im seeking work in the area which allows me to use public transportation or other resources for me due to my disability.
author: Pamela Williams

label: negative
message: I still have beeak though grand mal seizures and the only answer I ever get is that it's stress. Is there any other reason that I would have one about every year?

label: negative
message: I start feeling extreme anger and hatred with no reason behind it. I don't become violent, but I get really confused after. Sometimes, it turns into a bad seizure, and my dog starts jumping on me until I lay down. I keep a record when it happens, if the confusion lets me. I have been told I have right-frontal and right-temporal seizures. Is this connected to those areas?
author: Matthew Lane

label: negative
message: Pre & post left AMTL, my complex partials caused postictal déjà vu, & crying (involuntary); then 10 yrs later after getting VNS, auras precede CPS (déjà vu, & sensory-motor symptoms). I swipe magnet & it stops ictal activity.  Yes szs can control emotions, expressions, feelings, etc. Even preictal & postictal periods!!

label: negative
message: I don't currently have a neurologist. Finding one who is credible and reputable has proven to be difficult as I have a medical card. I never thought to write them down. (I'd be writing all day nearly everyday.) I have a VNS implant which has been ineffective. I struggle with several types of seizures and have yet to respond positively to any meds. I am frustrated and tired and struggling to keep up with my 2 year old.

label: negative
message: Trtry to keep calm really not much i can do

label: negative
message: I have a 15 yr old and a 5 yr old who have Epilepsy, neither one of them are able to tell doctors how the feel before, during or after a seizure. My 5 yr old had a seizure about a month ago and during the day she kept telling me to give her her pills, even though she had already had them. That evening while in the ER for other reasons she spiked a fever and went into one.

label: negative

Compared to other types, I'm at least conscience through it, and fully aware of my surroundings while it is going on.

label: negative
message: I have those kind of seizures but my meds help me with them some time

message: This is good information, my daughter is 6, & was born with CP and Epilepsy, we've always known stress among other things can cause problems, but we had a wedding this past weekend and boy did she act up a lot, she has 4 type's and its over 475mv in the right frontal lobe at times her base line is always over 2.5, & higher, the rest o  the right side is I guess you calling sparking starts  But is multiple places and the left well she only has one left chambers/core and its always active also.... Good information.... I wish I could learn so much or to help her ... where can I gets books ex f. To learn as much as possible??? Please tag me in any response , I don't ever get answers to questions cause my phone... unless I'm tagged ... Thank

label: positive
message: I just learned something new today :)

label: positive

label: negative
message: some times that is correct! an EEG can only detect above the bain transmission.Some seizures like mine could not be detected by a EEG,do to transmission where deep in brain. i found that the hard way after surgery and going threw 20 seizures a day then a stroke on top of that. But still great advice!

label: negative

label: negative
message: My dad thinks I still have these but my neurologist already told my as a kid I don't show signs.

label: negative
message: I used to complex partial seizures by the hour each month for a few days. After removing my right temporal lobe in 1999 they stopped. Something small is starting to happen after all these years. Can a panic attack cause you to lose control of a full side of your body that's jerking? Never been diagnosed with panic attacks but it just seems like it would be more that than seizure since I know what's happening. I just don't know how to stop the jerking on my left side. I don't want to go back to having seizures.

label: neutral
message: I had Complex, & Gran Mol seizures.

label: neutral
message: My daughter is diagnosed with this type of epilepsy.

label: positive
message: I have had deja vu for years before I learned this. I do not have epilepsy (migraines, though) but both of my daughters have epilepsy and migraines. I'm always fascinated how all these things could be connected.
author: Jennifer Davis

label: negative
message: Mine sound a little like Joy Kirlin Stewart.  I would get a feeling much like a panic attack and get really hot.  Then a crazy off the wall thought would fly through my head and I would had a moment of déjà vu.  I would try to quickly sit down and hold tight to the arm rest.  Next thing I always remembered was waking up to EMS standing around me!  I would have had a grand mal seizure that lasted for several minutes.  Thank goodness my grand mals have been controlled with medicine.  I still get déjà vu and partial seizures though.
author: Dianna Alexander

label: negative
message: I use have deja vu in the beginning of my epilepsy. I new something was going on. I had a rush feeling going up my arm. I, just had to sit down and/or lie down. Not that bad. It go away. Now, mostly in sleep. I don't know if one coming on until afterwards. I would wake up with bitten lip.
author: Joy Kirlin Stewart

label: negative
message: I have experienced both and have complex partial seizures.  Brain surgery got rid of the seizures but not those feelings!
author: Janet Adams Bonzo

label: positive
message: Déjà vu was almost a daily experience for me the first 25 years of my life before I was diagnosed with epilepsy (left temporal lobe complex-partial seizures) in 1979, after a seizure caused me to have a serious car accident.
author: Tim Tilt

label: negative
message: I have the deja vu all the time and I have complex=oartial seizures
author: Kris Luck

label: negative
message: Looks like getting control!
author: Dean Leong

label: positive
message: Doe'r  keep going forward!
author: Joy Kirlin Stewart

label: neutral
message: Medicine,rest,VNS,Neurologist
author: Bonnie Burt

label: positive
message: Kicked it's butt big-time!
author: Suzy Welch

label: negative
message: My name is Kim. My son is an epileptic! He was diagnosed with seizure disorder @ 17 yrs of age .... nearly all are grand mals .... some very extensive injuries  over the years too! Took my son who is almost 30 to say to people "I am an epilptic." My son, J, has worked a job, attended college & inspite of is 'never knowing when' he will go into his grand mal seizures ... nearly ALL of my family  & my other three children have all witnessed & assisted him during these numerous times! I am very proud of my son in so many ways!  J as a young adult with seizure disorder; to a grown man who takes life one day @ a time! In a brief second my son goes from talking to you to gasping for air, starts grandmalling while he falls to the ground! NOT easy when one NEVER knows when to expect them. LOSS OF HIS INDEPENDENCE on / off over the years has been a challenge too! ONE day at a time!
author: Kim Brown

label: positive
message: My daughter started having tonic-clonic seizures out of the blue one day when she was 17 she still has them usually while sleeping or upon waking, especially if she exhausts herself. She's 24 now, they are managed with meds, and she works part-time.
author: Sara Barker

label: negative
message: About a year ago I was told I had temporal lobe epilepsy and was put on meds till we found the right ones to get the episodes under control once things got under control and calmed down, life was back to normal here it is over a year later and all of a sudden out of no where I'm having episodes again was admitted to the hospital and while I'm hooked up to the EEG I have an episode the doctor walks over lifts my eye lid and says it's not seizures gets mad and walks out of the room and sends me home and tells my family he is referring me to a physchitrist for depression meds.... I have multiple witnesses that includes medical professionals that say I'm having seizures..... After an episode I can't remember nothing that has happened in the several hours, I'm tired, have a headache, and just out of it..... Any help would be greatly appreciated
author: Brandy Vargas Axton

label: negative
message: I have them -  started 6 years ago at 46 -  changed my life completely.  I went from a successful person and life to no job at the moment and  crap jobs.
author: Jackie Moore

label: negative
message: This is how my epilepsy started. I was at work and had a simple, but strong feeling known as deja vu. It happened a few more times there and kept getting more intense. I'll never forget it and I now know that I should have seen my doctor.
author: Mark Allison

label: negative
message: Sara Barker I also was diagnosed with epilepsy when I was 17 just a month before my 18th birthday.  I have seizures in my sleep and just upon walking up in the morning now.  I have complex partial and simple partial epilepsy,  but I haven't really had many during the day because I can sort of control them when I feel them coming on. And sort of wish them away. But I find that the ones I have in my sleep is because my body temperature goes up and I get too hot, especially when walking up my body can't regulate my temperature quick enough and I have seizure.
author: Airianna Mae Culp

label: neutral
message: My neurologist says mine is not epileptic seizures but panic and anxiety attack seizures
author: Denise Gilliland

label: negative
message: I cant look at any stobe lights or emergency vehicle lights because they ll throw me into my seizures specially if it is dark outside.
author: Denise Gilliland

label: negative
message: All I have to do is walk into gamestop,  that lighting in the store makes me dizzy,  start sweating and feel confused.  I try to avoid that store at all costs, no matter the state it's in I get the same feeling.
author: Stacey Burroughs

label: positive
message: Exactly Roxanne Frazier Hodges...and it leaves me so tired...I had seizures in the past but haven't had any in a couple years and I'm hoping these aren't seizures...my son and mother have epilepsy and it's horrible
author: Christine Bush-Croushore

label: negative
message: I have those and they come exactly where the picture says they come.. The front top right and the left back of the brain. They also don't make me go unconscious, but give me headaches or get me really tired, sleepy, or drowsy when its just one after another for like an hour non stop.
author: Daniel Enrique Patino

label: negative
message: Does it feel like "bolts of lighting pain shooting through the head lasting 10 to 30 seconds???
author: Christine Bush-Croushore

label: neutral
message: Thanks for being with me Susan Coats Lyman! Love you!!
author: Laurie Coats Stachowski

label: positive
message: I am so lucky. I work at whole foods market and they know my history. ive had at least 3 at work. thankfully im seizure free after my last big one at work. they know what to do. also, every day at 3pm there is always a supervisor that comes by and either reminds me, which is good because sometimes you just don't remember, or asks me if it's a good time for me to take a small break so I can take my meds.
author: Stephanie Shaner

label: neutral
message: The ADA is worthless to people with Epilepsy.  Employers can fire someone with Epilepsy, without making any accommodations, for a million reasons as long as they don't blame the firing on your Epilepsy.
author: Tim Myers

label: negative
message: My place of employment has been very good with my seizures.  They keep an eye out on me if my eyes look like they are glazed over because that either means I have had on or going to have one, my face gets really pail.
author: Denise Gilliland

label: positive
message: My son has been 'released' from multiple jobs after having a seizure. Employers don't want to take the risk.  Without exception they cited that my son poses a safety risk to himself and/or his co-workers. He told one employer up front that he had a seizure disorder. They hired him. Three days later they said had to let him go due to safety issues. Trying to get Social Security Disability for him. Tried Vocational Rehab and they said he had to be seizure free at least 1 month before they would help him. Tim Myers post is correct.
author: Connie Bradford

label: neutral
message: I've told my past employers, and they managed to 1. Even though explained not to hold me down, they did and bruised me. And 2. Fired me when I missed work.
author: Diane K O'Hara

label: negative
message: My weekend has been thanking every vet and military person I see for a job they did not have to do...but did. This is a weekend about remembering those that gave all...
author: Christie Mayo

label: neutral
message: As a person who has epilepsy here are my four words: My consciousness is precious.
author: Stephanie Freeman

label: positive
message: Had a bunch of simple partials Sunday and yesterday.  Nothing so far today, but they usually come in clusters that can last for several days. Slows me down a bit, 'cause it  makes me have to "think harder" about every day "normal" tasks, but Thank the Lord, no complex partials.
author: Tim Tilt

label: positive
message: Hope you feel better Tim Tilt. You are not alone.
author: Valerie Ware

label: neutral
message: They are fortunate..I have grandmal seizures and that is not the case it would be easier if it was...praying all seizures be taken away from everyone
author: Sherryann Smith

label: positive
message: Yup it does. I had one at work yesterday. And I also have complex partial seizures. It's nothing new to me since I have had epilepsy for more than half my life.
author: Nancy Barragan

label: neutral
message: My 5 year old has complex partial seizures.
author: Jenny Garls Dirst

label: neutral
message: I had three simple partial seizures yesterday.
author: Tina Miley

label: neutral
message: I have lost 3 jobs since I started the complex partial 6 years ago, totally out of the blue....  I went from a very successful person to what people think is an idiot....  It SUCKS!!
author: Jackie Moore

label: negative
message: Sounds like one of my sezuires..I'm.alert
author: Amanda Garrick

label: positive
message: Glad to hear there r others, me not alone.
author: Judy Jones

label: negative
message: I was having  undiagonised partial seizures for 2 years when I had 2 major surgeries in 5 days. The partial seizures became more frequent and stronger almost immediately after the surgeries.  It took another 1 1/2  years to get the diagonals. I know the exact date they started,July 28, 2010 because they started within hours of having a very, very minor stroke. My partial seizures mimic the stroke symptoms except after surgeries I started having olfactory hallucinations.
author: Margie Bass

label: positive
message: I'm going through a troubled marriage hoping this doesn't cause one.
author: Amanda Garrick

label: positive
message: I'm applying! My academics had to be put on hold because of money and taking care of my husband who has epilepsy with any luck my dreams will continue to move forward! Thank you for posting!
author: Jessica Johnson Douglas

label: negative
message:
It would be interesting to know how many of us have POS and GM seizures due to ruptured aneurysms and from the results of surgery.   Brian and Angela are you finding the medications are effecting your memory?
Do they effect your stamina or your ability to work?
author: Jesica Webster

label: negative
message: When I had mine...I was asleep. Bad grandma seizures too....then when I'd start snapping out of it....I couldn't tell you what day it was...or what I did the day before...just really lost.
author: Natasha Jones

label: neutral
message: I have GM.seizures so all that happens to me not fun at all
author: Erica Weaver

label: negative
message: Take care of yourself Brian! Temporal Lobe here too from surgery. It is rough but we are tougher than epilepsy.
author: Angela Troyer

label: neutral
message: Temporal Lobe from Ruptured aneurysm....POS and GM...
author: Brian Krueger

label: negative
message: Began having starring episodes again after not having them for a long time. Not cool.
author: Jen Showalter

label: positive
message: I had to retire at age 44.  It is tough.  But I still have bad auras and myoclonics.  Some of my auras are real bad.  I can't drive either.  So I have a hobby I can do now and sell them on Etsy.  It's not like working, but it's something.
author: Bill Woodrome

label: neutral
message: The American with Disabilities Act is worthless at helping people with Epilepsy stay employed.  If an employer hates an epileptic, they can fire them for a million bogus reasons as long as they don't blame it on Epilepsy.
author: Tim Myers

label: neutral
message: My question is how do you prove that is due to one having epilepsy?  Yes I can ask this due to having epilepsy myself. I think it would be hard to show that one was fired over it.
author: Shannen V Crampton

label: negative
message: Tim, I agree with you 100%! I am an Epilepsy group support group leader, I do it as a volunteer. I have 2 children. I have had seizures for about 13 years now. I have a Bachelors & Masters in Social Work. But, I have never had a paying job in my field for over 6 months now. I would say...it is a miracle if people who have Epilepsy can even find work!!! You are discriminated against and how do you even tell your employer that you have Epilepsy (by law you wouldn't have too)? Or, how do you hide it and even get to work????????? Give me a fricken break, does anyone have some secrets that I just am not getting????? Please tell, I would like to hear them!
author: Danielle Perdew DeGroot

label: negative
message: I wish I could they made me go on disability . Now that I am on disability I had to wait 2 years to get insurance I would love to have one seizure free day then six months so I can go back to work.I am only 48 I have been working since the age of 9 this not working can drive a person insane! One seizure free day may lead to another I hope.
author: Wayne Heitz

label: neutral
message: All an employer has to do is say that the person with epilepsy is a potential harm to himself or to other workers and he is let go. My son was upfront about his epilepsy and actually got hired by two companies and let go within three days due to this 'concern'. Add in the fact that he doesn't drive and his employment opportunities become even more limited. He is 29 and has had tonic/clonic and partial complex seizures since he was 14.  It is heartbreaking to see him try so hard and to be turned away.
author: Connie Bradford

label: neutral
message: I had to retire at 28 :-/ im 31 now. sucks a lot. and mine were mostly myoclonic and partial, but the bad days before, were just absolutely horrible.
author: Jessica Taylor

label: negative
message: I had to retire 4 years ago 2010 age 35 at the time and I went from having 3-5 gran mal seizures a week to now I have 2 a week! Its so horrifying and I'm still young and a mother of 3 but I really miss my job of 16 years at that time..
author: Cassandra Lee-Gulley

label: negative
message: I started my own business. Lucky I know when I am going to have one so I can still drive.
author: Vicki Watson

label: neutral
message: Can't prove it Corrie Stone Fielder
author: Khadijah Fielder

label: negative
message: would you be able to help me find work?
author: Kris Luck

label: positive
message: Epilepsy sucks !! Keep strong !!!
author: John Forgett

label: neutral
message: Omg growing up I was so embarrassed of having seizures and it went away for a lil while but the tingling and the jerking is new to me but my question is does it ever go away once ur diagnosed with it
author: Ashley Brown

label: neutral
message: I've thrown cups of coffee with those annoying jerks..
author: Lori Bruce George

label: neutral
message: I had JME and now it's moved onto it's adult-form :) yes epilepsy sucks !!!!!
author: Mir Rahman

label: negative
message: This happens to me alot. My girlfriend said she hears me laughing/jerk real quick then I wake up. I say I must have been dreaming. We haven't been together long so she doesn't know much about it. I've told her about all the warning signs. But she's going to get her way next time,I'm going to hospital. I've also had the laughing ones.
author: Aaron Cwiklinski

label: negative
message: My wife freaks every time. Thinking it is the beginning of a grand mal.
author: John Forgett

label: negative
message: I have the hand jerking almost every day even before falling asleep.
author: Tasha Johnson

label: neutral
message: Just during my complex-partials... if you se thoughs as the same.
author: Chad Martin

label: positive
message: I have them at times, like a Jacksonian seizure.
author: Cathy Wills Wydner

label: neutral
message: My son had laughing seizures when he was smaller
author: Kelsie Clark Webster

label: negative
message: Are these common in people with epilepsy ? I have seizures usually severe ones in the night.  .many times eight before falling asleep my body jerks me awake
author: John Forgett

label: negative
message: Not getting enough sleep for me is a major trigger
author: Dean Leong

label: neutral
message: Routine and having someone wonderful beside you helps a lot :)
author: John David Williams

label: negative
message: I usually go to bed about 10 n im up by 6 usually..Since I been doing this routine for awhile n it trained my mind n body when to be up n awake at around 6 n to start feeling tired around 10...It works n helps for me...
author: Brian Krueger

label: negative
message: yea...but it's hard not to resist a good cup of "Tim Horton's" coffee everyday, my weakness? (2 cups daily)? and plenty of fresh air helps me to fall asleep?.
author: Bradley King

label: negative
message: I can't sleep I go to bed at 10p finally go to sleep at 3 Am get up by 8 am so exhausted
author: Desiree Wilson

label: negative
message: yes my son Jason had one sunday because he was not getting enough sleep
author: Janetta Langley Skaggs

label: positive
message: i see all the things u guys do but i try and no luck still sleep day and  12
author: Sean Mccabe

label: negative
message: It's very difficult and challenging when you don't know. Something has to happen to me or someone has to tell me. I wake up with a really bad headache, chewed the inside of my mouth, and feel lethargic..indicators for sure.
author: Mandy Moyer

label: negative
message: I know what you mean Mandy Moyer. I hate it when you chew up your cheeks or tongue. They didn't know exactly where my seizures were comming from until they did brain mapping.  They took out my hippacampus and amigdla from my right tempola lobe. One is emotion and the other is memory.  You have them on both sides of the brain.  I'm just running on 1/2 power!   Lol. But I am blessed because I can function and I can drive.
author: Robin May Ruggie

label: negative
message: That is the part that is so hard for us as our son is 5 hours away at college but doesn't know when he has one so we have no way of tracking them to see if his medication is really working. :(
author: Carrie Galigher Newton

label: neutral
message: Not knowing when ,was the hardest  part of this , for me   with Jack.
author: Marsha Mccrone

label: negative
message: I get a nasty headache. Feels like a drill inside part of my brain for a few minutes. Take care of yourselves and never loose hope.
author: Aaron Cwiklinski

label: neutral
message: I orginally had grandmal seizures. Was very scared cause i woke up in a hospital not knowing what had happened. Over a period of time we saw those disappear and now I have generalized seizures but I usually know what is going on.
author: Elizabeth Burke

label: negative
message: The brain is such an odd thing, that even dr.s don't fully comprehend it. They just often won't admit to that.
author: Angela Taylor

label: negative
message: I know when i have one - but lose so much memory of the time around it and then forget i had one.
author: Theresa Litzinger

label: neutral
message: Thank you baby,  I didn't know all this!!!!  Love to my baby , Landen<U+2665><U+2665><U+2665><U+2665>
author: Mary Sexton

label: negative
message: My husband just started these one week ago so sad
author: Dovie Lockhart

label: negative
message: If I may pose a question. why would  my seizures be progressively be getting worse? Also why would one person have so many different types of seizures? why do I seem to be developing more and more triggers? Thank you for all you do and your time!
author: Wayne Heitz

label: neutral
message: Can a person experience ONLY psychic seizures ?
author: Marcia McMeen Hildebrandt

label: negative
message: How would I know for sure ? I have experienced "Grand Mal" and "Partial" seizures for many years now. I am also fighting battles with depression on and off. Please advise.
author: Edward Crane

label: negative
message: I have them all the time they are technically a simple partial seizure with feelings of terror or exteme happiness or even sadness and fear of what might happen. Your expression on your face will often change and freeze with these emotions.  Horrifying seizures I hate them.
author: Benjamin Phillips

label: negative
message: Wayne HeitzWayne before I had my brain surgeries I wrote down every stomach flip,  tingle, mouth watering,  chill,  or anything else seizure related. The more info you can give your Drs the better they can help you.
author: Robin May Ruggie

label: negative
message: My daughter has 'out of body' experiences, usually when she's stressed and trying to get something done fast..........dizzy, eye pain and little by little more partials appear including the 'out of body' experience. We were very surprised when a neurologist rattled off a whole list of things that we didn't know were part of her seizure activity.......stress, lack of sleep, eye strain from studying too long.........all triggers for these. There is so MUCH that people need to be educated about!
author: Marlene Raid

label: neutral
message: Does tobacco cause petite mal seizures-
author: Adrian Dodge

label: negative
message: I feel this way sometimes.  Its disturbing to be upset and not know why.
author: Robin May Ruggie

label: negative
message: What part of the brain triggers this type of seizures? I have had phenomena like this.  I have a daughter with complex partial seizures from 4 temporal lobe and a son who has bipolar disease and that is now thought to come from the r temporal lobe.
author: Donna Portlock Higgins

label: neutral
message: Deja vu is also common during these episodes
author: Stacey Hipsley

label: neutral
message: I actually don't have Epilepsy myself. I have a family member that does.
author: Marcia McMeen Hildebrandt

label: negative
message: Have these all the time, completely suck!!! It's a feeling of fear on top of feeling like you know "what, when, how" everything is going to happen. But you're frozen and can't do anything. Everyone around you is moving just as you "predicted" all the while staring at you, trying to figure out why you have a blank stare on your face. It's scary, sometimes feels like dejavu, most times feels like "psychic". Always feel sick and out of sorts afterwards. I have dealt with these for over 20 yrs.
author: Amber Koernke

label: negative
message: This is how in was dx: feeling of falling backward and lost of time then the great Terror. The doctors at er. Thought in was having a stroke!  Crazy time for me!! Night time is the worst time of all.  How is the night time for others with these feelings and seizures you don't even know you are having???
author: Ruth Premo Berkowitz

label: negative
message: Jeannette I would keep baby monitor in room. Tell others in family to be aware, most of all teacher to let you know of anything. I used to watch my daughter sleep when child so I could explain to Doctor. Mostly had at night.
author: Cathy Mendez

label: negative
message: I never heard of this and i go through these feelings almost every sometimes i dont care falls in there
author: Robert Jarvis Jr

label: negative
message: I didnt have siezures untill I was 55.All three have been in my sleep.Is that common?All three were major siezures since 2012.April,May2012 then Augast 2013.I have probably had 10 to 15 simple partials in between.The first and worst I cracked my head open, got three compression fractures one bulging disc and bit my tounge very deeply.Like almost half way through and a tounge wound can not be stiched.Anybody else have night time only siezures?
author: Ron Jacobson

label: negative
message: I don't need to "recover" from simple-partial seizures... only once it advances into a complex-partial
author: Chad Martin

label: neutral
message: People not bother me with a lot of questions.
author: Cathy Wills Wydner

label: negative
message: I seem to need about 20-30 minutes to recover and no, I don't really know I had them except for the fact that I have no idea where I am or what I am doing -  so now, a few years later -  I finally can recognize that Ihave had one.
author: Jackie Moore

label: negative
message: Is there any way to monitor how often these occur? My son has them but he doesn't always remember.
author: Carrie Galigher Newton

label: negative
message: It always help me to just close my eyes and sleep for a little bit in a dark room just like recharging my battery.
author: Patricia Cantu

label: negative
message: For me it takes about 4 hours to recover and I started keeping track on a epilepsy diary on my phone. It has taken me a really long time to accept that I have epilepsy but now I accept it
author: Patricia Cantu

label: negative
message: Partial seizures for me I just stay laying down in my bed or stay sitting down where ever I am until it stops.  Full blown seizures are different story if I have thoughs then lots of sleep .
author: Megan Plotner Schichtl

label: negative
message: If only teachers would recognize that kids with partial seizures check out occasionally....with or without the boredom of the classroom to blame. Have not been able to teach teachers about this one...sad. If you can't see it it doesn't exist...
author: Elizabeth Meehan

label: positive
message: Time. Sometimes food. I seem to have more when my blood sugar drops.
author: Amy Granger

label: neutral
message: Remove myself from stimuli, no talking or tasks for a few min
author: Stacey Hipsley

label: neutral
message: I cannot sleep after a seizure,  I have kids. I just take a few minutes to breathe
author: Theresa Litzinger

label: negative
message: Sleep.   I must nap or go to bed for the night.  I can sleep for a long time after a seizure.
author: Robin May Ruggie

label: negative
message: depends on what type I have time and rest for some . taking a walk for others. I have even stood in the shower for hours to try to help. People don't seem to understand and look at you like a freak!
author: Wayne Heitz

label: neutral
message: I just started w/the partial seizures, I've had the grand mal for 12 yr but was 8 yr.s free of them, seems that stress is a big factor of bringing them on & I get a funny feeling in my stomach prior to having one, yet my Dr. says it's not Epilepsy?
author: Tina Troendle

label: negative
message: Orange juice or ice water. Then just sit still for a while. But I come around faster with cold drink and air or fan on.
author: Diane Buschbacher

label: neutral
message: Peace and quiet, sleep as much as needed.
author: Angela Ross Williams

label: negative
message: When I have the "absence" seizures I need to take an emergency pill and then lay down for about an hour while trying to avoid going into a gran mal seizure. Usually I am ok after that but maybe extra tired. When I have a grand mal seizure sometimes I don't remember having one and don't know where I'm at or that I have been sleeping for hours. But I remember once I realize that I have chewed deeply into my tongue. That's the worst.
author: Amber M Sirianni

label: neutral
message: I usually have a hard time breathing after alsi
author: John Forgett

label: negative
message: I never really remember mine but someone is always around me when I have one thank god! and I can't breath after I have one I know that and I always make a strange noise before I have one. I sleep after I do have one though.
author: Megan McKendrick

label: neutral
message: I have pretty much every seizure there is and rest and my family to calm me down helps. I'm getting older now so it takes longer to recover now it seems.
author: Lori Bruce George

label: neutral
message: Peace and quiet. Lots of sleep.
author: Jenlyn Williams

label: negative
message: I describe mine to friends as being in a blackout and knowing what is going on around me. Afterwards I need to sit down for a few minutes.
author: Susan Slugg

label: neutral
message: Just my fiance talking me thru it..calming me down
author: Sherryann Smith

label: neutral
message: When I have a seizure I lose consciousness. Afterwards I just sleep that's the only thing that helps.
author: Jeremy Metzger

label: negative
message: I have no idea. All I known is I have no warning signs. I just go out. I have gran mal seizures and the only time I've had a ct scan it came from the right rear air mastoid. When I come to I have memory loss, am very sore the next few days and am pretty irritated for the next few minutes after. That's all I know.
author: Aaron Lafferty

label: negative
message: Yes...I pratically get those feelings all the time, but sometimes I can or cud fight them off..or let it go through its faze?.
author: Bradley King

label: negative
message:
I have been diagnosed with epilepsy for 7 years now, but my neurologist says I have probably had it all my life just hadn't recognized the sign til it progressively got worse with age and not being medicated til now. See when in grade school my teachers would say that I would day dream alot and wouldn't pay attention in class,  but my doctor now thinks I could have been miss diagnosed back then when really I could have been having absence seizures all along.  I still do have many absence seizures a day along with my partial complex ones. 
But I too through the years have learnt to control my seizures,  and tell my brain to basically to take the seizure away with out having to go through all the whole episode of having a full fledge attack and get embarrassed because people don't understand what's going on,  nor know how to help. 

Which I find is hard sometimes now that I have gone back to college.  I try to keep my epilepsy to myself because I am scared of judgment that was so tough for me when I was in high school.  :-(
author: Airianna Mae Culp

label: negative
message: after more than 40 yrs of experience, i get really tired, really fast, lose all appetite, meticalic taste, all before, if i control breathing, sometime i can stop..
author: Sheila Kessler

label: neutral
message: I have had these types of sensations since I was diagnosed with Epilepsy. After reading this now I understand what they are. Thank you for posting the information!
author: Marcy Nance

label: negative
message: I feel tingeling in my tongue, and back left "corner" of my skull and a flipping in my stomach.  That flipping feels like when you are on a roller coaster, when you go down the big hill. I feel like i'm  going to lose my lunch, but never do.
author: Robin May Ruggie

label: neutral
message: My daughter has had where she will start mumbling an laughing,  after a seizure, once or twice she screamed loud then takes her about 10 minutes to come around she remembered nothing. They are changing as she is getting older.
author: Cathy Mendez

label: negative
message: Yep. Me too Tim. I've got countless faceplants on my resume
author: Aaron Lafferty

label: negative
message: Wow, able to fight it off!  Didn't know you could do that.
author: Timothy W Henry

label: negative
message: Before I have my seizures I get a full body cold chill, my heart starts to race, my face gets hot, my whole left arm get numb, and my ring and pinky finger on my left hand get numb and tingle with the prickly sensation,   all a while my right arm jurks every minute or so backwards like it's trying to get the pain I get in my elbow out. I also start to flick my right index finger and thumb together that I usually get blisters from because of the friction of my nails scratching my skin.  After a few minutes of all of that I remember nothing.
author: Airianna Mae Culp

label: negative
message: sometimes right before i have one i get the goose bumps
author: Jack D. Autry

label: positive
message: I get a sense of deja vu then my mind starts trying to find this memory. Then its lights out

<3

message: I couldn't help but laugh when I read this. My first thought was a lunch I had with my best friend, when all of a sudden I started twitching and threw my fork across the room. I've always loved how my family & friends used comedy to ease the embarrassment of my epilepsy.

message: Learning this makes me feel so much better! My son (occasionally) laughs & smiles during his, didn't know that this could be why! Thank you

label: positive
message: Hey that is Callie, the seizure response dog I received from Canine Assistants in 2008, my husband and me walking at the National Walk for Epilepsy last year.  It is amazing what they are capable of training the service dogs to do!  We were at the  Epilepsy Foundation of Greater Cincinnati and Columbus walk today.  I thank the Canine Assistants and epilepsy foundations for what they do!
author: Emily Horsley Compton

label: negative
message: Canine Assistants doesn't ask for recipients to do any fund raising for their dogs. All their dogs are sponsored through fund raisers and private and corporate sponsors. You fill out an app and they contact you when app is received and ask you more detailed questions. You are then added to a wait list that can take anywhere from 1-5 yrs. My son has been on the wait list now for 1.5yrs. Again.... Canine Assistants does not ask for you to do any fund raising for your dog.
author: Mindy Roy Hauser

label: negative
message: If you are like me then epilepsy says, "Beam him away Scotty!" That's why I rely on my enterprising friends and family to see what happens until I'm finally beamed back. They can tell not only my epileptologist, but also myself what happened while I was gone. We need that info.

label: negative
message: My partner Rob always accompanies me to all my nedical appts. I thank him so much bc half the stuff they tell me by the time I walk out of the office I already have forgotten! Lol! He's a great back up & supporter! <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+008A>

label: negative
message: It's very helpful to have the two of us there. One of us is left brained and one is right brained, so we ask different questions. It also helps the doctors get clearer answers as to what is happening.

label: neutral

label: negative
message:
My son has most types of seizures. A couple years ago he had a grand mal(now tonic clonic.) and he was laying on me. It was the weirdest feeling I've ever felt. My hold body was shaking along with his. I'll never forget that feeling. 
My daughter used to say when they were little her brother looked like tickle me Elmo.

label: negative
message: Never heard this before but now that I have I think this may be what my son was going through. Wish we had known.

author: Kathy Fowler

label: negative
message: THESE ARE NOT A SIGN OF WEAKNESS!  Auras are like blanking out of life for a few seconds and not really knowing that you did it, however there are times when you do know it but you totally do not know what you were just talking about or possibly even where you are.  Then the fact that you can have the kind when there is no one around.  However, with medicine and/or surgery they are making progress every day.  Every day/week/month can always get brighter looking at everything, not just my everyday epilepsy.  Everything is a challenge, you just face it on and say SCREW IT and move on.  You keep trying and don't ever let it knock ya down.
author: Bob Archer

label: positive
message: I experience auras , there kinda like a warning where I need to stop what I'm doing and sit down before I hurt myself wen something big happens
author: Megan Plotner Schichtl

label: negative
message: I have this disease and it has been difficult to control.  I have seizures where I appear to be functioning but I cannot tell you who I am or anything specific.  I can't find my words or numbers.  I appear to be drugged or drunk and vomit and have severe headaches afterwrds.

label: negative
message: yes I do it feels like an out of body thing something I don't like to feel

label: neutral
message: Yes I experience 2 types if auras/partial seizures. Mine consist of a foul smell as if something is burning or on fire. My second one is I get an upset stomach with a nausea feel.

message: My daughter says there are "bugs in her brain"

label: negative
message: My son gets a nauseous feeling in his stomach, his face goes pale, he swallows over and over, and his speech slows.  He would rather have a complex partial seizure than the aura (simple partial seizure).  It makes him feel very scared and sick.  He says it's like a lonely feeling...like he worries that he's not going to be able to come out of it.  Does anyone else experience that fear???

label: neutral
message: I get dizzy, my body starts to tingle, short of breah I get hot and break out in a sweat. Sometimes I just get tremors first
author: Marie Andres Workman

label: negative
message: How do you know if its an aura?  I'll be watching TV then just start starring off for a few seconds.  I've had full  grandmal seizures since I was 12.  I haven't had one of those for seven years now.  Confused!!
author: Miranda Anderson

label: negative
message: My 9 year old daughter has experienced these for close to two years.  They present to her as "rainbows" and during the episode her eyes shift to the left and stay there, or as she describes it, her eyes are watching the rainbows.  This usually lasts 2 minutes at the most before she becomes very nauseated and vomits.  She will sleep for an hour or so immediately following one of these episodes as her body drains of all energy.  Even though they are 90% controlled with medication, she will still have a random episode every few months or so.
author: Mirc Ngk

label: positive
message: She sees her neurologist in March. Hopefully he will be able to have some answers. But we live in such a rural area that he is the only pediatric neurologist in our area.
author: Joann Stevens Clay

label: positive
message:
I'm not sure if I'm doing this right but...

Peter Aguero and Sara Peters at TEDMED 

This video hit me hard and made me think differently!  I hope this helps everyone on this page!

label: negative
message: My 9 year old daughter has absence epilepsy. She often has stomach problems, as well as headaches.  Sometimes she complains of funny taste in her mouth. Since her seizures can last 30 sec to several minutes I was wondering if some of these could be considered auras or side affects of a seizure?

label: negative
message: Mine feel like I'm floating outside of my body. I get really hot, dizzy, and I can't focus at all. I also tingle a lot. My service dog can sense them, too. Having her there helps keep me calm. It's also a little embarrassing...

label: neutral
message: My doctor has asked me for years do I have an aura before my seizures. I do not think I do.

label: negative
message: I used to get them all the time in middle school. What would happen with me would be the room would start to spin, my tongue would go limp, the room would start to smell like paint thinner. Then my legs would give out and I'd keel over. All of this occurs within 10 seconds or so. Whenever I'd feel the first signs of it, I'd scan the room to make sure I wouldnt fall on something sharp or hard that could crack my head open.

label: negative
message: I get clumsy and confused and my nose goes numb right before a petite mal. I have no warning when I am going to have a grand... Which is scary!!

label: negative

Always freak me out because I know 9 times outta 10 a bad seizure occurs then I will be sick and sore for atleast a weak.
author: Kathy Millard

label: negative
message:
What started as dizziness and  changes in the way things looked, ended up as "status epilepticus", a coma for a few days in the ICU and altogether 13 days in the hospital.  Took over 4 months to get back to normal.
Partial onset seizures are nothing to play with.
author: Chad Hogue

label: negative
message: I wish I had known this. My son passed away a little more than a year ago of SUDEP. Never heard of it or even these type. Thought I was educated on what I needed to know. If only. These post have really been eye opening but I wish I had known before. Hopefully these will help others. Communication with your doctor is most important.

label: neutral
message: I have these. They have led to tonic - clinic seizures before
author: Megan Patterson

label: positive
message: Those are what I have.  And they start in my right thumb and fore finger and then proceed in my hand.  Then my arm starts to do its own thing.  And my cheek and eye lid on the right side start to switch and feel funny.  After that I don't remember anything else about what happens during my seizures
author: Airianna Mae Culp

label: negative
message: No    I   didn't  know    sure  is     good  information.

label: negative
message: I have had these, and the E.R doctors or nurses accuse me of faking it! It makes me so angry, when someone says I'm faking it, just because I'm still coherent, doesn't mean I'm faking it. They also think I'm faking because my whole body isn't shaking when I get this type of seizure. I get a mixture of seizures.

label: negative
message: yeah, another time I went through a grocery store and was able to get 3 or 4 bags of groceries. message: I didn't know. I have those symptoms with my seizures.  Usually my right hand starts then my face and eye starts to twitch.  My right leg has started doing its own dance as my teenage boys call it. But once it gets to a point I don't recall a thing. Wow! Thank you!!!

label: positive

Sorry I have bad humor) absent photo and prob one that has yet to be named (sorry,it helps me to poke fun at my situation,not trying to offend) We can all hope for an epilepsy free life,take care of yourselves all and never give up hope that one day we can find even ground with our condition :-)
author: Aaron Cwiklinski

label: negative
message: Diagnosed with generalized epilepsy at 15 when I had my first tonic-clonic (grandmal), they realized then by discussion with my parents that I had been having absent seizures since a young child however. My teachers complained I was a constant daydreamer, yet I swore I was paying attention.  About 1 1/2 ago I was diagnosed with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy after 2 years of new neuro symptoms.
