author: Julie Shaffer-Mchenry

label: positive
message:
I have someone who takes me to all of my drs. appt. and I tild this family member that from now on STAY IN THE DABBLASTED WAITING ROOM!  THIS IS MY DRS. APPTS. ABOUT ME, NOT YOU!  I DON'T NEED YOU INTERRUPTING ME,  TO TALK ABOUT YOUR HEALTH! AND ADDING BITS AND PIECES ABOUT THINGS YOU HAVE NO IDEA ABOUT, ESPECIALLY SINCE YOU DO NOT EVEN LIVE WITH ME!!!!!!!!
After I told my father off he not permitted in any drs. appts., nor any drs. treatments, physical therapy or anything dealing with ANY DRS. that talk to me. Even if it is in th ER. I TOLD HIM, IF THAT HURTS YOUR FEELINGS, I'M JUST EXPRESSING HOW I FEEL, AND HOW SOME DRS. HAVE  EXPRESSED TO ME, WHILE  YOU ARE BEING THE ROOM DURING MY TREATMENTS.  YOU ARE DISRUPTING THEM, AND CAUSING THEM TO CUT MY TIME IF WHAT THEY NEED TO ASK,  OR DO! 
SO.......after that nice little conversation,  he waits I the waiting room, or if something happens, and he is needed,  then he is allowed. He is not permitted to even read what I may have to sign, nor is he permitted to speak on my behave if we are in the ER, and I can't speak, like when I had my Stroke in 2012. I tried to sign, but it was hard since I was paralysed on one side of my body, but it was just my left side,  but I did what I could with my right. Once my brother came to the ER,  he was able to translate, since I taught him when he was younger, and he still remembered,  and he sometimes has to use it for his job, and he knows my body language, considering he lives with me. So he, and my mother know my body language without me saying a word, since I do live with my Mother.  She works, since I am disabled with a lot of things, while my father is, I guess disabled, but he doesn't work, so that's my transportation. That is also, I hope answers your question, EPILEPSY ADVOCATE.......anything else, you can send it to me by way of  message. 

PEACE LOVE JUSTICE HUGS KNOWLEDGE WISDOM UNDERSTANDING HUGS

X<U+2661>X<U+2661>X<U+2661>X<U+2661>X<U+2661>X<U+2661>X<U+2661><U+2661>X

message: My NEUROLOGY THINKS I may have something called Refractory seizure I have never heard of this.I always have had Temporal lope seizures. Lately for the past 6 months I started doing what I would call involuntary noise.They can be very loud at time to a scream, or to a just a grunt sound.I have never had any thing like this before.It is totally embarrassing so much that I didn't even want to  go out in public or to Church for I never knew when one was going to break forth. I will be going into the Hospital next week for a 72 hrs EEG and VIDEO watch.Iwill be took off of all my seizure medicines to try and figure out if maybe one of them is maybe working against me .Have you ever heard of this type of seizure? Its strange that I just notice the other week that i haven't being having any break through of the temporal lobe seizure since this started.

label: negative
message:
I also have a degree in Emergency Medical Philosophy. People at the Epilepsy Council in the city I live in assume Paramedics know practically nothing about seizures.
I felt like asking her how many people she's seen go into a seizure and then treated them for it. 
It was a presumptuous statement to say I know practically nothing about seizures.
author: Vicki Gleason

label: negative
message:
I'm a Paramedic. I think they need to offer classes that teach the public not to stand around at the scene of a person who's having seizure activity and ask stupid questions like "Does he want fries with that shake."
A person can die in a seizure. That's a fact. Seizure activity, as our captain says, is nothing to clown around about.
I get tired of people doing that. I'm not a saint. I'm an Emergency Medical Technician at the Paramedic level.
I wish there were more classes that explain how serious seizure activity really is. Sometimes, I think some people NEED to feel the import behind the words. Their comfort or discomfort at know what it's really like shouldn't matter as much as getting the point through their heads.
author: Vicki Gleason

label: positive
message: Great story !  I am always encouraged by other people who have lived with Epilepsy.  My son was diagnosed with his Epilepsy at 3 years.  Today he is 17.  He has been seizure free since Oct.2010.  He had some genetic testing and found that he had a genetic scn1a a type of mitochondrial disorder...what it did, this knowledge was let us know which meds are recommended and which ones are not !!! He had been taking 2 meds which were not recommended.  Wow....sure glad we found out.  I recommend having the genetic testing done if you do not know the reason for your seiuzres !!!

label: negative
message:
I think you should bring up a question of "How do you think Epilepsy Facebook pages should communicate with those that ask questions on facebook?" - Where do people post questions? Is there a forum anyone knows of? So far, the three that I've checked out on facebook doesn't seem to be reciprocal - only on occasion a post from another person who have liked the page, comes up. I appreciate it, but I don't always get public notifications. 

 Epilepsy Advocate, Team Epilepsy, Epilepsy Foundation of America, I'm asking for advice and help on each one of your pages, and unless I'm not getting notifications, have not heard from anyone yet, on each page. 

Thanks
author: Penny Bradford

label: negative
message: Hi Penny, as you may know, epilepsy is a complicated condition. That’s why we are working hard to get the information out there. We appreciate your request but please keep in mind that only  a healthcare professional can give proper medical advice to someone with epilepsy.

author: Courtney Bergeron

label: negative
message: some weeks I can go without any, but then the next week can have like 8-10 in a 8 hour period. not really positive when I started having them, I can remember some odd things happening to me as young as 9 could have been absence ones, then when started having partials and complex partials was treated for panic attacks, then after about 3-5 years after that had a grand-mal and still wasn;t diagnosed with epilepsy until about 1 year to the date later had another grand-mal and even after trying numerous different meds and even brain surgery still have them.

label: positive
message:
Wow, thanks for the great feedback everyone! The results of our poll are in: 22% of our community’s respondents said that they bring a caregiver with them but not to the exam room, 50% said they bring their caregiver into the exam room, too, and 28% said they don’t bring anyone.

Any feedback from the community? Is this surprising to you? What about you… do you have a caregiver or partner come with you to your doctor’s appointment? We want to hear your thoughts.

Matthew was my only Son who was an upcoming artisit who was working on his Master's Degree.  My prayers and heart goes out to all of the people with Epilepsy.  They are all true hero's and we must keep up the fight to get the word out there that it can happen to any of us at any given time.  Merry Christmas and God Bless everyone of you and your families.  No greater loss then that of your Daddy or Mommy or your child to Epilepsy!

author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: positive
message: Great story !  I am always encouraged by other people who have lived with Epilepsy.  My son was diagnosed with his Epilepsy at 3 years.  Today he is 17.  He has been seizure free since Oct.2010.  He had some genetic testing and found that he had a genetic scn1a a type of mitochondrial disorder...what it did, this knowledge was let us know which meds are recommended and which ones are not !!! He had been taking 2 meds which were not recommended.  Wow....sure glad we found out.  I recommend having the genetic testing done if you do not know the reason for your seiuzres !!!

label: negative
message: Epilepsy, has been in our family  for 18 yrs Chaz has had  seizes started at the age of 4 yrs. he has the grandma seizes.  It is so hard. For me when he goes into a seizes ,  it is so hard to be there and I can't  do anything for him ,I pray and I  talk to God to help me and Chaz  get through this seizes ,I. Feel so helpless.,and sad for Chaz  for what he is going through . The seizes are so hard on him,I. Couldn't make it all these years with. Out Gods love and his blessing. It is a shame that people  don't understand  how hard it is for Chaz  to get through a day without having a seizes and all the medication he has to take. People look at him  as being different ,afraid  of him , I don't know why !!  He loves people wants to be around people and other kids. We love Chaz so very much . Thanks for taking time to read this ,I needed to write  this and to let everyone know your not alone  out there ,iand if when your feeling  sad and down remember  I'm praying for all of you  and I feel your pain too.

message: I dyed my hair purple and painted my nails purple for November. I have been telling my story and posting different facts everyday on FB and have gotten some people to make donations. It's so easy to tell your story with purple hair, anytime I go anywhere someone asks about the hair and that's my icebreaker... Also people are very curious to hear my story more than ever because I'm preggers (with a little girl)! Great job to everyone spreading the word this month and good luck to us all and our loved ones!

label: negative
message: My daughter has had FOUR(4) grand mall seizures in the past 4 weeks after never having any before this. Up until this point it had only been noticed that she "spaced out" once in school and this is what I understand to be an absence seizure - this was the only time that was noticed. NOW...she has had these FOUR episodes in FOUR WEEKS. After the 3rd we were finally able to meet with a neurologist and medication was prescribed yesterday. Today she had another seizure. WHAT IS GOING ON?!?!? How does she go from never having one to having them so frequently?!?!?

label: positive
message: In 2006 My daughter was 16 and her first had a seizure and they said she had  Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy. she then started have  grand mall seizures .They put her on some medicine to help.she is now 21 with 2 healthy boys one is 18 mo. and the other is 8mo...I talked to her doctor about the boys getting epilepsy and he said there is a 1% chance of them getting them.And there is no Family member that has epilepsy. yes it is very scary. So I think people need to learn about what to do when they see some one having a  Seizure. And knowing the tigers that cases you to have a  Seizure.. We found out watching t.v.with out lights is a tiger,not getting enough sleep,stress  we can't forget the flashing light as well... May God Bless you all.

I also have epilepsy.  30 years now i have been dealing with this. I am in the hospital right now. Having tests done to see if I am a good candidate for surgery. I have found out I have more then one type of epilepsy.

label: negative
message: I want to wish you all the luck in the world with your test and that you will be a candiate forr the surgery. I had the surgery back in 2011 and I am now seizure free amoung other things I now have.. But I am now able to drive and am now back in college something I was not able to do for 6years. So I wish you all the luck in the world. Surgery was the best thing in the world you could ever imingine to have done. But I had the VNS Thearpy done in 2009 and right after it seemed that my seizures got worse going to Tonic-clonc and every kind of seizure their is known to man. But again I hope they are able to find what and were it is your having seizures. Best of luck to you. Please feel free to email me on fcbk if you would like to talk more. have a great night.

label: negative
message: Sad to say, I do not believe in prayer. The seizures I have augmented my lifestyle. It is not a lack of hope but, a realistic decision. I pray, amen

label: negative
message: I use to have Grandma seizures. The worst you could have. I started having them when I was 10 & when I was 13 I had brain surgrey cause they thought I had a tumor bt it wasnt. The part on my leftside above my ear had died. It had started bleeding & it dried up & killed the size of a quater & 2inches thick! As I got older they got to be not as bad. Im still on medicine & go see my nauroligist every 6mnths & sometimes sooner. It really sucks having Epilepsy cause I cant drive,work, nothing really!!! Its not something u want but its apart of my life!!!

message: :) I am an Epilepsy patient and I get your magazine.  I advocate for people with epilepsy because there is still a lot of misunderstanding and discrimination regarding epilepsy at large.  It is often misdiagnosis and definitely misunderstood by society at large.  You can continue to live a very normal life and still have this disorder.  It is not a disease, it is a disorder. :)

label: positive
message: Prayers & faith. I also make sure I take 5 or 10 mins for myself each day.
author: Sincere Brown Hunt

label: negative
message: Sleep when she sleeps, find friend/family to chit chat about life/world events/etc with during those few free moments to help you reconnect with rest of world, sit on porch swing and relax a few minutes while she watches her favorite shows just a few feet away, use those few minutes when she's in someone else's care (school) to get things done that have to be done, and then use whatever time is left (if any) to do little things for me (plant flowers is one of my favorites (when I do get a chance to sit in porch and gaze in flowers, they remind me that God is at work in this world and has a plan for everyone), but it can take a long time to actually have time to plant) ...  Just little things here and there to help maintain the sanity and offload some of the stress.
author: Robin Langston

label: positive
message: I crochet alot, I make several items for charity, I make time by doing my own pedi and mani, and  I do genealogy research. In between making sure my husband is ok. Hes had epilepsy for years, so we have most of his triggers figured out, we try to talk to others  with epilepsy who need guidance, research, and a friend to talk to as well.  Its good to live as much of your own life as possible, when possible. Ane yes daily prayers are in our own lives as well. We  pray every night before bed time and we take turns. Its good to take a few minutes, if you cannot do more.  God bless you all.
author: Mary Nelle Dagenhart

label: negative
message: Between being a caregiver & my 2 children at home....I have NO time for me. Im having surgery Nov.1 & the time I get off after(of coarse unpaid) will be the time I et to take care of me. Other than that....forget about it!!
author: Misty Lynn Harvey

label: negative
message: Caregivers are on call 24-7 at least at my house. I make a little me time every day. Take a walk or bake something to share. Explore new recipes. Connect with friends. Go out every Wednesday to my weight watcher meeting enjoying my me time makes me a better wife daughter mom.
author: Melanie Foley

label: negative
message: I am not a caregiver, I am one of the unfortunate ones that needs the care.   What I would suggest is that if you are taking care of someone with epilepsy,  try and talk with them and learn all you can about the deises, and remember to be pateint with the person that suffers from it

message: You have to be strong and embrace it. God wouldn't have given you this responsibility if you couldn't handle it. Your loved one needs you. It's definitely a hard balance!

message: I truly would appreciate any information or suggestion to help our 24 year old son. We found out a few months ago that he has epilepsy.  He was told he cannot be a firefighter anymore, cannot drive, etc. I am at a loss sometimes as to what to say. I try to be encouraging, and positive, since I am a heart attack survivor.  I wish the best for all of you and hope you all have a blessed day.
author: Dee Wagner

label: neutral
message: Actually Dee, there are plenty of epilepsy resources available on Epilepsy Advocate’s website at http://www.epilepsyadvocate.com/resources/epilepsy-programs.aspx. Have a look.
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message: Dee i am 34 on nov 6th. my first grand Mal seizure was when i was 3. i  had my first seizure on my third b-day. i also have an 11 year-old daughter with epilepsy. it is very discourging to be someone that has to live with this disease. your son is more unfortunate than me. give him some time to grieve the losses that he has had to go through with this. i wanted to be a chef. they told me no because of the heat. i will pray.  he has lost alot of privliges that other people take for granted. i know how he feels in some aspects. i gave my daughter to my mom because of my seizures onfornately all i can say is it is a hard disease and you and him will learn to live with it. get him to go to places with you show him that he is normal like everyone else like you have been. it is hard i know but it sounds like you have been doing a great job. he may not see this as a normal part of life for awhile so just tell him hey i am here. i love you. i am your mom. tell him this is just an obstacle and he is a very strong man.
author: Kate Mason

label: positive

label: negative

author: Sheri Chandler Irby

label: negative
message: I have it on my calendar the very first day I can reorder it . I call them that day or very soon and reorder. I also have a weeks worth in my purse with a piece of paper with my doctors , their phone numbers, the medicines, the doses , the mg, and my medical illnesses. Everyone I love knows I have that so if I have to go to the hospital they won't have to jump through hoops to get that information. Plus it comes in handy with all those pesky doctors appointments.
author: Pam Lawrence

label: negative
message: I filled my daughter's medication and then had her doctor write a 90 day prescription through her insurance company.  At any given time I have a 30 to 120 days of her medication on hand.  The medication coming in a 90 day supply is cheaper than going month to month through a local pharmacy.  I also use my flexible spending account to pay for all her medications that many do no take advantage of through their jobs.  As soon as the 90 day prescription arrives I send in the reorder form and they auto fill it on the first day it is eligible to fill.  This is one of my greatest fears is to be without her medication.
author: Joy Mullis Kurtz

label: positive
message: Joy, I do TH 90 day supply too.  I have had Epilepsy for 43 years.  Better safe than sorry.  When I pack for a trip, my medicine is packed 1st.  It is the most important item.
author: Judy Hodges Redderson

label: negative
message: I also have at least 90 day supply on hand...alwady keep some at home & in my purse in case i feel i need a little extra.

label: negative
message: I know that a lot of companies  offer flex spending accounts.  You can estimate what your yearly cost of medications and place the money in that account and reduce your taxable .income

message: A pill box is a great thing to have.  For those of us who are so forgetful it is a wonderful reminder.  Many times in the late morning hours I say to myself did I take my meds this morning? I agree with Randy another thing I do when I pick up my prescriptions is to ask the pharmacist if my meds are still in automatic refill, this comes in very handy.

I know of people who have faked illnesses and receive aid. Wow

message: My son had a near fatal car accident back in March due to a partial onset seizure. He had been seizure free for almost a year. I am grateful he did not hurt anyone and he is alive. He is being evaluated for a second brain surgery.

People think if they can't see a disability it isn't there.I am lucky I have wonderful friends and a really great family. Love them so much!! I have had the same job for 25 years and they have been good to me also.  I am a lucky one. I love life.

label: positive

label: negative
message: I had grandmal and petit mal seizures from the time I was 4 until I was in my 30's.  Then suddenly they stopped.  I haven't had any kind of seizure since 2002.  I am almost 41 now and by the grace of God, I haven't had any seizures, and also no medication.  I know the seriousness of this first hand.

label: negative
message: I used to walk alot but one day went to cross the road and if a friend had not been with me I wouldn't be here now because I had an absence seizure and didn't know I was crossing the road when a car or two was coming. Yes they are dangerous as well but you learn to cope.

label: positive
message: the dangers with partial /complex seizures is they dont show activity alot of the times on an eeg,as why there were 2 car accidents becuse nothing showed up on the eeg after the first accient
author: Terri Bass Barlow

label: positive

It hit four vehicles,  plus hit the ceramic garbage can (crashed it ), broke the enterance door of private business.  Thanks God, nobody died.  I didnt drive independetly after that.  Two years ago, had a brain surgery in Rush Hospital,  Chicago n I am a seizures FREE.

label: negative
message: I've had epilepsy for 17.5 years now. Finally a doctor found a good mix of pills for me to take. I have Grand Mal siezures, Complex Partial Siezures and Simple siezures. I've never driven a car, never had a girlfriend, never been to a bar, So many things. I haven't done. Regualar people don't know what seizures are. I started having them when I was 10. Now I have a V.N.S. (Vegus Nerve Stimulator) to help me stop some of the seizures but still most of the siezures come on to quick for me you use it.
author: Mike Anderson

label: positive
message: I was in my senior yr of HS when a doctor finally believed us that something wasn't right. I have 3 different types of seizures, the majority being absence. It changed my life, for the good and bad.

label: negative
message: My son was in an accident when he was 17 ,got a head  injury this was in 2000 then in 2007 he has grandmal seizures, partial complex, focal, and now to top all that off has pyhschosis from the brain injuy.., he is 30 now no disability or nothing if it was not for familyhe would be homeless...

label: neutral

author: Reba R Brewer

label: negative
message: I have complex partial seizures, mostly in the middle of the night, which affects my sleep. If I feel weird, I don't drive. But, I've never been able to hold a job for long, since they started when I was a baby. It's extremely frustrating to always be told I'm not paying attention and not taking initiative. I just started learning about partial seizures the past few years and they're still somewhat of a mystery to me. Eve Laplante's book,  "Seized" made me feel not so weird.
author: Spring Johnson

label: neutral
message: i think this happens to me especially since my siezures are induced by stress
author: Sarah Rod

label: positive
message: I have had a few partial seizures while driving as well.. I drove off the road once, into a shallow ditch, with my sister-in-law and husband, everybody was ok. I swerved into  oncoming traffic, I had the steering wheel jerked back over by a passenger. Also I almost drove off the road while my husband and mother in law were in the car. They grabbed the wheel. My Dr. revoked my license and put me in new meds.. All is good now!`` =)
author: Megan Patterson

label: positive
message: My daughter's seizures are all generalized, rather than partial, but I can attest to the fact of how scary Epilepsy can be! It is definitely life changing, not just for the individual involved, but for all who are involved in his/her care. So many people just don't understand. Thank you Epilepsy Advocate for helping to spread the word!

label: negative
message: Well I don't know what causes epilepsy but it is disturbing,  I had another episode a couple of days ago.  It is bothersome that I can be alright one minute and the next I wake up in an ambulance on my way to a hospital.  I was born with this dreaded illness and all I can say is I wish there was something I could do to stop getting them.   There are a lot of things I am no longer able to do, for example: drive, drink when I go out with friends and now another must a low sodium diet.  What causes these episodes?  I'd like to know.
author: José F Londoño-artist

label: positive
message: Well mal just learned my daughter has pettie mal ones real scary for me noot knowing anything
author: Amanda Marie

label: negative
message: Tonic Clonic seizures are painful and scary, I have found that most people are supportive when I have these. The most difficult for me are partial seizures.  Blanking out for a few seconds during a conversation, staring off into space, or certain odd uncontrollable body movements.  With these seizures I have found people aren't as supportive or understanding.  I don't have issues with people that do not know me.  What I have issues with and what really stings are the friends and family that do know.  Many make snide, low brow comments like "look at me when I'm talking to you," snapping their fingers in you face, treating you like an idiot, rolling their eyes when you talk or just plain being mean and rude.  I understand that it is ignorance and education is needed.  However, just as ignorance of the law is an invalid excuse for breaking it, treating others poorly and claiming ignorance is inexcusable as well.
author: Donna Jarvis Stovall

label: negative
message: I have been living with Epilepsy for 14 years now, and they still haven't gone away, an I have had two surgeries. I'm praying that I won't live with this problem for the rest of my life.

label: positive
message: I do have Faith, I have been waiting 6yrs for a Surgeon that is willing to give me a hip replacement , with having seizures!! Unable to walk without equipment.  Raising 2daughters..my faith gets my though, one day at a time.  ( Matthew 4:23--25 ). NIV
author: Annie Hayes

label: negative
message: Seizure control , would give me my life back if this can really happen! Stress plays a big part in my life, have alot going on and its just me moving but the stress alone. For i am on medication yet had a seizure in my rest. Bit my tongue and broke a tooth doen to tha gum line. In this case you have doctor bills , medications and other injuries that can cause other exspencies, now i have to take it eady for a day. Really can 't afford, so much to do but its my health that comes first. You just never know when it can happen!! Its frruatating ( very ) find away that sercurity

author: Tamara Zavardino

label: negative
message: I have no seizure during the day and I can work . But when I sleep my brain is in seizure mode. Its doing its own thing! Im pretty tired but and dont drive.  Im 47  now. Started having grand mal seizures now this is what it is. And they dont know why. They say Im seizure free since January but Im having them when I sleep. Im a functional epileptic! Yes loving life!

author: Jerry Werner

label: negative
message: FOR me, it means being able to function like a "normal" human being (able to use the bathroom without assistance, take a shower by myself, not have to have someone stand by me when I stand up and walk around because there's a really good chance that I might fall over).  It means being able to sleep in my bed without worrying about falling out of bed and injuring myself or anyone around me.  This is seizure control to me.  I know it is very different for other people.  There's more to it than just this, but this is a start for me and I enjoy being able to at least do these simple things for once!
author: Melissa Eavey

author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message: My daughter is 21 and was diagnosed with epilepsy at age 14. I have watched health and youthful vitality steadily decline. Her memory is terrible and she is very frail and weak. I would like to see more in the way of research and funding to find ways to keep epilesy under control. She cannot drive because she is not free from seizures for long enough to get driver's license. Her medication is very expensive even with insurance. So I would also like to see programs to help with cutting costs of epilepsy medications.
author: Lisa Cowart Burks

label: negative
message:
the epilepsy Medications are outrageous And for myself unaffordable also the side effects are horrible because of the cost and Side effects I am now only taking one medication Versus two 
I now have more Seizures then before but the side effects are not as bad I have Extra help through Medicare but every Year the Social security administration tries to get me kicked off the program
author: Deb Fritz

label: negative
message: Vickie, A Pre-Existing Condition Insurance Plan (PCIP) provides new coverage options to individuals who have been uninsured for at least six months because of a pre-existing condition. States have the option of running this new program in their state. If a state has chosen not to do so, a plan should already have been established by the Department of Health and Human Services in that state. This program serves as a bridge to 2014, when all discrimination against pre-existing conditions will be prohibited.
author: Barney Osborne

label: negative
message: I have had epilepsy for over 36 years they need to do more research and definitely cut the cost on medications . especially because I live on Social Security if you want to call that even living .

I have found that people are more receptive to what I have to say and they are quite interested in what I tell them.

label: negative
message: Just my opinion folks, but.........don't those of use with seizures have to work "around" things a little differently? I always said that I grew up looking at things a "little bit sideways" in the ways that I had to approach things. Still do. Always will. Maybe there is something  there , that connects  Caesar and Einstein and all the famous ppl. ...We tend to be more 'creative' (I think) and approach problems differently than most ppl do.  Just don't let Epilepsy EVER define you. You can find a definition in your own mind of what Epilepsy is , just do NOT ever let it define you. .................

label: negative
message: That was one of the first things I found out while reading Encyclopedia Brittanica back in the 70's, when I first found out I had epilepsy. It stuck in my head all through my travels, as I hitched and walked across America so many times. If someone could be the ruler of an Empire and yet have seizures, why, then why, couldn't I do what I wanted to do in this world, especially since it is now a free-thinking world, where one does not have to do as their emperor says, or be fed to the lions. So I 'just did it!'.

author: Billy Bosson

label: negative
message: I am 27 yrs old and have lived with Epilepsy since I was about 15months old.  I have been on just about every drug out there and have lived anything but a normal life.  I did everything I could to live with it and try to not let it interrupt my life too much.  I was a very loyal and accountable employee until finally it took over my life.  I never called in sick unless I had to go to the ER because I couldn't function without having a seizure.  Finally I went to a new dr. earlier this year and was introduced to something called VNS.  I had this implant put in back in March.  It has made a tremendous difference in my quality of life!  I can actually go to sleep and not be so concerned about having horrible seizures in my sleep or wake up having them.  I'm not cured, but I definitely have a better quality of life!  Thanks to everyone involved in making this possible!  One thing that is essential in having Epilepsy, even as an adult is having a good support system and someone around to help you almost at all times.  I have never been able to live on my own because of this.
author: Melissa Eavey

label: negative
message: As you may know, epilepsy is a complicated condition. That’s why we are working hard to get the information out there. We appreciate your comment and try to keep in mind that anyone with epilepsy should consult their doctor before making any lifestyle changes.

I forget what I'm saying and I have to constantly excuse myself to the people I am talking to for the cut off
author: Shannon Darnell

label: negative
message: My daughter too has bouts of memory loss and forgets things. I want her to be able to live well with epilepsy but it has created it's challenges. I wish there was a organization in ohio where children like my daughter could talk with each other and see how they cope with this disorder. Unfortunately we found out her condition was caused by scar tissue on the temporal regions of her brain which was a congenital defect and she will need medication to control her seizures. I worry cause before Jan 28, 2010 I had a happy go lucky 7 year old who didn't have a care in the world. Now she does not like to be around people cause she fears having a seizure around them and has become more of an introvert. Any suggestions on how to help my daughter have better social interaction with her friends and classmates.

message: My dream is to become a nurse. I had my first seizure when I was 1. I had a "break" after 3 years, and my seizures stopped, but came back when I turned 12. label: negative
message: I have a question: Does anyone know of a program to take a dog that is currently living with someone who has seizures and shows signs of being able to tell when a seizure is coming on for training? Everything I have seen is for dogs already in the programs. Just a few months before my brother's first seizure I got him an akc yellow lab, he went two years before his last seizure a few months back and Bailey (the dog)  sat in front of my brother and started to stare at him minutes before the seizure came on.  If he can sense these things and we can teach him how to hone in on that and let someone know when they happen since my brother lives in an upstairs apartment alone would be great. Any ideas?

We love you Megan Ballard.
author: Pam Ballard

label: positive
message: I had my first seizure when I was 8.  Very little was known about epilepsy then (1953) and a little later my folks were told they should put me in an - insane is not the word but close to it - asylum.   I will be forever grateful they didn't and treated me the same as they did my brother and sister.   I was on cross country team in HS.    I have 2 associates degrees and have had a full life.  Working for most of it and  married 41 years this Oct.   They are now controlled and I haven't had a seizure in about 6 years.

I was very scared when I woke up in the hospital I had no idea what had happened and why I was there. My dad calmnly explained everything to me. It was the one time in my life that I was not afraid and I felt safe. Thank You to my Dad Skip Gilley.

author: Elizabeth Robles

label: negative
message:
My daughter began experiencing seizures at 3 months old. Nobody believed me, at first, that anything was going on because they were so short and infrequent. I knew. I just knew.For years I dealt with it without any kind of diagnosis and everyone thinking I was being overly cautious and making a big deal out of nothing. She started preschool and the teacher would send home discipline notes every day about how she wouldn't listen. How she spent too much time daydreaming. About how she was defiant and would sit and stare at her desk instead of lining up with the other kids.. I told them what I had suspected since she was an infant. They didn't believe me. I told her doctor. She said "Sometimes kids just daydream.."  At seven, she complained on New Years Day of a headache.. Then, her seizure started. I drove through a blizzard to get her to the emergency room and the seizure was still taking place. They finally believed me. She is now 8. Her seizures are for the most part under control. She's beginning hippotherapy this week. 

Nobody knows better than a mother. If you feel that your child needs something, fight for it. All too often serious matters are disregarded as behavior issues when, in fact, they actually have no control over it. Don't give up.
author: Jennifer Thomas

message: I didn't become epileptic til I was 28 and my grand mals are nocturnal. I can have petite mals at any time. But since I have a had a Vagas Nerve Stimulator implanted in my chest and along with my medications they have mostly been controlled. I only occasionally have petite mals as long as I keep my medication going.
author: Shari Hill-Brown

label: negative
message: Wastntime Shari-that is good to know.  Thank you.  My love of my life, my second son has grand mal seizures now.  I will look into it.
author: Laurie Anne Steele

label: negative
message: My daughter had epilepsy when she was younger but I still worry that it might come back.  She had grand mal seizures and she took two very strong medicines everyday.  When she became pregnant with my grand son, sadly, her seizures came back briefly.  Happily, she did not need to be put on medicine.  We became members of the Epilepsy Foundation of CT.  They were very helpful with information about this medical condition.  There was also a nurse in the hospital who was extremely helpful to us with great information for me and my daughter.  I think that the more you know and understand about this medical condition the better you can try to control it.  I wish everyone the best.
author: Khadija Abdul-Salaam

label: negative
message: same for me. I am 18 and got my driver's lisence last year. I  love backpacking, white water rafting and rock climbing- almost anything outdoors. Having epilepsy doesnt mean you can't be part of the adventure. I just means you have a few extra pounds (or kilos) on your back.
author: Carina Garcia

label: positive
message: I have been fighting with epilepsy for over 6 yrs now after having it for most of my childhood as well. I have 3 amazing children who r now 13, 11 and 8 and an amazing hubby. The doctors only can tell me that stress is the cause. They can not find any other reason for my seizures. They have found some white lesions on my MRIs, but do not know what they r, what caused them and/or if they have anything to do with my epilepsy. I do not know anyone who has epilepsy, so it sure is nice to have found u! I would luv to meet others who have epilepsy and who can share their experiences with me and me with them.
author: Rebecca Stacey White

label: negative
message: Hi Rebecca, My name is Meredith...I had epilepsy as a child but grew out of themin 3rd grade...then in 203 I fell an hit my head and they started back up...feel fre to send me a friend request so we canchat more about whats going on wi you...ok..
author: Meredith Roberson

label: neutral
message: im ciindy   i had epileply  since i was 3   im 56 in 1981 i went for left temperl lobe surgery  ive been siezure free for 30 years
author: Cindy Pelletier

label: neutral
message: my wife had seizures for most of her life, but thanks to god and her surgery about 10 years ago she is now seizure free and now can drive and work a full time job!

label: neutral
message: No one knows that better then you sweetheart

label: negative
message: I have Epilepsy and it is really an electrical discharge in the brain...like an electrical storm.  Dependent upon where the storm "hits"..it could be a grand mal seizure or a petit mal.  Thank goodness for medications that they have for Epilepsy :0)

label: negative
message: I have lived with Epilepsy for 15 yrs now. I had surgery 2 yrs ago. And I do recommend it if your Dr says it is an option. Before my surgery I was talking a combo of meds totaled 8 a day. Since my surgery life has been a lot easier and I take 1 med 2 a day. A big diff. Stay confident, Strong and Patient. There WILL BE BETTER DAYS.
author: TooBlessed ToBe Stressed

label: negative
message: I just wanted to introduce myself, we just recently found out my 6 year is having seizures. I'm so glad I have found this page, it's been a very scary time for us. I just wanted to say thank  you to everyone that has shared their story
author: Katie Janitz

label: positive
message: I had had epilepsy for 23 years with 3 surgeries and every anti-convulsant on the market, but when I started practicing with "meditation" the results were amazing!

label: neutral
message: I received my epilepsy in 2nd grade but never did go into effect until before my nine grade. 2nd grade I had a high fever and went into a coma.

label: neutral
message: I have had it since I was 17 I will b 36 on the first of july...its hard....

label: negative
message: Yes and some in Neuroscience have a hard time engaging with new research no mater how many times the findings are validated and found to be true....new form of epilepsy instantiated by PSTD/Anxiety...and with Vet's return  home - standard EEG testing does not reveal all...and the paradigm changes and will the knowledge experts engage a new set of paradigm(s)...

We appreciate your comment but try to keep in mind that only a healthcare professional can give proper medical advice to someone with epilepsy.

label: neutral
message: yes,i agree about keeping in touch with your,DR WITH DR VISITS,AND BOOK TO KEEP TRACK PF MEDS,AND SEIZURES....

label: negative
message: BELIEVE ME I'VE HAD SEIZURES SINCE I WAS 18 MONTHS OLD.I'M ALMOST,AND.BEEN TO SO MANY DRS. I'VE LOST COUNT.I JUST TELL MYSEL FI CAN DO ANYTHING IF I TRY HARD ENOUGH.IT SEEM FROM MY POINT OF VIEW,I NOT 'VE DONE JUST ABOUT EVERYTHING I WAS TOLD I COULD NOT DO ALL YOU HAVE TO TELLYOURSELF YOU CAN DO ANYTHING IF YOU SET YOUR MIND FOR IT.AND KEEP TRYING TILL YOU CAN DO IT.....CINDY

label: negative
message: here is a legitamate question how do we get disability for having Epilepsy? I've had it for the last seventeen years and have been turned down ever since?????

message: you appeal it larry!!!!! i did it twice and got it for my son!!!!

label: neutral
message: is this the Casie Tomlinson from Fairfield Ill.???
author: Larry Talbert Jr.

label: neutral
message: You can get involved with “My Four Words” by jotting down your personal four-word story here on the Epilepsy Advocate Facebook page!
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: neutral
message: I have epilepsy and every little bit helps
author: Kim Frederick

label: neutral
message: Seizure free since october 25 2005 and no meds after a temprolobe was removed
author: Robbie Pursley

label: negative
message:
I was born with it myself. After having home through 2 surgeries. I'm happy to say I haven't. Had a seizure in 4 1/2 yrs.
The first surgery was a temporalobectomy. It slowed them down a lot. I went from having 12-15 per month to 1-2 every 6 months.
My doctors still weren't satisfied. I was on large amounts of medications.  On march 17,2008 my doctors put in a NVS Vagus Nerve Stimulator. Since I had the implant put in I haven't had any seizures. They were also. Able to cut back on my medications.
I will probably always have to take some meds but not as much. ;-)
author: Vickie Roy

label: neutral
message: Myh band played at the first and second annual National Walk For Epilepsy. We were asked to be the main act again in 2012, but I missed a deadline and we lost out. I miss it  sniff sniff
author: Karie Schneider

label: positive
message: Seizure free since 09/I'm glad u have this group! God bless you! I've been on medication since I was a kid an I'm thirty
author: Bethany Moutry

label: negative
message: i  had Epilepsy  until i was  30 then  i was told i am  95 percent  Cured .   next Sat i am being taken off the meds.
author: Chris Bullens

label: neutral
message: if all of us with epilepsy had been born 100 years ago we would all have  ended up in asylums!
author: Elisheva Alter

label: negative
message: Yes, I knew that. I once told a girlfriend "I have fallen for you" and then I did. LOL
author: John Finn Jr

label: negative
message: Lol i never had one standing but I can help my brother with his homework..
author: John Kayser

label: negative
message: Not mention that for some of us we would be straring right at the walls all day and not even realise it at the time.
author: Doug Gatrell

label: negative
message: That's a good way to say it for me because I fall down at times while having seizures!

label: neutral
message: yes..now a days we just use a fancy word for the same problem..I know I have it, unfortunately.

label: positive
message: I have to live in apartment with stairs and this is something I fear.
author: Shawnee Dawn Horn

label: negative
message: There are stairs inn my house and my mom and i fall alot
author: Beth Burnworth

label: neutral
message: my son's room is in the basement and that scares me
author: Cindy Clark

label: negative
message: I also seem to fall a lot.  I usually fall going up the stairs so I always hold the handrail.  Thank goodness our house does not have any stairs at all but I miss the exercise I used to get walking up and down the stairs!
author: Janet Adams Bonzo

label: negative
message: I usually end up white knuckling anything I can going down stairs.  I don't  worry too much on my way up the stairs.
author: Arone Bernacchi

label: negative
message: I would fall all of the time, so when I walk I always walk near a wall and use my hand to balance...unfortunately, I usually end up just walking into the wall...I'm able to laugh at it...I think other people think I am drunk half the time...if only they knew lol
author: Meggie Kathleen

label: neutral
message: i think i hated the drop seizures the most (my son)
author: Susan Caswell Brooks

label: positive
message: No swimming for me but everything else is good!
author: Pam Lawrence

label: neutral
message: For example, don't stick anything in a person's mouth while s/he is seizing.  Really, dad, a spoon? I'm lucky to still have my teeth.  He's still lucky to have his thumb, because that's what he was using prior to the spoon.  It is HIGHLY unlikely the person will bite off the tongue and swallow it.
author: Leah Norton

label: positive
message: Believe, support, hope together!  Continue to believe in a better epilepsy treatment tomorrow; support others who live with epilepsy by listening, encouraging & sharing what you know; and always speak up to inform & educate when you have the opportunity.
author: Loretta K. Boileau

label: positive
message: ACT. Follow my dreams because nothing can stop me. Epilepsy is just one part of who I am, it's not who I am.
author: Laura Hudson

label: negative
message: i tell others that epilepsy does not run my life, i will not burst out in a seizure, i am not a ticking time bomb, i am not contagious. If you have questions, ask! i'll let you know if i don't want to answer :) Talking about it and putting out in the open dispels a lot of myths and misconceptions.
author: Sara Garcia

label: negative
message: Become an advocate in your area.  Take advantage of local festivals to hand out brochures, teach seizure first aid, and offer a listening ear with an open heart.  Epilepsy advocacy is simply loving other people who have epilepsy by standing up for them, educating yourself and the public, sharing information especially updates in the local newspapers, making yourself available on radio talk shows and cyber networking, and enjoy not feeling alone by sponsoring an epilepsy "Family and Friends Day" picnics.  Any way you can spread a healthy word about epilepsy and help others who struggle with it,  It's a step in the right direction.   My ten year anniversaby as an epilepsy advocate is the the first week of July, just two months after brains surgery.  I'm not bragging just encouraging.  As the old saying goes, if it feels good do it.  Take my word for it when I say, epilepsy advocacy feels good.  Join me.
author: Diane Quay Keeler

label: negative
message: Drs I've encountered so far that are suppose to be helping my best friend with his abnormal seizure activity just brush him off by changing meds. It's time to understand that each case of seizures is unique and needs to be researched in a way that doesn't break a patients bank account!
author: Harry Grillo

label: positive
message: I  have had epilepsy for 14 years and enjoy telling my story of trials and tribulations!
author: Courtney Foreback

label: negative
message: I agree Courtney I have had it since I was 3 hours old and now I'm 25 and have over come a lot... Learning disability, speech problems, and I have a type of seizure that they believe to give me mood swings and I have learned how to control my angry and mood swing and we all should be damn proud of what we over come because many people would just give up and not even care
author: John Kayser

label: positive
message: I agree with you. In a way I am glad to have epilepsy.  It has helped me learn a lot and a lot.  I have had it for over 40 years.  When I was young people would tell me I could not do something because I had seizures, this motivated me to show them I could do it.  I have been to college, I still live on my own, handle my own finances and can do more on my laptop tham my caseworker can.
author: Cathy Wills Wydner

label: neutral
message: Educate myself!  I cannot dispell the myth's if I don't know the info!
author: Michelle Downing

label: neutral
message: im 25 and i've had epilepsy since i was 5 many ppl said i cant do many things becuz of it but i have over come those obstacles and im proud of it because i can help others understand what epilepsy is ^.^
author: Johanna Cespedes

label: neutral
message: I write about it on my FB, share and support others but Chris YOU are correct I can do more...
author: Zimm's Angels

label: negative
message: My best friend has epilepsy & so does my boyfriend...recently he had 5 seizures in the space of bout 5-6 min...he went to his doc & did a MRI...seems that he may have had a small stroke during that time...he has to have a sleep-deprived EEG soon...crossing my fingers that its not too serious...although it has taken him a long time to bounce back...doc wanted to put him on a mood-stabilizer but it will cause more problems...any suggestions?  Please le me know on my wall.....
author: Sara Spurlock

label: neutral
message: I agree with you Chris...I have had to deal with epilepsy a a child and now as an adult..It is realy time to break down the stigma that people with epilepsy cannot be thereownperson...I myself am gettiing my BA in Health Care Administration at Ashford University Online.

label: positive
message: This will be my third year working at the Jason Fleishman camp in CO. It's been the most rewarding experience of my life! :-)

label: neutral
message: The summer camps are a wonderful idea. I was wondering if you have summer camps for people over 50?

label: negative
message: My grandfather had a dog with epilepsy.  We use to talk about the meds the dog took and the ones my daughter took, if they worked or not!!  Funny thing is, that if it didn't work for her it didn't work for the dog either and vice versa.
author: Mary Charlene O'Hare Orlandi

label: negative
message: my sister-in-law's dog has seizures.  The first time I met the dog, it took to me instantly and hung around me all day.  She said her dog NEVER likes strangers, so I suppose it could sense that we were very similar!
author: Rhea Hansen

label: negative
message: I have epilepsy and have had 2 dogs with the same . It was very hard to see when Katie had lond seizures.
author: Eugenie Margaret Macfarlane

label: negative
message: Idk if it is epilepsy, but I have seen my dog have a couple at random, they looked exactly the same too! It was scary.
author: Jordyn Penner

label: negative
message: It's incredibly hard to see a pet you love so much have seizures.  It's surreal, knowing your body contorts in that manner & heartbreaking as you wish you could have the seizure for them.  I miss my Marbles.  <3
author: Julie Edwards

label: negative
message: I love my dog coley I hug her all the time ,take her to the park and eveing let her sleep with me when Mike is away lol.

label: neutral
message: except it says "There are no upcoming events"

label: neutral
message: We have two do it evrey day as remind me I do I were my purple wrist band

label: negative
message: If "optimal" control  means no seizures,the answer is no.    I wish it existed.
author: Eileen Warren

label: positive
message: But I never have given HOPE that in my lifetime, my daughter will be 80% seizure free, thanks to my pushing to try new things for her.  My theory is "We have nothing to loss and everything to gain.  If it doesn't help her it might help someone else."
author: Mary Charlene O'Hare Orlandi

label: negative
message: I am 50 years old, the siezures are hitting every few months and that is so much better than everyday. I can live with it.
author: Lorrie Keaton McIntyre

label: negative
message: If you feel like your doctor is not thinking outside the box, find another doctor. My daughter's doctors became stagnant and failed in running simple tests in finding a true diagnosis. Had my husband and I not gone to this other doctor we wouldn't have the answers we do now.
author: Cheri Kasseroler Roblyer

label: negative
message: Yes I agree with you Laura Locklear Dubois I am like you but I have my meds under control now found a good doctor that has helped me control it
author: Elizabeth Robles

label: positive
message: My daughters last doctor just loaded her up on all sorts of meds and never ran blood tests or anything I finally said that's enough and looked around and found a doctor that's more active in her treatment  he is trying new things new meds and running appropriate tests. I am so happy to cause the med we are taking her off of right now I never want her on again. She is almost completely off of it and her language and awareness has improved soooo much!
author: Roxanne Bartlett

label: positive
message: And she hasn't had any seizures while coming off of the med so in my opinion it was doing more harm than good
author: Roxanne Bartlett

label: negative
message: It took the 3rd neurologist to tell me I actually have epilepsy, not brain damage. It pointed out my frontal left lobe & says "this means you have epilepsy, period." The other docs told me I must of hit my head, hard on the right to have scare tissue on my left lobe. If you see your child isn't getting the proper care, don't settle, there are more knowledgeable docs out there :)
author: Eli Sabeth

label: positive
message: I appreciate my doctors efforts with my seizures, I try to push my doctor to try new meds, but my doctor and another doctor don't want to. They say that I'm fine with the meds I have now, Even though I still get seizures. It has taken over my life and it sucks
author: Juan Castro

label: negative
message: To learn more about reporting an adverse event, please visit our Adverse Events Reporting tab. Thank you. https://www.facebook.com/epilepsyadvocate?sk=app_125197820925384
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message: I've had many doctors since I was diagnosed with epilepsy and have gone thru so many meds, but I don't give up and I certainly don't let it get me down...I'll keep on fighting even if it means fighting with doctors! (which I've done in the past)
author: Maggie Carmel

label: neutral
message: I went years and years on 4 seizure meds and no control. Since I had my vagus nerve stimulator put in I have dropped to two seizure meds and have gone 29 months seizure free!
author: Denise Cairns

label: negative
message: As a Pediatric Neurology nurse, I read these comments, and want to do the very best I can to improve the lives of my patients and their families. Educate yourselves. Empower yourselves! Do not accept mediocrity. Ask for what you need. And I will listen, and try to help, to the best of my ability!
author: Tanya Hammer

label: positive
message: I've had epilepsy for 22 years and I don't know which changed more, my neurologist or my medications. I now have a great epileptologist who listens to me and that in my opinion makes him the best doctor near me.
author: Mark Allison

label: positive
message: 23 years of uncontrolled seizures. More medications than I can remember, a cranial lobectomy, a VNS implant, and a new drug trial have not been successful. All I can do is hope. That's why I follow the latest research in epilepsy, support causes like The Epilepsy Foundation, and read sites like this. It also reminds me that I am not alone.
author: Tracy Tieskoetter Clair

label: negative
message: has anyone looked into Nora Gedgaudas ? she has had success with patients on a very specific diet. kids especially.
author: Shawna Marie

label: negative
message: Even in Canada. The same thing: No total cure for that. only tihing is medic with full of side effects and putting your body worst. But you must all know yourself and it's not the doc that tell you , JUST STRESS get you in other side of epilepsy having already your medic.

label: negative

label: neutral
message: Absolutely, don't let anything negative describe you.

label: positive
message: Father-Son-Holy Spirit. These four words have given me strength to surpass my 2 brain surgeries in the last 3 years.

message: I like: Make Epilepsy Fear You!

label: neutral
message: my family loves me! ..... Representing my 5yr old little girl :-)

label: neutral
message: Absolutely, don't let anything negative describe you.

label: neutral
message: Yep but not the fact that they broadened it to 30+ that's kinda wild
author: Kelly Delmont

label: positive
message: Enjoy learning and also hearing personal stories - my granddaughter has epilepsy and her teen years are so affected by the disease.  I walk for other causes and agree that this disease, severe or not, needs funding.  A CURE for ALL, instead of treatment for SOME!  Best regards to those who contribute to this site...
author: Anna Louise Hinch

label: positive
message: You need to YouTube Jenny LaBaw and feature her! I am a huge Crossfit participant and Jenny was the 6th fittest female in the WORLD last year and had Epilepsy!! Great role model!!
author: Scott French

label: neutral
message: Where is this walk held?  I would love to participate in the future.
author: Brandi Paris

label: negative
message: My thoughts exactly Lynn, but mine was a little over a year ago. We are still trying to figure out meds that work for our son with little side effects and right doses. I'm seriously hoping this time we get it right
author: Ashley Renae World

label: negative
message: To learn more about reporting an adverse event, please visit our Adverse Events Reporting tab. Thank you. https://www.facebook.com/epilepsyadvocate?sk=app_125197820925384

label: negative
message: Gotta keep staying strong
author: Nikki Ungaro-Loyd

label: neutral
message: Remember Never Say " Never"

label: neutral
message: My mom and 14 yr old niece have it !!
author: Kim Owens

label: negative
message: Thanks, cause being from Canada, i really feel alone, & i know i shouldn't feel this way.  I live in Alberta, and had Epilepsy for 19 yrs!,  Sucks! :'(  So thanks, its first thing in the morning, so i liked to see that. <3
author: Dana Sliworsky

label: neutral
message: Coulde you put more info Howe do I sign
author: Alfredo Salas

label: neutral
message: Go to their FB "info" page, click on their website under "contact information" then click on "Sign Me Up" button at top right of page.
author: Mindy Roy Hauser

label: neutral
message: The signup is on their web site: http://www.epilepsyadvocate.com/
author: Tracey Holmes Marcelo

label: negative
message: i tried signing up - first the site told me my street address wasn't valid, then it crashed on me...oh well..
author: Beth Olarsch

label: neutral
message: no i did not... my son has this n i b scared when he goes into 1
author: Donna Mcleod

label: negative
message: ~WOW~ No wonder my head feels funny just before my seizures! Thanks for ALL the useful info!
author: Crystal Ann Teal

label: neutral
message: Zzz_zzzzzzzzzzzzing!   Kapow!  Brrrrrrrring! Patcheouuuuu!
author: Eileen Warren

label: negative
message: I have many different things that go on right before a seizure.  I have gotten a tingling sensation over one side of my head or down a leg.  I get a deja vu feeling when a seizure is just coming on.  scary. very scary!!!!!
author: Melissa Weymouth

label: negative
message: I get weird twitches...especially in my temples.  I am semi aware until the twitches start.  Then it leads to a full tonic clonic.  If only that electricity could be used for superpowers, I would be set!
author: Matthew Logan

label: negative
message: I never know. Always have them  at night time in my sleep. Wake up next day tired and exhausted with bite inside my mouth. No ryme or reason.Not fun.
author: Joy Kirlin Stewart

label: negative
message: I call myself Electric Girl! Looks like a serious short circuit! LOL. Also explains the headaches I usually have the morning of a seizure...getting ready for overdrive! Thanks for the info!
author: Georgia Lee Deakin

label: negative
message: Must be why my head was spinning so fast the other day, when I had a seizure..get kind of dizzy.
author: Susan Brammer

label: negative
message: as a parent, it is one of the hardest things I've ever seen my child go through...
author: Amy Shultz

label: negative
message: If I get really dizzy and my head feels funny I lay down and sleep and sometimes it will go away and other times not. I too have seizures in my sleep because I will wake up finding I have bitten my tongue or the inside of my mouth.
author: Cathy Staeven

label: negative
message: Oh wow now i know why i be so dizzy when i wake up sometimes i have seizures in my sleep i will wake up bite inside my mouth too with blood yuck & i call myself  twitche girl lol cause i used to  twitche all the time then have full blown seizure very very scary now im medicine so i feel alot bettter Thank God
author: Allison Tookes

label: negative
message: Thanks for sharing all the experiences and information. Watching your child have seizures is such a helpless feeling.
author: Paula Menefee

label: positive
message: I think everyone with seizures  is a superhero and has super powers.  I don't know how many times I bit my tongue during a seizure or felt so dizzy, out of it, headaches, and so many other things. But I always somehow get through it. I think we all have super healing and super strength.  Because no matter how many times we fall, bite our tongues we can always heal. No mater how painful it is, scary, hard to deal with, the not knowing when its going to happen or why and many other thing's. We can all make it though and it dose take a superhero with super powers to do that.
author: Clara Hutchinson

label: negative
message: I hate having seizures, I had them since I was 2yrs and I'm 26yrs. My mom has a short leash on me. Mine are uncontrolable, I don't know when I will have one, though mine can last for 5minutes or 6hrs, I take meds. Though, I've notice I only get'em when I'm stress,don't feel good or over-heated, just upset. I want to learn so badly, so I ask my doc if I can go back to school but on the net, he said yeah. But my mom thought I would get cut off SSI and my benifits, and so I had to cancel my app. I always wanted to take up web design. =/ so my life is boring.. all I do, is get up, take my meds and do whatever to keep me occupied. I have one friend that we go to places that we've too already, but she has a job so we hardly see eachother any more, and I really want to goto college online, make something of myself even though I can't work web-design would be awesome to learn by professional and i could make my own website, or help my mom..
author: Jenn Morgan

label: negative
message: I get daja vu and a pain in my left eye and the nerves twitch  Have 47yrs long time
author: Margie Lucas

label: neutral
message: no i did not... my son has this n i b scared when he goes into 1

label: negative
message: ~WOW~ No wonder my head feels funny just before my seizures! Thanks for ALL the useful info!

author: Margie Lucas

label: negative
message:
Over the phone!! it was 1977 and I was working at a tee shirt graphics
shop and this guy called looking for someone who used to work there.
When he found out that she no longer worked there he all of a sudden
"came onto me"~"Well I guess I'm going to have to take you out to
lunch instead"~ On April 6th,we met for lunch and before I knew it
he went and proposed one Saturday afternoon!!!
We've just celebrated our 34 Anniversary,we married on 2-19-1978
He's wonderful when it comes to my Epilepsy,always making sure I
have my medications and he worries if I go anywhere alone.
My cell phone is really only for emergencies,not just calliing friends.
author: Marlene Ferraro Emmett

label: negative
message: My husband & I met as a blind date. His best friend's girlfriend (now wife) was a mutual friend & thought we'd hit it off...we'll celebrate our 12th wedding anniversary this year! :)
author: Alyssa Catenacci Stepp

label: positive
message: We were in kindergarden together didnt know each other and later years where I was living he knew my neighbors then in our junior high school a friend called him and we talked and met the next day and been together ever since 30 something years. He is wonderful !!! :) God put us together!
author: Melinda Lowery OQuin

label: positive
message: Elizabeth Robles I met my husband in MySpace by one of my friends she  tells me to write to him I was a little scared to do it but finally I did write to him now he is the love of my love and I am going to celebrate my 2th year of my anniversary this year with the one I love <U+2764>
author: Elizabeth Robles

label: negative
message: im not married but i met my boyfriend at church.....i offered him a piece of candy and by the end of our friendly conversation i had his number!!!!!!
author: Kayla NubianQueen McBride

label: neutral
message: I married my true love 3 years ago! We met through mutual friends and met at a horse ride. They had a party after the ride with a band and Bon fire! That is where I met my cowboy! Very happy!!!!!
author: Shana Faulkner

label: negative
message: I married my best friend 11 years ago but we actually met in seven grade! Amazing husband my support my everything! We are a team and I struggle we epilepsy and now one of my daughters too but we know that everything is possible and this condition is not going to control ours life:)
author: Giovany Rodriguez

label: negative
message: Met my hubby online.(Thank you Plenty of Fish.) About 4 months into dating I had a medication issue and had a HUGE Grand Mal in front of him.He took it in srtide, didn't run for the hills and still loved me as much afterwards. I already knew he was a keeper. But that clentched it.
author: Kendahl Steggall

label: negative
message: I knew I had found true love when I had my first seizure on my future in-laws sofa. He got me to the hospital and stayed by my side for many trials with epilepsy.
author: Becky Fouts

label: negative
message: When my husband I first started dating I had a grand mal in front of him, I was soooo embarrased.  After the siez. I told him that it was ok, he could leave, I'd understand, he looked and me and said "Do you see me going anywhere?"  He's been there ever since.
author: Tomi Pintler

label: negative
message: In high school....been with me for 38 years now, guess it didn't bother him.
author: Sharon Bridges Schroeder

label: neutral
message: At church.  He was a youth advisor and I was youth.  Tomorrow is our 21st wedding anniversary!! :-)

label: neutral
message: Yes I have found my true love, and she is a Virginia cutie in my mind.

label: positive
message: Then there is even less of an excuse for not knowing better treatments and care!
author: Carol Hermann

label: negative
message: To learn more about reporting an adverse event, please visit our Adverse Events Reporting tab. Thank you. https://www.facebook.com/epilepsyadvocate?sk=app_125197820925384
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message: I have spoken over and over with my Daughter Neurologist and we have even seen an epilepsy specialist but over the course of the last events since the beginning of the year they have gotten worse plus she has a VNS..
author: Tina Marie Burleson-Johns

label: negative
message: My epilepsy pills give me depression ughhh! Thank God my Neurologist is takin me off of them.
author: Megan McKendrick

label: negative
message: My dad is 63 has epilepsy since 6yrs old went through every medication possible as he was a "guinea pig" has a VNS and Im happy to say my dad had a right temporal lobectomy march 30th..the surgeon had given him the percentage of 30% my father was having 5-6 seizures and 6-8 auras a month (sometimes less) and its been 6 weeks for either one.....
author: Erika Bowman

label: neutral
message: My son just had 2 on this saturday. Aggrivating when he is takinghis pills and still has them. With no tell we can never be sure.
author: Rebecca Susan Conner Klimek

label: neutral
message: My son continues to have seizures, despite medication adjustments; his best seems to be periods where the activity is a few times each month. But overall, that's better!
author: Yvonne Novak Matz

label: negative
message: I am stuck between a rock and a hard place where I cannot, due to side-effects, take all but one of the few meds that work for my types of seizures. Neither surgery nor VNS are options for me. I wish there weren't so many of us.
author: Cal Wiggin

label: negative
message: yes I did know...and yes I talked to my doctor...and because of our discussion I had L temporal lobectomy and have been seizure-free for 12 yrs as of tomorrow!!! Thank you Dr. Yeh!!!
author: Dianne Logsdon Huber

label: negative
message: It sucks, I had all the surgeries even vns implant, still haven't stopped yet
author: John Mihalina

label: positive
message: Never, never, never stop trying.  After 40 years of seizures, I am suddenly 3 years seizure free without surgery.  It just took the right combination of medication and VNS for me (plus a whole lot of patience, persistence, and determination!)
author: Audrey S. Autrey

label: negative
message: I do know that, infact I am one of those whose meds don't help, so I am having a Temporal Lobectomy in June.
author: Tomi Pintler

label: neutral
message: Good advice, I think, Tomi!
author: Laurie Marifjeren

label: neutral
message: This page is for friends of Epilepsy Advocate to discuss their concerns and share support and encouragement for each other. Please make sure your posts align with the philosophy of our page. If you are unsure about what you can post, check out our community guidelines. Thanks.
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message: Does anyone know how to talk comfortable with with someone without it.
author: Tim Murphy

label: neutral
message: l have epilepsy but l no what to diet :-(
author: Melissa Blanco

label: positive
message: as little stress as possible..stress just makes them more frequent..
author: Mary Zwanzig

label: positive
message: Knowing what triggers my seizures, learning to stay away from triggers (if possible), and/or preparing myself for possible seizures at any time.
author: Jill Troxell Miller

label: negative
message: full body control...we wish
author: Jennifer Cortez

label: neutral
message: Control to us is when epilepsy is a part of our lives, it doesn't dictate our life.
author: Rebecca Flynn

label: positive
message: @mary yes it does for my 13 year daughter when she has a  big test or drama in school is when I notice she has more ticks and jerks when she is asleep her happen when she falls a sleep
author: Misty Dawn Castro

label: negative
message: Amen Rebecca when my daughter had her first seizure it was crazy and my daughter was so upset when we found out she had epilepsy but we will not let this keep us down she will still be a teen girl and have fun ;)
author: Misty Dawn Castro

label: neutral
message: Being able to remember the past few weeks & function as a normal person would....It had been over 1 1/2 years!!
author: Ame Elsasser

label: negative
message: control to me means not having 2 to 5 seizures a day with the medication Im on
author: Russell Adams

label: negative
message: Finding the right doctor and cocktail of meds to control me without making me a zombie!
author: Pam Mason Reinfelds

label: negative
message: when my son doesn't have any more seizures and can live a happy normal life.  His biggest anxiety is having seizures in public places.  He hates it when people outside the family witness him having a seizure.
author: LeeAnne Hughes

label: negative
message: Getting to the point I can drive again. Add on another year after the seizure I had last week. :( And finding out WHY would be nice too.
author: Jessica Chance

label: positive
message: For me, stress brings my seizures on. I've had them for several years. Controlling mine consists of plenty of sleep, and for some reason a Pepsi. I heard a friend say it helps so i tried it. It worked for me for a little bit.
author: Missy Seargeant Heberlig

label: neutral
message: Seizure control means freedom to me
author: Shannon Edwards

label: positive
message: Seizure control to us is a non existant word. But...having better control means that our daughter is more alert and not seizing all the time and is happy!  As long as she is happy that is all that matters. God is in control as He has made sure that our daughter has a good quality of life. For that I thank her amazing Dr.
author: Angela Pence

label: neutral
message: Lesser stress, taking breaks when necessary, and staying away from unhealthy substances that stimulate the brain.
author: Michael R Cannon

label: negative
message: Each person who has Epilepsy is different as night & Day.
author: Marlene Ferraro Emmett

label: neutral
message: No seizures ,driving, no fear,freedom
author: Mary Wyrick Harris

label: neutral
message: educating yourself and making sure u take every single dose no skipping
author: Jess Gizas

label: negative
message: I like to call it "seizure management"!  Finding that fine line between sedation and seizure management for my 13 year old is hard.  She has at least 5 seizures per day now...we'll take it!  We've been status before and have dealt with lots more that 5 per day so we're happy with our "seizure management"!
author: Kim Leach Medeiros

label: negative
message: take every dose of your medication-I got on the right 1 23 years ago,and it has been wonderful!
author: Melita E.Pitts

label: negative
message: No meds, no restrictions  and no siezures.  That would be the only definition of true control for me.  In the meantime I guess it's life.
author: Eileen Warren

label: neutral
message: Taking meds (all 3 of them)making sure I sleep and my wonderful vagus nerve stimulator!  :D
author: Denise Cairns

label: negative
message: Sleep, naps, no stress, no late night phone convos, set working schedule, no clamping jaw when trying to sleep, eat healthy, be a social drinker, exercise, take meds as prescribed :) All & one can help but I have nocturnal seizures.
author: Eli Sabeth

label: negative
message: @ Morphine...most good neurologists take payment plans, none of mine have turned me away, regardless of how much I owe!
author: Eli Sabeth

label: negative
message: If I try to handle my stress levels..and eat healthy on schedule..I can remain seizure free without medication! I just have to keep in mind I have epilepsy EVERYDAY and live with it and not against it! Over 5 years seizure free :)!! There have been times I have had to go back on meds but in the past 10 years I have come so far and I am so lucky!! To all of you still struggling..my wish is for all to find "control"!!
author: Meggy Moo

label: neutral
message: ....if I ever had control, I would comment on what it means to me!
author: Stacey Phillips Cummings

label: negative
message: Comming to grips with the fact that for me, a seizure is possible and not the end of the world.  I'll gladyly take another than be on medication again!!  Sticking to my modified atkins diet and eliminating stress.  Telling families at the ED I work at to stop acting like thier patient is dying and stop embarassingly freek out around him/her.
author: Shirley Anderson

label: neutral
message: FIND A PLACE TO LAY DOWN.....ASAP... thats my control , if I get warning signals.....not always that lucky, but usually am.
author: Andy Z. Guitarzan

label: negative
message: To learn more about reporting an adverse event, please visit our Adverse Events Reporting tab. Thank you. https://www.facebook.com/epilepsyadvocate?sk=app_125197820925384
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: neutral
message: It means I will be able to drive again! Therefore leading me to more stable employment! Bring it on! I've not siezed since Dec!
author: Casey Zajackowski

label: negative
message: To keep our 11 month son from having to be entubated because of his seizures and spending more than a week in NICU
author: Devon Smith

label: neutral
message: It means being controlled without the side effects of medication. I haven't seized since 2009.
author: Athena Ramirez

label: negative
message: No alcohol, can't stay up past 10, low stress exercise, eating really healthy, no mental stress, no concerts, great meds. Which is really hard since I'm only 19 and was diagnosed 2 months ago and had 5 seizures since, I just want to drive again!! Ugh
author: Alison Hoss

label: negative
message: A guarantee would be nice but not going to happen, but for now I would settle for feeling alive once again and not zombie like
author: Joe Austin

label: negative
message: Being controlled without side effects of meds is correct. Not having a seizure is Awesome, but not having a life sucks.
author: Matthew Sullivan

label: negative
message: red meat no more than once a week, 1000mg extended release depakote at night, minimum of 7 hours of sleep
author: Jillian Gross

label: negative
message: Few seizures and still know you are alive!
author: Mary Beth Meggs

label: negative
message: To be ready for anything, to look at things logicly and not get to happy or to sad...to be neutral and never at any extreme point of the spectrum
author: Noe Avila

label: negative
message: not being under stress. It has almost been 6 months since I have had one.
author: Rachael Stoy

label: positive
message: I've had seizures for 13 years now and last week I was diagnosed with Lupus. Possibly that's why I've been having seizures all these years.
author: Judy Peebles Williams

label: negative
message: seizure control to me means getting thru the day without too many simple partials.
author: Donna Cameron Searcy

label: negative
