author: Lisa Henderson Reents

label: negative
message: I love seeing the comments on links like this because it allows me to ask more probing questions to my patients. This allows me to help them more and gives them more control over their symptoms/seizures. Thank you all for sharing!
author: Dr. Raj Bhayani, Specialist Doctor of Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT)

label: negative
message: I don't want to see my son have ANY sort, any type of seizure-that's my where definition of control is-but sometimes it's not that easy!
author: Lara Dinkins

label: negative
message: I have had some control for 3 years when I found out the stress att my place of employment was causing them and putting a strain on my marriage could not figure it out at the beginning but when I got laid off and started getting enough sleep and not being stressed that's when I noticed and now its been 3 years seizure free and I haven't had any medication
author: John Saldana

label: negative
message: I am so glad to see physicians reading this thread!  Seizure control really is different for each and every one of us.  I never dreamed I could reach seizure freedom, but am 3 years seizure free for the first time in 46 years - but I know that they can come back at any moment if I don't do the right things (take my meds regularly, get enough sleep, be careful with my stress levels...)
author: Audrey S. Autrey

label: negative
message: they tell me seizure control is taking my meds, dont get stressed, get enough sleep , being a mom thats impossible, i have no idea when theyre comming so i dont know what seizure control is

label: positive

We are still trying to figure out my tirggers and such nd my lack of memeory REALLY get in the way of that
author: Erin Verzella

label: neutral
message: I think everyone should have a patient advocate, especially if there is any kind of memory loss involved. A patient can become overwhelmed with the emotional aspects of what a doctor is talking to them about and it becomes very difficult for them to then connect with what is being said on a medical level. A second "detached" person taking notes can be a lifesaver during the appointment and after!
author: Julee Spangler-Sallaz

label: neutral

author: Nicole Heideman

label: negative
message: I have grand mals n lately up to an hours worth:-(  so I can't remember anything for long periods of time so I'm glad that I have friend's that r there to help me out n remind me when I forget:-)
author: Tracy Fowler

label: positive
message: Do you sometimes forget whether or not you have taken your medication?? ~~withOUT the medicine I have at least 5 Grand-Mals (with posticle paralysis/loss of voice) and countless Petite-Mals & others....so I'm afraid NOT to take it...ended up in the hospital with toxic shock/potassium so low I could've had a heart attack ...so after several trys I came up with a way to remember: IN THE PM I TURN THE BOTTLE UPSIDE DOWN AFTER I TAKE IT ...SO IF IT IS RIGHT SIDE UP WHEN I'M WONDERING IN AN HOUR I'LL KNOW I DIDN'T TAKE IT...IN THE MORNING I LEAVE IT UPRIGHT (never had trouble remembering in the morning)~~hopes this helps someone =))

label: negative
message: I explain how scary it is waking up from a seizure, how I had a miracle moment when I survived a ten minute grand mal with no brain damage, explain how misunderstood the condition is, tell people I got it from a slight head injury when I was a kid, and how it can be hereditary. Then I explain all the many types and signs of epilepsy. People are always very surprised.

author: Candy Gregg Johnson

label: neutral
message: Hi Candy-Actually, there are plenty of epilepsy resources available on Epilepsy Advocate’s website at http://www.epilepsyadvocate.com/resources/epilepsy-programs.aspx. Have a look.
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message: Hey there, wondering why your comment was removed? As you may know, epilepsy is a complicated condition. That's why we are working hard to get the information out there. We appreciate your comment but try to keep in mind that only a healthcare professional can give proper medical advice to someone with epilepsy
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message: Candy, I'm very sorry to hear that! I'm an epilepsy Advocate, and I talk to people all over the world who a wide range of issues, including your situation. Coping with epilepsy and patients like me are great sites that offer help, advice, and support. I belong to them too. It helped me with my decision for brain surgery and coping with epilepsy, and I felt less alone. My friends and family dont have it, and don't fully understand, but they listen and offer support. Instead talking to people with epilepsy has helped me accept, cope, and deal with the struggles of everyday life we live. Good Luck and Take Care! :)
author: Mandy Moyer

label: negative
message: I am an epilepsy advocate for Dover, DE.  As an advocate it is still difficult getting the word out about epilepsy awareness.  I have been to schools, small businesses. Health care fields.  But, it is not enough. Tried cup cakes no bakeries locally in the area. The 5th day program didn't go over well with district office of our local school district.  Can't do it in each individual classrooms, said there is to many 5th grade classrooms.  Any suggestions?
author: Carol Haney

label: negative
message: these are staggering statistics.We need more awarness.you guys are great.I loved this months issue packed full of great info.
author: Tracy Beach

label: negative
message: no wonder we epileptics have a hard time finding a job. besides the fact thay employers just dont want to be bothered with us.
author: Timothy McCleary

label: negative
message: My 10 year old is in a school district that does not have many cases.  She has several Petit Mals a day.  Her first Grand Mal went into a 45 min Status.  It's taken be 2.5 years but we are making progress in awareness.  She finally has the educational help, we are working on transportation.  The truth is in education.  People don't know what to do.  I am her advocate utill she is able to be an advocate for herself.  Don't assume all is being done for your child...You have to continuously follow up.......Peace
author: Diane Gowdie Hoppe

message: @Dana M Chally-Green: My family made our own. We used purple grossgrain ribbon, made the ribbon loop out of it and hot glued it to hold in place, using different colors of fabric paints, we  wrote/painted "EPILEPSY" on them, then put a tiny brass safety pin on back. They looked and worked great, and the kids were proud of their own special ribbons. :-)

I am 38 yrs old and my child hood friends are just finding out about my epilepsy! I hid it from everyone. Not a good thing to do. The more education the better! My new line "That'll learn em" have fun with it. It great to see these expressions. good luck!

author: Michelle Donnan Johnson

label: positive
message: They don't cost anything. But there is a waiting list that goes based not on When you applied but how quickly Who needs one first. You can Google  'Canine Assistance/Assistants' and itll pull their site up. They also have a FB page with all the proper links and steps you must go through in order to have one of these dogs. Even the vet bills are covered, as the animals are considered a service. My five year old son has sleep seizures, abscence seizures and more recently has had his first physical seizures. I came across this info while reading in the neurologist's lobby, while waiting for an apt. As my son stops breathing a few seconds into his physical seizures, this is something Ive taken a great interest in. Its a bit of a process, but they map it all out for you there. Ill try to find a link for you.
author: Katie Watkins

author: Crystal Ann Teal

label: negative
message: I have epilepsy too! I started having them at age 15, and I'm 34.  It's been a struggle, especially when I started having 5-6 seizures per day, tried 7 different med's, and nothing worked. I've always been heavily medicated in order to control seizures, but since I had a Left temporal Lobectomy surgery 3 yrs ago, I've been a lot better, and on the least amount of medication for the first time!
author: Mandy Moyer

label: negative
message: I have had Epilepsy for the past 5 yrs, and have only been seizure free for the past 2 months. My meds will be gone within the next 15 days, so I don't know what I face, besides the ER. I have been doing what I have to do as far as trying to acquire more, without sounding like a whiny person. But yes, more awareness is definitely needed. I feel as though people think I am just making excuses when I try to explain the in's and out's of the probs associated with this illness.
author: Dayna L Sapp

label: negative
message: I am facing exactly what all you guys are.  I am having major troubles with finding the right medication for me so like many I have tried so many different medications.  I also just had a left temporal lobectomy and that seemed to work for about a month and half  but then my seizures came back ...full force.  So i am back on many pills and we are trying to calm my seizures down.  There might be another surgery coming up but who knows until the new year begins.  I wish so many more people knew about epilepsy.  I am so happy that there are many people getting it known.  Together i know we can make things happen!
author: ERin O'Hayre

label: negative
message: As you may know, epilepsy is a complicated condition. That’s why we are working hard to get the information out there. We appreciate your comment and try to keep in mind that anyone with epilepsy should consult their doctor before making any lifestyle changes.

message: I have had epilepsy since I was 15 and am now 37.  Have had very many hard years trying to control them and about 6 years ago had vagus nerve stimulator put in it helped a lot. author: Denise Cairns

label: negative
message: my son is 6 yrs old, 2 year lekemia survivor and now a new diagnosis of generalized myoclonic seizures:( he is now on medication so hopefully his seizures will go away or at least get a little better so he can continue enjoying his life, he keeps falling down and getting hurt even though he wears a helmet, I just want life to get back to somewhat normal for him......
author: Rebekah Riese Kjendlie

label: negative
message: 22 days to go to reach the $200,000 mark! Have you picked up a Pledge for Purple Day yet?
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: negative
message: me too!! my son had an inutero stroke, which has caused a PVL on the left side of his brain, and its the reason he has epilepsy.  My Dad died of a stroke, so I always thank God that my son is alive!  I have always been fond of purple, now it means even more.  Purple is also the color of repentance, and I am Catholic, so I like it for that too!
author: Diane Marie

label: neutral
message: This page is for friends of Epilepsy Advocate to discuss their concerns and share support and encouragement for each other. Please make sure your posts align with the philosophy of our page. If you are unsure about what you can post, check out our community guidelines. Thanks.
author: Epilepsy Advocate

label: positive
message: I HAVE OVERCOME EPILEPSY WITH THE RIGHT MEDICINE AND BEEN SEIZURE FREE FOR 6 YEARS NOW AND EVERYBODY ELSE CAN DO IT ALSO.
author: Ruth Cummings

label: positive
message: Yeah!!! Finally the word for our children is getting out!!!
author: Loretta Neal

label: negative
message: I was diagnosed at 4 years old.. when I was 18 I went into an 'epileptic coma' for a week.. when I woke up, seizure free... until about 6 months ago.. I am now 30 years old... and after going so long without a seizure, i have to say ... This blows.
author: Cassandra Hall

label: positive
message: I was diagnosed when I was born,but I didn't have a seizure until I was 15, when my father was killed. It was then that I found out by a Neurologist, that I had petit,and grand mal seizures
author: Lorie Schulz-rector

label: negative
message: I had my first seizure 4 years ago & still to this day will never know why!  I've had EEG & sleep tests & been to 4 doctors & on 5 differant meds, after all that I found the best Neurologist & the right meds & have been seizure free for 1 yr.!
author: Stacy Vandeman

label: positive
message: I had a seizure at 15 and I am spreading the word about epilepsy by getting others to share their personal stories as well.. You can check out my story at www.myepilepsystory.org under Brandy's Story .....I actually switched to one of your medications a few years back....Thank for all you do to find better medications!
author: Brandy McFadden

label: negative
message: 1 out of 100 people have seizures!  Do you know how to help a person having one?  It is easier than learning CPR. You can do t.  Learn today!
author: Carol Hermann

label: negative
message: My name is sarah i have lived w epilepsy sence i was 8 what i mean my mother had epilepsy she was 10 years old when she new she had it i have been taking care of her sence then until now shes 67 and i also have a daughter shes 21 we first found out she had them when she was 13 my daughter is so kool i know cpr n how to take care of them very well im 46 ive lived this all my life thank u all
author: Delila Lozano

label: positive
message: My son Jonathan is almost 16 and he suffers from epilepsy....we are considering surgery because he is now having a seizure per week...I am mildly fearful of surgery but I have all my faith in God & science...
author: Jilma Ball

label: positive
message: It's not a matter of DOING on anyone's part; it's a matter of investing more money to research "cures" and make the medicine affordable!!!!
author: Mimi Bartley

label: negative
message: I have almost been 6 months with out a seizure it has been every 4 months after brain surgery i went 3 yrs without a seizure started doing retail and the stress started having them everyonce in a while after my meme passed i had alot
author: Rachael Stoy

label: positive
message: I am going to be posting facts everyday on facebook about epillepsy. More people need to be aware of what exactly epilepsy is, what kinds of seizures there, what can cause epilepsy and how it affects people and their families., etc,..
author: Brandi Twilegar Fielding

label: negative
message: Have tried to get involved but there are no support groups within driving distance from us. Have felt alone and on our own with my son's seizures and care for fifteen years now.

label: neutral
message: There aren't any support groups in Rawlins, Wy.

label: neutral
message: No support groups in Adrian, MI.

label: neutral
message: Julee There are plenty of epilepsy resources available on Epilepsy Advocate’s website at http://www.epilepsyadvocate.com/resources/epilepsy-programs.aspx. Have a look.

label: positive
message: Brandi Now that’s the spirit. We need more people like you to help spread the word about epilepsy within the community. There are things you can do in your community all year round!

message: My 5 year old autistic son was just diagnosed last week.  How can I get involved.  I need support groups and I would love to help educate, once I educate myself.  I am from Pgh PA
author: Loralei Perozich

label: positive
message: My daughter is asking her high school principal if she can collect donations for Epilepsy Foundation! has the posters and ribbons made! Her classmates have been wonderful since her diagnosis! God Bless all of you!
author: Heather Padgett Janik

label: neutral
message: Loralei, Joanna will be getting back to you to help you with your questions.
author: Sharon Stiffler

label: positive
message: Loralei, There is no where in our area for support of Epilepsy either, so I am starting one myself.....Its not easy but I am gonna stick with it, I hope to have one in place by christmas. I am right now in the process of educating myself..a 17 chpt. book that I have to read and then test on....I started with my county commissioners and on the 25th of oct they signed a resolution and my county is finally particiating in Awareness month...baby steps. And do not get dissapointed if you get a few doors closed in your face, because I am finding out that many more wil open...God Bless You and your son. Good Luck.
author: Joanna Snyder

label: negative
message: if I can be of more help let me know..PLEASE!!!
author: Joanna Snyder

label: negative
message: My daughter Kelly Brandon was born with epilepsy and diagnosed at the age of 5.She still battles with it to this day.I have helped other families in my area and will continue to help as much as I can.It a month to month struggle for some if not a second to second struggle.You never know.
author: Carla May Brandon

label: positive
message: Not a problem, I love you guys and somone needs to do something, Why not me!!!!

label: negative
message: I was told I had Epilespy in 2009;it was the first seizure I had every had at the age of 63, I must say God has watch over and protected me In February of 2010 I drove to school perfectly parked my car went to my classroom and a couple of my co-worker realized something was not quite right took me to the school nurse I woke up in the hospital emergency room. Glory to God I have not had one since. I might have it, but it does not have me. I would really like to know where or how to get the purple ribbon.
author: Patricia Needam

label: negative
message: Hi Patricia. We are glad to hear you want to spread the word about epilepsy by sharing the ribbon! If you go to our Photos page and select the Profile Pictures album, you can click on any image you wish to and then click “Share” to post on your own wall or to share with your friends. You can also right-click the image to save it and use as your own profile picture, email it to friends, or share any other way you can think of! Way to be an advocate!

message: As you may know, epilepsy is a complicated condition. That’s why we are working hard to get the information out there. We appreciate your comment and try to keep in mind that anyone with epilepsy should consult their doctor before making any lifestyle changes.

label: negative
message: Yes, were just normal like everyone else.  Some of us have never experiened a normal life so our lives with seizures seems normal because we have never experienced a life without them.
